09 February. Boko Haram attack the village of Bakalisse of Waza, with one death reported.
08 February. Boko Haram attack civilians in Maguirde of Kolofata, killing 5 and kidnapping 5 others.
08 February. Boko Haram attack Touski area of Bonderi, killing a fisherman.
07 February. Reports of gunfire at Mile 2 of Limbe as part of a continue "lock down" by Ambazonian separatists (assumed armed clash with security forces)
07 February. Cameroon military forces and Ambazonian separatists clash in Ndawara of the Northwest region, killing 10 separatists and wounding 6 soldiers.
07 February. Boko Haram attack Gouzoudou village in Kolofata, killing 2 civilians.

06 February. Cameroon military forces and Ambazonian separatists clash in Buea following 4 vehicles being burned by separatists, with reports of a child killed, a soldier beheaded, a man shot dead in the chest and others wounded. Dozens arrested by police at Ndongo checkpoint and and Molyko area of Buea following the clashes. Tens were arrested in LImbe the next day.
06 February. 14 people are killed at Bole Market of Meme by military forces.
06 February. Ambazonian separatists burn a school and the vehicle of a principal in Babadjou of Bamboutos in the West.
06 February. Ambazonian armed separatists enforce "lockdown" by blocking streets with coffins.
06 February (on or around). Soldiers dragged at least 9 people from their homes and shot them dead in the Travelers area of Bamenda following Ambazonian attacks and "lockdown".

05 February. Cameroon military forces clash with Ambazonian separatists, killing a commander called "Commander Virus" and another separatist in Makanga area of the Southwest following the group's raids in Muyuka.

05 February. Cameroon military forces clashed with Ambazonian separatists on "lockdowns" and set several homes on fire in Besongabang of Mamfe. Several bodies found on the streets the next day. Several coded as "10".
05 February. Ambazonian separatists kill 4 civilians in Buea, Tiko and Mutengene of Fako at the start of a 10 day "lock down". 4 deaths spread across the three localities.
05 February. Ambazonian separatists kill 4 civilians in Buea, Tiko and Mutengene of Fako at the start of a 10 day "lock down". 4 deaths spread across the three localities.
05 February. Boko Haram attack villagers near Ngouma and Makary of Hile Alifa, kiling 2 shepherds and stealing livestock.
05 February. Ambazonian separatists block roads in Ndop with trees and stones as a part of ongoing "lockdown".
05 February. Ambazonian separatists block roads in Babanki with trees and stones as a part of ongoing "lockdown".
04 February. A commercial driver and his assistant are killed by Boko Haram in Gasama of Logone Birni. The bodies are found the morning of 5 February.
05 February. An unidentified armed group hijack a truck heading to Kousseri between Dabanga and Tilde on RN1, killing the driver, his assistant and stealing goods.
05 February. Ambazonian separatists kill 4 civilians in Buea, Tiko and Mutengene of Fako at the start of a 10 day "lock down". 4 deaths spread across the three localities.
05 February. Ambazonian separatists kill a commercial moto driver in Bamenda.
04 February. A soldier is killed following clashes with Ambazonian separatists and military forces in Limbe of Fako.
04 February. 6 members of Boko Haram are arrested by Cameroon military forces between Goumouldi and Kerawi of Kolofata.

source: Mimi Mefo; Camer.be; Journal du Cameroun; AFP
notes: 04 February. Ambazonian separatists burn a vehicle and fire shots at an education delegate in Buea. Injuries reported.
04 February. A journalist, Paul Chouta, is beaten and stabbed by an unidentified armed group in Yaounde.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Naval Force
notes: 04 February. A group of 15-20 gunmen, likely Ambazonian separatists, kill a navy officer and kidnap others from Mokunda in Limbe 1.
03 February. A Nigerian dentist is killed by police forces in Ediki of Kumba 3.
03 February. Ambazonian separatists construct roadblocks in Bole Bakundu at Mile 15. [size=no report]
02 February. 2 members of a local communal militia in Abdouri Blama of Kolofata killed in a clash with Boko Haram.

30 January. A journalist, Paul Chouta, is stabbed at his home in Yaounde by an unidentified armed group, following a string of violence against journalists after their coverage of an opposition protest.
30 January. Boko Haram atacked Goumouldi village in Kolofata near the Kerawa border. 2 civilians killed.

assoc_actor_2: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
notes: 29 January. Following widespread protests over the weekend by MRC members, over 100 MRC supporters were arrested, includin the MRC leaders Maurice Kamto and Albert Nzongang, in Douala.
28 January. Ambazonian separatists shot and killed a police officer in Atuakon area of Bamenda.

28 January. 14 Ambazonian separatists are killed in Bafut of Bamenda 2 following clashes with Cameroon military soldiers. Other injuries and civilian casualties are mentioned but no specific information available.
28 January. 2 members of Boko Haram among Nigerian refugees in Afade are found and arrested by the Cameroon military forces.

28 January. An unidentified armed group opens fire on a mini bus of civilians in Muyuka traveling to Douala from Kumba. No casualties were reported, but luggage was searched, likely in connection to recent string of military arms theft.
27 January. Around 30,000 Nigerians from Rann flee and settle in Goura, Bodo, Medina and Afade in Makary, fleeing recent Boko Haram attacks.
27 January. 3 civilians are abducted from a field around Alagarno of Mora by an unidentified armed group.
27 January. An unidentified armed group burns more than 30 houses in Zelevet of Mokolo.

assoc_actor_1: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 26 January. MRC members protest in Yaounde in support of opposition leader Maurice Kamto. Police and BIR use tear gas to disperse the crowd and arrest 62 people.

assoc_actor_1: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 26 January. MRC members protest in Bafoussam in support of opposition leader Maurice Kamto. Police and BIR disperse the crowd and arrest 42 people.

assoc_actor_1: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 26 January. MRC members protest in Mbouda in support of opposition leader Maurice Kamto. Police and BIR disperse the crowd and arrest 13 people.

assoc_actor_1: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 26 January. MRC members protest in Bandjoun in support of opposition leader Maurice Kamto. Police and BIR disperse the crowd and arrest 25 people in Demdeng and Poumogne areas of the city.

assoc_actor_1: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 26 January. MRC members protest in Douala in support of opposition leader Maurice Kamto. Three protesters are injured by live gunshot rounds during the protest by police and BIR forces, as well as 13 arrested including Jean Mitchel Nintcheu and Joshua Osih.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: January 25. Boko Haram and Cameroon BIR military forces clash in Banki of the Far North. Cameroon military seize a weapon from Boko Haram forces.

January 24-January 25. Boko Haram attack Ngosi and Toufou of Mayo Tsanaga, leaving 1 woman injured, 193 burned huts, two rocket-destroyed classrooms, one health center destroyed, and 6 shops broken into, as well as food, an ambulance and drugs stolen.

January 24-January 25. Boko Haram attack Ngosi and Toufou of Mayo Tsanaga, leaving 1 woman injured, 193 burned huts, two rocket-destroyed classrooms, one health center destroyed, and 6 shops broken into, as well as food, an ambulance and drugs stolen.
January 24-January 25. Boko Haram attack Kerawa of Kolofata, killing one civilian.

25 January. A train from Ngaoundere going to Younde at Goyoum station is attacked by an unidentified armed group as it is leaving the station. Shots were fired at the train cars, but no injuries were reported.

25 January. 5 students are abducted from a secondary school near Natcho in Bamenda by an unidentified armed group, Cameroon government officials and Ambazonian separatists blame each other for the ongoing abductions.
25 January. 2 Lawyers are abducted in Buea near Mile 16 neighborhood by an unidentified armed group. Cameroon government officials and Ambazonian separatists blame each other for ongoing abductions.
24 January. Cameroon military and Ambazonian separatists clash in Matoh area of Konye, military forces kill 3 separatists and seize weapons.
January 24 (night of). Boko Haram attack the presbytery in Mangirlda, leaving at least three priests killed, including an American, and 12 others injured. Populations arrested three assailants.
24 January. Major deployment of military forces along the northern border with Nigeria after increases in Boko Haram attacks.
23 January. A teacher at Polytechnic school is abducted in Bambui by 3 from an unidentified armed group.
Week of January 23. Boko Haram attack the border town of Fotokol, killing 3 civilians.
23 January. Ambazonian separatists set up road blocks in Mamfe, causing disruptions to traffic, while police intervened to remove road blocks.
Week of January 23. An unidentified armed group attacks a vehicle of civilians in Muyuka. No casualties were reported.

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Gendarmerie; Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 23 January. Military forces, BIR and gendarmerie attack civilians in Rohkimbo area of Kumbo of Jakiri during operations against Ambazonian separatists. Military forces fire shots into the village, killing a child.
22 January. Ambazonian separatists attack a convoy guarded by the military in Ndop of Ngo-ketunjia, removing the vehicle occupants. No deaths reported.
Weekend of January 19-20. Boko Haram sets 99 homes on fire in the Aschigachia area of Mozogo in the Far North, injuring 7 civilians.
19 January. Military forces stop civilians in a taxi at a checkpoint and beat them in Jakiri, Bui.
Night of 18 to early 19 January. Boko Haram and Cameroon Military forces clash in Sandawadjiri, killing one Boko Haram fighter.
19 January. Ambazonian separatists set a garbage truck on fire in Mbessi quarter of Bamenda, fleeing on a motorcycle. Drivers escaped but one was seriously injured.
Weekend of January 19-20. Boko Haram sets 99 homes on fire in the Aschigachia area of Mozogo in the Far North, injuring 7 civilians.
18 January. Boko Haram kills a young member of a local vigilante group in Talla Mada (assumed armed).
18 January. Boko Haram attack Talamade in Kolofata, killing 3 civilians and stealing goods.
18 January. Boko Haram steal goods from homes around Igawa in Mora.
18 January. Soldiers and Ambazonian separatists clash in Kumbo of Jakiri, killing a civilian nurse in the cross fire.
18 January. Civilians demonstrate in Kumbo of Jakiri following the military forces killing a nurse, demanding an end to violence against medical staff. [size=no report]
17 January. Boko Haram attack Aschigachia near Kerawa of the Extreme North, burning cars and vehicles.
17 January. Workers at Paul Biya stadium in Yaounde protest, demanding salaries be paid before they return to work.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 17 January. Boko Haram attack Ashigashiya in Kolofata, burning 15 homes. BIR Cameroon military forces quickly repell the attack.
16 January. Cameroon military and police forces clash with and an unidentified armed group on the Wum-Ngouh road of Menchum, killing one police officer and wounding soldiers.
16 January. Unidentified armed group attack a school in Limbe of Fako. Coded as VAC pending more information.
16 January. The government of Cameroon forcibly returns 267 Nigerian refugees from the Extreme North region back to Nigeria.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Month of January. Military BIR forces rape 3 women in the North West region. Date unknown.
Week of January 15. Two people associated with Boko Haram are detained and interrogated by Cameroon military forces in Mozogo.
In January, around 10 Ambazonian separatists beat a Fulani civilian, stripping him naked and hitting him with sticks and machetes, in Alabukam village in Momo region of the North-West.

15 January. An unidentified armed group kidnaps 36 people from a bus on the road from Buea to Kumba at Ediki in the South West region. Ambazonian seperatists blame the government while the government blames the seperatists for the kidnapping. Passengers were released the same day without their possessions.
14 January. Military forces raided Ajayuk Ndip, Manyu in search of Ambazonian separatists and forced civilians to flee.
14 January. 11 dead bodies are found in the river in Yarbang of Mbere, as well as reports of kidnappings by unidentified armed groups.
14 January. Residents protest in the streets of Bafang in the West province to demand the release of their mayor, Pierre Nkwemo, who was arrested a week ago on land appropriation charges.
14 January. Ambazonian separatists and police forces of Cameroon clash in Mamfe after separatists attempt to try to set the police station on fire.
13 January (night of). In Wouro Kessoum of Amchide area in Kolofata, Boko Haram looted cattle and escaped before the military arrived.
13 January. Boko Haram attacks Guitsnad area of Mokolo, burning homes and killing one civilian.

12 January. Cameroon forces kill 7 separatists during a clearing operation in Alabukam and Mankon, near Bamenda. They also destroy the camp and seize weapons, uniforms and motorcycles. Fatalites spread over two locations.

12 January. Cameroon forces kill 7 separatists during a clearing operation in Alabukam and Mankon, near Bamenda. They also destroy the camp and seize weapons, uniforms and motorcycles. Fatalites spread over two locations.
12 January. Residents of Bafang protest to demand the release of the mayor, Pierre Nkwemo, who has been arrested and detained.
11 January. 2 separatists are killed in clashes between an Ambazonian armed group and military forces of Cameroon in Ekona of the South West region.
11 January. Boko Haram kill one civilian and burn homes in Guitsnad of Mokolo arrondissement. Guitsnad not found, coded as Mokolo city.
11 January. 8 armed combatants of Boko Haram loot bicycles and food items from the village of Amchide of Mayo Sava.

11 January. 21 separatists are killed in clashes between an Ambazonian armed group and military forces of Cameroon while soldiers were returning from Nkambe to Sabongari of Donga-Mantung in the Northwest.

10 January. Armed Ambazonian separatists and military forces clash in Kumba of the South West region near a local school, wounding three soldiers and killing and wounding "several" seperatists. "Several" killed and wounded coded as 10.
09 January. Boko Haram loots a bicycle, motorcycle and food. in Zize of Ganse.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 06 January. Cameroon military forces kill 2 Ambazonian commanders, General Obi and General Eyong in the Southwest region. "Several" other separatists and government forces died inthe clashes (several coded as 10). Exact location of raid unknown.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 05 January. Boko Haram steal livestock in Amchide, but leave the animals after an intervention of the BIR of Amchide. Two injured.
01 May. Military soldiers fire weapons indiscriminately at civilians following Labour Day activities around Alahchu area of Mankon in Bamenda 2, killing one civilian.
03 January. Dozens of armed Ambazonian separatists attack the SOMECAM Tiko Rubber estate and cut the fingers from around six workers.
03 January. Unknown assailants burned down the house of Chief Dion Ngute in Bongongo of Ekondo Titi.
03 January. Ambazonian seperatists and Cameroon military forces clash at the Brakah gendarmerie brigade in Lebialem. Three injuries to gendarmerie were reported.
Week of 02 January. A school principal in Bamenyam of Galim district is kidnapped by Ambazonian separatists. He was released hours later.

Between 1 and 4 January (ate unclear). Report of intensification of fighting between Ambazonian seperatists and Cameroon military forces in Kumbo of Jakiri after the President's New Years address to eliminate seperatists. "Many" casualties reported as 10.

31 December. Governor of the North West region, Adolphe Lele Lafrique Tchoffo, and his vehicle are attacked by Ambazonian seperatists in Bamenda near "Below Foncha junction", injuring a police inspector guarding the convoy.
31 December. Boko Haram clash with a local vigilante group in Gakara, killing 1 vigilante member.
31 December. Police hit two young men suspected of illegal market trading with a machete while held in custody in Yaounde police station.
December 27. Cameroon military find a store of weapons in Dogba outside Maroua in the Extreme North.
December 28. Moto taxi drivers go on rampage in Foumbot after one of their is assaulted by a gendarme over theft (coded as two separate events).
December 28. An unidentified armed group and military forces clash in Bamenda village after a soldier is beheaded.
December 28. A moto taxi driver is assaulted by a gendarme officer over theft, resulting in a "rampage" by other moto taxi drivers (coded as two separate events)
December 27. Ambazonian seperatists attack Bangourain in Noun, killing one civilian and burning several homes in ongoing struggle.
27 December. Boko Haram militants kill one villager and kidnap others in Tarmoua of the far north.
December 27. Three people are kidnapped by an unidentified armed group from a village near Belel.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 27 December. Cameroon military forces BIR and Ambazonian separatists clash in Liabelum, wounding the Ambazonian general called "Field Marshall" or Oliver Leke Fongunueh who died later in Taraba state of Nigeria.
December 25. Locals in Bagourain of Noun district beat to death two suspected Ambazonian separatists attacking the town for the second time in three days.
December 25. Group of Boko Haram members kill a civilian from Amchide in Kolofata.
December 25. Moto taxi drivers barricade Kienke bridge and the road to the port in Kribi, then clash with police forces.
Week of December 25. Ambazonian separatists and military forces clash in Bamali and Ndop in Ngo-Ketunjia, with 6 deaths including some civilians reported (fatalities spread over two events)
Week of December 25. Ambazonian separatists and military forces clash in Bamali and Ndop in Ngo-Ketunjia, with 6 deaths including some civilians reported (fatalities spread over two events)
24 December. Gendarme forces shoot and kill a civilian with intellectual disabilities in Ndu, Donga-Mantung.
December 24. The village chief of Youkkoutodou, Belel is kidnapped by unidentified armed group.
December 23. English speaking separatists attack the town of Bangourain in Noun killing one night guard (assumed unarmed), kidnapping 15 others and burning down 86 homes.
December 23. One person was killed and several wounded in an attack in Bangourain by Ambazonian separatists.
December 22. Three people kidnapped and then killed by unidentified armed group in Maber district of Djerem.
December 21. ADF commander, General Ivo, and three other separatists were killed by Cameroon military forces in Teke, a rural area in the Southwest outside Kumba.
December 18. Cameroon Development Cooperation workers protest at the Likomba office over six months of unpaid salaries.
December 18. Two Boko Haram members aboard a motorcycle kill a civilian in Bodo of Hile Alifa district.

December 18. Rioters, many of them traders, set fire to a police vehicle and truck in Douala at Camp Yabassi over land disputes and destruction of property. The traders also clashed with the police officers, who cleared the protest with tear gas.
December 17. Former general of the genarmerie, Jean Baptiste Bokam, beaten and robbed in his home in Yaounde by 6 people of an unidentified armed group.
December 17-20. Dozens of striking former employees of Chantier Naval demonstrate in Yaounde with police arresting many of the protesters due to the "unauthorised protest".
December 17-18. Seven Ambazonian seperatists are killed in an armed clash with the military in Bamenda, wounding 4 soldiers and one civilian.
December 15. Kanwing Andre, a senior police officer, beaten and killed by a group of Ambazonian seperatists in Ndop of the North West region.
December 15. Boko Haram kill two people, set fire to the village and kidnap six others in Tarmoua, Far North region.
Month of December. Military forces kill a civilian nurse in Kumbo of Jakiri.
15 December. Shots were fired into retired judge Paul Ayah's family home in Buea by unidentified perpetrators.

December 14. Fusi Naamukong and other drivers assaulted by military forces in their vehicles in Nchoubuh locality of Bamenda. Reports described their vehicles being shot several times and tires punctured.
December 14. Six children and a teacher are abducted by Ambazonian separatists in Nkwen of Bamenda 2. They were all later released.
13 December. Two suicide bombers detonated themselves in Kolofata, killing themselves and injuring others.
13 December (on or before). The home of the DDR Coordinator for the North West region was burned down by suspected Separatists.
12 December (on or before). An armed group opened fire on lawyer, Ayah Paul's home in Buea.
12 December. An armed group attacked a military base in Wambashe. The attackers were repelled by military forces.
12 December. Two suicide bombers attempted to break into the mosque in Igawa but fled after being spotted by a local vigilante group.
10 December. Gunfire was heard in Molyko, the following morning a body was found. No indication of the identity of the deceased or perpetrators (coded as VAC pending further details)
Early December. A civilian is abducted by Ambazonian separatists and taken to Teke of Tombel.
10 December. Ambazonian Separatists killed a female faculty member of the Belo Technical School. She was accused of providing information to the military.
09 December. A young female suicide bomber, killed herself and two others in Madahoya (Zigague).

08 December. Unidentified armed men abducted 12 University of Bamenda students. They later released a video of the students and urged others against attending schools. The Ambazonian Separatists are known for their opposition to the education system, which they view as an extension of the Francophone government. The students were later released. However, a statement issued by the Governor indicated that a criminal gang seeking a ransom was responsible.
07 December (on or before). Ambazonian Separatists abducted the Fon of Nso and two of his sons. They tortured the men and later killed the two sons. The Fon was later freed.
December 7. Roman Catholic priest detained by armed Ambazonian seperatists, called the "Amba Boys", on the road near Buea. The priest was released the same day.
07 December. Boko Haram attacked a village 10 km from Zigague, killing the chief of the village and his nephew.
07 December. A community vigilante group caught a female suicide bomber who escaped from an earlier attack in Limani, 7 km from Limani and Boudowa.
07 December. Military forces caught two female suicide bombers and defused their explosives. The military is searching for eight others.

December 3 - 6. Soldiers attack Kumbo of Jakiri and surrounding areas over several days burning over 55 homes and killing civilians. Unknown fatalities coded as 10 (spread accross four days of violence)
06 December. In the evening, a Boko Haram suicide bomber set himself off in Limani. Another suicide bomber fled.
06 December. Boko Haram looted livestock, bicycles and a motorcycle from Kalguiwa. They later dropped the goods amid military patrols.
05 December. Following clashes at the Buea motor park the day prior, military forces assaulted civilians in the motor park. Most of the victims were bus and taxi drivers.
December 5. Roman Catholic priest detained with guns and rudimentary weapons by a Ambazonian seperatist group, called the "Amba boys" on the road in Batibo. The priest was released on the same day.

December 3 - 6. Soldiers attack Kumbo of Jakiri and surrounding areas over several days burning over 55 homes and killing civilians. Unknown fatalities coded as 10 (spread accross four days of violence)
December 5. Military forces kill 7 civilians and burn buildings in Meluf of Yaounde in Mfoundi.
05 December. Military forces attack civilians in Meluf of Kumbo in Jakiri, killing 7 people and burning dozens of homes.
04 December (on or before). The Government of Cameroon established a committee for the DDR of Boko Haram and Ambazonian Separatists.
04 December. Ambazonian Separatists set fire to two trucks carrying tea in Ngo-Ketunjia.
04 December. Military forces and Ambazonian Separatists clashed in the Buea motor park for one hour. Two people were killed.

December 3 - 6. Soldiers attack Kumbo of Jakiri and surrounding areas over several days burning over 55 homes and killing civilians. Unknown fatalities coded as 10 (spread accross four days of violence)

December 3 - 6. Soldiers attack Kumbo of Jakiri and surrounding areas over several days burning over 55 homes and killing civilians. Unknown fatalities coded as 10 (spread accross four days of violence)
02 December. Clashes between military forces and Ambazonian Separatists occurred around Ekona.
02 December. Ambazonian fighters blocked the Buea-Kumba road in Ekona, following clashes with the military.
On December 1, in Kumbo town (Bui, Nord-Ouest), Ambazonian Separatists abducted Sehm Mbinglo, the Fon (leader) of the Nso people. He was later released.
01 December. During the weekend, Separatists and military forces clashed in Mankon. Three people were killed.

On November 29, Cameroon has reactivated village militias on its northern border with Nigeria after twin suicide bombings November 28 wounded 29 people. A group of 200 militia men were mobilized from 20 villages to defend against further Boko Haram attacks.

actor2: Boko Haram - Wilayat Gharb Ifriqiyyah (Barnawi Faction)
notes: On November 28, in Amchide city (Mayosava, Extreme-Nord), police shot and killed a second Boko Haram woman who was equipped with a suicide vest some time after a female Boko Haram militant detonated a suicide vest and wounded 29 people in a market place (coded in a separate event).

Around November 27, in Fundong town (Boyo, Nord-Ouest), women gathered in demonstration to call for peace and to mourn those departed as a result of the crisis in the North West and South West regions of the country.
27 November. Ambazonian Separatists clashed with military forces in Ndop.
27 November. Armed men abducted a barrister in Bamenda.
26 November. Ambazonian forces stormed Ako, burning the police station and customs office and killing two civilians. Security forces responded by opening fire, killing seven separatists.

Over November 24-25, Ambazonian separatists clashed with the Cameroon military in Babungo town (Ngo-Ketunjia, Nord-Ouest) and Batibo town (Momo, Nord-Ouest), leaving 65 civilians dead. Fatalities spread over four events.

Over November 24-25, Ambazonian separatists clashed with the Cameroon military in Babungo town (Ngo-Ketunjia, Nord-Ouest) and Batibo town (Momo, Nord-Ouest), leaving 65 civilians dead. Fatalities spread over four events.

Over the weekend of November 24-25, Ambazonian separatists clashed with the Cameroon military in Babungo (Ngo-Ketunjia, Nord-Ouest) and Batibo (Momo, Nord-Ouest) towns, leaving 65 civilians dead. Fatalities spread over four events.

Over November 24-25, Ambazonian separatists clashed with the Cameroon military in Babungo town (Ngo-Ketunjia, Nord-Ouest) and Batibo town (Momo, Nord-Ouest), leaving 65 civilians dead. Fatalities spread over four events.

On November 22, in Bali town (Mezam, Nord-Ouest), Cameroon's military engaged in battles with Ambazonian separatists, killing 21 separatists, destroying three villages, seizing a huge consignment of guns, ammunition, machetes, motorcycles and drugs.

On November 22, in Fundong town (Boyo, Nord-Ouest), Cameroon's military engaged in battles with Ambazonian separatists, killing 22 separatists, destroying three villages, seizing a huge consignment of guns, ammunition, machetes, motorcycles and drugs.

On November 21, near Kumba town (Ndian, Sud-Ouest), Cameroon military forces clashed for a second day with armed Ambazonian separatists who abducted students and teachers from Lords Bilingual School, leaving two separatists dead and freeing nine of the children.
On November 21, in Kembong town (Manyu, Sud-Ouest), a Kenyan priest at a church was killed by government soldiers who were firing at random from their vehicle.
On November 21, in Belo town (Boyo, Nord-Ouest), Ambazonian separatists killed the Vice Principal of the Government Bilingual High School.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 21 November. Ambazonian Separatists ambushed BIR forces in Lewoh (Alou, Leblialem).
On November 20, in Kumba town (Ndian, Sud-Ouest), armed Ambazonian separatists abducted students and teachers from Lords Bilingual School.

On November 20, near Kumba town (Ndian, Sud-Ouest), Cameroon military forces clashed with armed Ambazonian separatists who abducted students and teachers from Lords Bilingual School, leaving two separatists dead.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: November 19-21. Cameroon military BIR and gendarmerie forces burn around 60 residential buildings and city hall in Abu of Menchum and 3 homes in Muteff.
On November 19, in Yaounde city (Mfoundi, Centre), dozens of disabled Cameroonians staged a protest against the killing of handicapped people in separatist clashes.

19 November. Ambazonian Separatists opened fire on soldiers in Bali Nyonga. The two groups exchanged fire for an hour, after which the separatists fled down the main street. The military then set all the buildings along the road on fire. Local sources indicated both groups suffered casualties (unknown if fsatalities or injuries coded as 0 fatalities).
19 November (on or around). Ambazonian separatists set fire to the grandstand at the center of Bali Nyonga.
19 November. Military forces attack civilians in Ngwa in the Ouest province, killing 3.
17 November. Boko Haram attacked Gogolomiyode. Five people were injured during the attack. The perpetrators stole motorcycles and burned homes in the village.
On November 16, in Gogo village (Mayo-Sava, Extreme Nord), Boko Haram militants attacked the village, injured five people, burned huts, and stole three motorcycles.
16 November. A staff member of Buea University was abducted by an unidentified group.
Month of November. Military forces destroy and steal medical property in Kumbo of Jakiri.
On November 14, near Nkambe town (Donga-Mantung, Nord-Ouest), the Cameroon military continued to battle Ambazonia separatists, leaving 15 separatists dead.
On November 14, in Ndu town (Donga-Mantung, Nord-Ouest), the mayor of Nwa was killed by Ambazonia separatists.
On November 13, in Ndu town (Donga-Mantung, Nord-Ouest), the Cameroon military battled Ambazonia separatists, leaving 15 separatists dead.

On November 13, in Bafut town (Mezam, Nord-Ouest) , students and staff abducted more than a week ago by armed Ambazonia separatists from a school in Cameroon's restive North West region have been freed.
On November 12, in Mbot town (Donga-Mantung, Nord-Ouest), the Cameroon military battled Ambazonia separatists, leaving 26 people dead.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 12 November. A BIR soldier was killed during a clash with an armed group of kidnappers in Belel.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: On November 11, in Belel town in Belel district (Vina, Adamoua), unidentified actors engaged in a clash with an element of Rapid Intervention Battalion. One Rapid Intervention Battalion member was killed.
11 November. Military forces killed one member of Boko Haram and captured another in Mozogo.
On November 10, in Buea town (Fako, Sud-Ouest), Ambazonia separatists abducted a professor and staff member of the University of Buea.

actor1: Boko Haram - Wilayat Gharb Ifriqiyyah (Barnawi Faction)
notes: 07 November. The IS-aligned Boko Haram faction released a video claiming to have killed a man whom they accused of spying for the JTF in Chek (no coordinates available).
06 November. Boko Haram killed a member of a vigilante committee group in Tchika during the night and abducted the man's seven children.

assoc_actor_2: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
notes: 06 November. Maurice Kamto, former presidential candidate of the MRC, and associates were arrested. Following the arrest, they were taken to Kamto's residence in Yaounde where he was placed under house arrest.
05 November. Ambazonian Separatists killed two people in Batibo. The victims were accused of colluding with the military.

assoc_actor_1: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
notes: 05 November. MRC supporters organized a protest against Biya. Police forces dispersed the protest and arrested demonstrators.

05 November. Seventy-nine students and three school administrators were kidnapped from the Presbyterian Secondary School in Bamenda. Ambazonian separatists were believed to be responsible for the abduction but have released statements denying any involvement. They alleged the government orchestrated it to discredit the separatists movement. Disagreements over the language used in a video with the abductors also emerged. All except for two students and one administrator were released on 7/11.
29 October - 12 November. At some point during this time period, a soldier was killed by kidnappers in Belel.

assoc_actor_1: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
notes: 04 November. Kamto supporters protested in Bafoussam over the presidential election results. Police dispersed the protest. At least 19 arrests were made, while the MRC has said 38 were detained.
02 November. Boko Haram decapitated a man in his field in Baljoel.
01 November. Boko Haram killed four people in Igawa.
01 November. An Ambazonian Separatist accidentally fired a weapon, killing a 14 year old girl in the Bafmeng (no coordinates available) market, Fungom subdivision in Menchum.
01 November. Military forces clashed with Ambazonian Separatists in Bamessing.
01 November. There was on-going gun fire heard near the Balikumbat health centre, which the military uses as a base.
01 November. A vigilante group lynched four Ambazonian Separatists after one accidentally shot a young girl in the Bafmeng (no coordinates available) market, Fungom subdivision in Menchum.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 01 November. A BIR vehicle hit an IED along the Vouzi-Vreket road. Two soldiers were injured.
31 October. Armed men abducted the principal of GTHS Jakiri school.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Joint Task Force
notes: 31 October. Two members of Boko Haram were killed by the Joint Task Force in Boudoua (no coordinates available).

31 October. Ambazonian Separatists attacked employees of the Cameroon Development Corporation rubber plantation in Tiko. The attackers assaulted at least 15 employees with machetes, cutting off the hands of those who attempted to block the hits.
31 October. Military forces killed one civilian, injured others, and set fire to homes in Balikumbat, according to residents. The military denied this.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 31 October. Ambazonian forces attacked a military site in Balikumbat. BIR forces repelled the attack and killed three separatists.

31 October. Soldiers attacked Mbeme and Moshie in Bayang in the early morning. Seven civilians were killed during the attacks, five occurred in Moshie. It is unclear where the two remaining fatalities occurred so they were coded at Mbeme. Property was also destroyed.

31 October. Soldiers attacked Mbeme and Moshie in Bayang in the early morning. Seven civilians were killed during the attacks, five occurred in Moshie. It is unclear where the two remaining fatalities occurred so they were coded at Mbeme. Property was also destroyed.
30 October. Gendarme forces force civilians to flee and destroy property in Guzang, Batibo.

30 October. Ambazonian Separatists attacked soldiers in Bambili, sparking a clash between the groups. A US missionary was killed in the cross fire and four separatists were also killed. The Cameroonian government has blamed Separatist for the missionary's death but the US State Department has indicated that he was killed by cross fire.

30 October. The City Community radio station in Kumbo was burned down. Ambazonian Separatists are believed to be responsible for the attack as they have previously attempted attacks on the station master, whom they accuse of collaborating with the military.
29 October. Following the killing of a civilian by soldiers, Ambazonian Separatists and military forces clashed around Njenka.
29 October. A civilian was killed behind his house in Njenka. Soldiers are believed to be responsible for the attack
29 October. Military forces and Separatists clashed in Bambili.
29 October. Suspected Ambazonian Separatist attacked the GBHS school in Penda Mboko. The attackers burned student uniforms, school bags, and other materials at the school.
28 October. Military forces and Separatists clashed in Nyassosso. Five civilians were killed in the cross fire. After the clash, the military burned homes in the area (coded as a separate event).
28 October. Military forces burned down homes in Nyassosso village after clashes with Separatists. People fled to the bush.

assoc_actor_1: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
notes: 28 October. Members of the MRC protested against the election results in Yaounde. Police arrested the demonstrators.
Looting: 28 October. Boko Haram looted food supplies and livestock from Hamande (no coordinates available).
27 October. Anti-Biya demonstrators gathered in Yaounde to protest the election results but were quickly dispersed by security forces.
27 October. Anti-Biya protests were held in Bafouddam but quickly disperse by police.

assoc_actor_1: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
notes: 27 October. Members of the MRC party protested in the streets against the election results in Douala. The protest was not approved by the government. At least 50 protesters were arrested by police and the offices of the MRC ransacked.
27 October. Boko Haram abducted a woman in Kassibe.
26 October. Military forces continued to clash with Ambazonian Separatists in Babessi.
26 October (on or around). Military forces killed three separatists in Essu and freed the local monarch, whom had been kidnapped.
25 October. Ambazonian Separatists and military forces contined to clash in Bambui.
25 October. Military forces clashed with Ambazonian Separatists in Bamali.
25 October. Military forces arrived in Essu and killed four civilians, including a blind person. They also burned down several houses.
25 October. The corpse of a person with a mental disability was discovered between Weh and Essu. Date of killing is unclear.
25 October. Boko Haram killed two people in Amchide.
25 October. During the night, Boko Haram raided Igawa and killed two people.
25 October. A professor was killed by unknown perpetrators in Bambui who followed him. Clashes between separatists and the military occurred on the same day in the town.
25 October. Soldiers killed two civilians in Bamali then left their bodies at 3 Corners.
25 October. Military forces clashed with Separatists in Babessi.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 25 October.Boko Haram entered Cheripouri in Kolofata to loot the village and clashed with BIR soldiers. One killed.
24 October. Police prevented Cabral Libii, the presidential candidate from the UNIVERS party, from holding a press conference in Yaounde.
24 October. Soldiers clashed with Separatists in Bambili. Locals could not move around the city due to the on-going fighting.

24 October. Clashes between the military and separatists in Ngarum continued for the second day. Five civilians, one separatist and two soldiers were killed between two days of fighting (disaggregated as four fatalities per day). Other sources have indicated as many as 15 fatalities.
24 October. Soldiers killed a passenger in Njaynyuy (no coordinates available).
24 October. Military forces traveling from Wum to Essu clashed with Ambazonian Separatists along the route.

actor2: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
notes: Incumbant president Paul Biya was declared winner of the presidential elections, three weeks after the vote took place. MRC's Kamto rejected the official election results over suspicions of electoral fraud.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 23 October. Military forces clashed with Ambazonian Separatists in Bombe Bakundu. Six suspected separatist were killed as well as a man previously registered as a refugee (unlear if civilian or fighting alongside the separatists). Coordinates are approximate- based off of reports that the town is located 25 KM south of Kumba along the Buea road.

23 October. Military forces and separatists clashed in Ngarum. Five civilians, one separatist and two soldiers were killed between two days of fighting (disaggregated as four fatalities per day). Other sources have indicated as many as 15 fatalities.

23 October. The military launched several operations against Ambazonian Separatists across four Anglophone districts (Bui, Mezam, Dongo Mantung and Ngo Ketunjia). Local sources indicate 30 fatalities, which have been disaggregated across the four districts.

23 October. The military launched several operations against Ambazonian Separatists across four Anglophone districts (Bui, Mezam, Dongo Mantung and Ngo Ketunjia). Local sources indicate 30 fatalities, which have been disaggregated across the four districts.

23 October. The military launched several operations against Ambazonian Separatists across four Anglophone districts (Bui, Mezam, Dongo Mantung and Ngo Ketunjia). Local sources indicate 30 fatalities, which have been disaggregated across the four districts.
23 October. Military forces launched an attack on an Ambazonian camp near Mile 14 in Buea. The military destroyed the camp and seized weapons.
23 October. Soldiers pulled two civilians out of a vehicle in Njaynyuy (no coordinates available) and shot them.

23 October. The military launched several operations against Ambazonian Separatists across four Anglophone districts (Bui, Mezam, Dongo Mantung and Ngo Ketunjia). Local sources indicate 30 fatalities, which have been disaggregated across the four districts.
22 October. Military forces clashed with Ambazonian Separatists in Bambui.
22 October. Additional military and police forces were deployed in Yaounde ahead of the release of the presidential election results.
21 October. Military forces launched an attack on an Ambazonian Separatists camp in Oku. Eight separatists were killed and four soldiers were injured.

21 October. In response to a planned protest in Douala by political opposition leaders, security forces were heavily deployed throughout Douala and placed the leaders of the movement under house arrest (Nintcheu, who planned the protest, and Kah Walla, another opposition leader). The protest was successfully prevented.
21 October. Military forces and gendarmerie attack civilians in Rom and Nsah areas, killing 4 civilians and burning buildings.
21 October. Boko Haram abducted eight women and a baby in Vourkaza.
20 October (on or before). Three bodies were discovered in Bamenda. Some believe they may have been killed elsewhere before being dumped in Bamenda.
20 October. The principal of GBHS in Jakiri was kidnapped by suspected separatists. According to locals, he has been targeted in the past for not 'supporting the struggle.'
19 October. An armed group abducted six students from a high school in Bamenda. Local sources report that one of the hostages escaped, but this has not been confirmed.
18 October (on or before). Military forces killed 17 separatists during an operation in Ndop.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 18 October. Military forces clashed with separatist around Mile 14 and Mile 15 in Buea. One civilian was killed.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 18 October. Military forces clashed with separatists in Mutengene. Three soldiers were injured.
17 October (on or before). Soldiers killed a 13 year old boy who was seeking refuge in the bush near Muyuka.

17 October. Chairman of the Social Democratic Front, John Fru Ndi, home in Baba was set on fire. The attack comes two days after soldiers shot Ndi's driver. According to the SDF flagbearer, the attack was perpetrated by separatist in retaliation for Ndi's participation in elections.
17 October. Ambazonian Separatists kidnapped the sister of SDF president and presidential candidate John Fru Ndi in retaliation for Ndi's participation in the election.
15 October (on or around). A 16 year old was taken from his home in Bali-Nyonga by soldiers. The soldiers then shot and killed him.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 15 October. Military forces clashed with Boko Haram in Amchide. Several were injured and a few members of Boko Haram were arrested.
14 October (on or around). Military forces clashed with Ambazonian Separatists in Mamfe.
14 October. Military forces killed four youth in Mutengene. The military suspected they were separatists, however, no weapons were on them at the time of their death.
14 October. Boko Haram stole sheep near Mozogo before crossing the border back to Nigeria.
13 October. Suspected Ambazonian Separatists burned a car in Wututu after they could not gain access to a compound where a military figure resides.
13 October (on or around). Military forces opened fire in Bamenda, killing one person and injuring four children.
13 October. Boko Haram looted Bouaram, a village in Darak (no coordinates available).
12 October. Ambazonian separatists and military forces clashed in Weh. One civilian was killed in the cross-fire. The coordinates are approximate, based on location 4km from Wum.

actor1: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
notes: 12 October (on or around). Presidential opposition candidates from MRC, SDF, and UNIVERS petitioned for the annulment of the election. Kamto (of the MRC party) alleged the military rigged ballots in the anglophone regions.
11 October. Military forces killed four separatists in Misaje.
11 October. The military killed seven separatists during raids in Eshobi.

11 October. Military and polices forces stormed Barrister Yondo Black's home in Douala. This came one hour before MRC presidential candidate, Maurice Kamto was scheduled to hold a press conference at the location.
10 October. The Mayor of Kumbo was kidnapped in Sabga by an unidentified armed group. The mayor was released the following day, without any injuries.
10 October. Two civilians were killed in Kumba. It is believed that they were targeted by separatists due to voting in the election, which the Ambazonian Separatists had warned against.
10 October. Bareta (a pro-Anglophone source) reported that 15 civilians were killed by military forces in Ekona. This could not be verified.
10 October. An armed group, believed to be Boko Haram, killed two villagers in Vizik (no coordinates available).
09 October (on or around). Military forces killed four people in Dumbo. According to the military they were separatists, while other sources reported that they were civilians.
09 October (on or around). Military forces burned homes in Dumbo, forcing the local residents to seek refuge in the bush.
08 October. Boko Haram attacked the village of Goni Kourmi in Kolofata. One person was injured during the attack. According to reports, Boko Haram crossed into Nigeria after leaving the village.
07 October. Ambazonian Separatists claim to have killed four soldiers at a polling station in Bamenda. This could not be independently verified.
07 October. The military intervened as separatists attempted to set fire to the polling station in Bafut.
07 October. Unidentified armed men shot at a Cameroon Tribune vehicle in Buea.
07 October. Ambazonian Separatists attacked a polling station in Alou but were repelled by military forces.
07 October. Ambazonian Separatist attacked the motorcade of the Buea District Officer. Security forces repelled the attack.
07 October (on or before). Soldiers killed a civilian in Ekona, who they mistook for an Ambazonian Separatists.
07 October. Military forces killed at least two separatists (some sources indicate three) in Bamenda, who shot at a passerby while they were on a motorcycle.

06 October. The house of a local rights activist in Lyssoka, Buea was burned down. The incident occurred the night before elections were scheduled to happen. It was rumored that the resident received money in agreement to host a polling station on his property, however, he denied this.
06 October. An unidentified group set fire to the High Court in Kumba.
06 October. Military forces clashed with an armed group near Lyssoka village in Buea (no information available on coordinates).
06 October. Boko Haram attacked Double, killing two civilians.
05 October. Soldiers burned down homes in Bafia after clashes with separatists.
05 October (on or before). Military forces and separatists exchanged gun fire near Tole.
05 October. Military forces raided a separatist site in Otu, killing seven.
05 October (on or around). Soldiers beat a man with an iron rod after accusing him of being a separatist.
05 October. Military forces and separatists clashed around Bafia. Following the battle, soldiers burned down homes in the town (coded as a separate event).
05 October. Soldiers entered an IDP camp in Tole and reportedly began shooting. Three civilians were killed.
04 October. A priest was killed by soldiers in Bamessing. He had stayed at the church after mass and was later shot and tortured by soldiers.
04 October. A person was killed in Buea by an unidentified group.
03 October. The military defused an explosive device, found on the Ardori- Homeka road.
02 October. Two female suicide bombers suspected to be linked to Boko Haram set off explosives in the Kolofata market. Seve killed (including the two bombers).
01 October. A civilian was shot and killed by security forces while driving in Buea. It is unclear where in Buea the incident occurred. Another civilian was shot and injured at a checkpoint in Buea.
01 October. Military forces and separatists clashed in Bambili after separatist tried to raise the Ambazonian flag in the town.
01 October (on or around). Soldiers killed two youth in the Sud Ouest, who they mistook for separatist.
01 October. Military forces and separatists clashed in Kumbo. Several fatalities reported (unknown number coded as 10).
01 October. Military forces reportedly set houses on fire in Muamu, which resulted in the death of an elderly lady who was inside one of the homes.
01 October. Ambazonian separatists and military forces engaged in skirmishes around Buea.
01 October. Military forces killed seven separatists in Wum.
01 October. An armed group attacked Bonakanda, but was repelled by security forces. One person was injured.
01 October. soldiers shot and killed an elderly man in Wokwei, a village in Buea (precise location unclear).
01 October. Two members of the Kerawa vigilante group were killed by Boko Haram in the bush near Kerawa.
30 September - 02 October. The Nord-Ouest and Sud-Ouest were placed under curfews for fears of Ambazonian attacks on the October 1st anniversary.
30 September. Ambazonian Separatist cut off a man's hand in the Buea area after accusing him of supporting the Francophone government.
30 September. Boko Haram attacked Tolkomari but were repelled by the military. Two civilians were killed during the attack.
Assumed on September 29, in Maroua town (Diamare, Extreme Nord), local residents staged a demonstration and raised a banner during candidate Paul Biya's visit to the area.
29 September. Ambazonian separatists attacked the military barracks and neighboring police station in Mbengwi.

29 September. Suspected Ambazonian Separatists burned down the home of the Divisional Coordinator of the ruling CPDM party, Benjamin Mutanga Itoe. Itoe had recently been campaigning for President Biya in the anglophone region, despite Ambazonian rejections of the elections in the region.

29 September. Residents in Bali-Nyonga heard the sound of a car driving through the area followed by gun shots. The next day they discovered the bodies of two male youths. The deceased were not local residents and remain unidentified.

actor2: Police Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Prison Guards
notes: 29 September. Separatists attempted to storm the Bamenda Central Prison but their attack as repelled. Additional security precautions have been taken at the prison.
29 September. Boko Haram attacked Ngouma, killing three men and abducting one woman.
28 September. Military forces and separatists exchanged gun fire for hours in Bali-Nyonga. At least one civilian death confirmed at time of reporting.
28 September. The military launched an attack on a separatist camp in Ndop. Six separatists were reportedly killed.
28 September. A student was beaten to death by a police officer at Yaounde University, for failing to comply when a faculty member asked him to remove his hat.
27 September. Soldiers shot and killed seven men in Buea. It is unknown if any of the victims were separatist, but according to witnesses none of the victims were armed.
27 September. Military forces stormed the house of a man in Bachuo Ntai and killed the man and his two sons. Another man was also killed by the soldiers.
27 September (on or around). Military forces and separatists exchanged fire in Bamenda. No indication of fatalities.
27 September. Boko Haram attacked seven civilians in Tala Malabrahim, four were beheaded, two escaped and an elderly man was spared.
26 September. Ambazonian separatists attacked the district police station in Limbe, killing two police officers and wounding another. The separatists then stole weapons from the station.
19 September - 3 October. Military forces took over the Balikumbat health centre and turned it into military barracks.

actor2: Police Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Prison Guards
notes: 26 September. Armed men stormed a prison in Wum, freeing at least 80 inmates.
25 September. Armed men entered the village of Wangara and killed two civilians. The group also stole goats which were later retrieved by BIR.
On September 24, between Djabire town in Dargala district (Diamare, Extreme Nord), Boko Haram killed six people.
24 September. Soldiers killed two men in Ndop and burned down two houses. Residents fled to the bush.
24 September. Soldiers reportedly killed two civilian male youths in Buea.
24 September. Ambazonian separatists attacked a military base in Essu. Locals reported 10 fatalities, including seven soldiers.
24 September. Security forces reportedly killed two young men who tried to flee when they saw the soldiers approaching in Kumba.
24 September. Ambazonian separatists attacked a military base in Bonjongo ,leaving one soldier injured. The separatists stole weapons during the attack.
24 September. Boko Haram entered Yegoua and looted a local shop.

assoc_actor_1: MRC: Movement for Renewal of Cameroon
notes: 23 September. A member of the MRC assaulted an SDF supporter before a political rally, tearing his t-shirt apart.

22 September. The military reportedly mistook a group of civilian men loading a truck for separatists and opened fire on them. Seven fatalities were reported. Coordinates for this location are approximate, based on location a few kilometres from Kitiwum at the outskirts of Kumbo town.

22 September. An unidentified group destroyed a bridge along the Ndop-Bamali road to prevent military reinforcements from entering the area. A temporary bridge has been constructed but it cannot support large vehicles.
21 September. Military forces and separatists have reportedly clashed in Bafut. No indication of fatalities.
21 September. Military forces raided a separatist hideout and killed an Ambazonian leader known as "Commando" in Kumba.

21 September. The Minister of Defense signed an order placing Anglophone areas of Yaounde under military surveillance until the October 7th elections. The neighborhoods named in the order were Obili, Biyem-Assi, and Etoug-Ebe.

20 September (on or around). Military forces entered the neighborhood of Boh Kamadoh in Bali looking for separatists and beat five women in an effort to get information. They also reportedly killed a disabled man and 'molested' another man.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 20 September. A BIR vehicle hit an IED near Amchide. Six soldiers were injured.
20 September. Boko Haram looted the Goudjimdele health center.
19 September. Military forces reportedly killed two men in the village of Babanki

19 September. Boko Haram attacked the village of Goreya, killing four IDPs and injuring one other person. The coordinates are approximate, based on location being 18km from Blangoua in Blangoua commune.

18 September. The state government in Nord-Ouest has implemented new requirements for anyone traveling outside of the state. Travelers must disclose why they are leaving and where they are going, failure to do so will result in being prohibited from leaving. This measure comes as many civilians in the Nord and Sud Ouest are fleeing from the on-going conflict between military forces and Ambazonian Separatists.
18 September. The Mayor of Kumba's son and driver were kidnapped by unidentified armed men while driving on the Matoh road. They were released after several hours.
17 September. Military forces attack Acha Tugui village, killing two men and injuring one other.

17 September (on or around). A man was killed by soldiers near the Ndu Tea Estate, an area patrolled by security forces. The soldiers then dropped the body off at the Tatum Council. No further details on why the man was killed.
17 September. Military forces reportedly seized control of an Ambazonian camp in Njikwa. Approximately 30 separatists were killed during the attack and two soldiers were injured.
17 September. Separatists and military forces clashed in Oku. No indication on fatalities.
17 September. The military killed two members of Boko Haram in Zelevet.

16 September. Separatist forces stormed the Saint Joseph's College near Buea. Government sources reported 20 injured during the attack. According to local sources, the separatists demanded the school send pupils home by September 19.
16 September (on or around). Security forces reportedly shot and killed a teacher in Bali. The forces checked the man's phone then proceeded to shoot him.
16 September. The traditional ruler of Bojoke was kidnapped by an unidentified armed group. The coordinates for Bojoke are approximate, based on its location near Bonjongo.
16 September (on or around). A civilian was killed by a stray bullet at a check-point that was intended for unidentified gunmen.
16 September. Military personnel reported seizing control of an Ambazonian Separatists camp in Ekona Mbenge, without a violent confrontation. The military seized weapons and destroyed the camp.

September 2018. Verified video depicting Ambazonian separatists holding the decapitated head of a police officer. The date of the incident and the precise location are unclear, although the location is believe to have occurred in Belo.
Month of September. Residents protest poor energy provision in Dimako, stopping traffic on the RN 10 from Yaounde to Bertoua. [size=crowds]
14 September. Ambazonian separatists and military forces reportedly clashed in Bafut. According to local sources, civilians accounted for the majority of the 'half a dozen' fatalities (coded as 6).

Property destruction: 14 September. Following clashes against Ambazonian separatists in the area, military forces reportedly burned homes in Tadu. Residents have reportedly been displaced, seeking refuge in the bush. Location coordinates are approximate.
13 September. Separatists launched an attack on a military base in Nkwen. The military forces repelled the attackers, killing six of the separatists.

12 September. Ambazonian separatists and military forces have reportedly been clashing around Tadu. Locals reported fatalities on both sides (coded as 10). The coordinates for Tadu are approximate, based on its proximity to Kumbo within the Bui district.
12 September. Guards at state-owned telecommunications corporation Camtel's office in Limbe demonstrated in front of the building to demand unpaid salaries.
12 September. The traditional leader of Wututu was kidnapped by armed men. The military freed him on 14 September, however, he sustained a bullet injury during the military's attack on his captors.
11 September. The body of a soldier was discovered in Muea. No further details provided. The military and Ambazonian Separatists clashed in the town earlier in the week.
11 September. Separatists reportedly attacked military forces at mile 16 in Muea. One police officer and three separatists were reportedly killed during the clash.

11 September. Military forces reportedly killed 15 separatists and captured two others during a raid on a hideout in Chomba. They also recovered arms and ammunition. Two soldiers reportedly sustained injuries.

11 September. Local residents reported an attack on Dyounde by Boko Haram. The attackers were repelled by a local militia group. Coordinates were approximated based on 15km from Double and near Ngalbiwa.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Joint Task Force
notes: 11 September. Boko Haram ambushed a multinational task force in Limani, killing one.
09 September. Separatists attacked the police station and gendarmerie barracks in Oku. Three police officers were reportedly abducted during the attack. No indication of fatalities.
09 September. The Russian ambassador to Cameroon was reportedly attacked at a hotel in Yaounde by unidentified armed men.
09 September. Two youths were killed in Ekona, reportedly by the military.

Arrests: 08 September. Security forces detained 40 armed individuals sailing on three boats off the coast of Limbe. It is believed they were sailing from Nigeria to Cameroon to provide arms and combat support to Ambazonian Separatists.

08 September. Separatists launched an attack on a road construction site at the entrance to Bamenda. During the attack at least one civilian was killed (some sources indicate two fatalities). The separatists used the equipment to dig a large hole in the road, effectively cutting off the transportation route to Bamenda.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 08 September. Boko Haram attempted to loot a shop in Gouzoudou but were repelled by BIR forces.
07 September. A father and his three sons were shot by the military. They were reportedly mistaken for secessionists.
07 September. Hundreds of women protested in Bamenda. The women protested against the continued conflict in the region.
Weapons seizure: 05 September. The military announced the seizure of over 800 firearms from armed separatists in Nord-Ouest.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 05 September. Boko Haram ambushed a Rapid Intervention Battalion vehicle with a rocket in Malloumri (Kolofata). Five military personnel were wounded in the attack.
05 September. A civilian car hit a landmine in Zourou. No indication of fatalities.

04 September. The Military reported operations against Ambazonian Separatists in Ndop, Bamessing, and Bambalang. The Separatists camps were destroyed. A 'dozen' fatalities were reported (coded as 12 then disaggregated between the three locations).

04 September. The Military reported operations against Ambazonian Separatists in Ndop, Bamessing, and Bambalang. The Separatists camps were destroyed. A 'dozen' fatalities were reported (coded as 12 then disaggregated between the three locations).

04 September. The Military reported operations against Ambazonian Separatists in Ndop, Bamessing, and Bambalang. The Separatists camps were destroyed. A 'dozen' fatalities were reported (coded as 12 then disaggregated between the three locations).

04 September. Ambazonian Separatists reportedly entered Bamenda in the morning and went to the hotel where the Minister of Education was staying. The group then clashed with military forces in the city. The government reports three fatalities, while other sources have indicated five.

04 September. The military launched an attack against Ambazonian separatists in the town of Yemngeh, 10 km from Zhoa in Menchum Division (North West) (approx. Coordinates used at 10km from Zoa). According to the army, 27 separatists were killed.
04 September. The Fon of the Bafut kingdom was kidnapped by separatists who alleged he was supporting military efforts against the group. He was released by the assailants a few hours later.
04 September. Two persons were killed when Boko Haram attacked Gouzoudou.
03 September. A Principal and seven students were kidnapped by an armed group. The assailants amputated two of the principal's fingers before he was later released, along with two of the students.
03 September. Boko Haram attacked Fotokol/Djabrali and killed two persons.

02 September. Ambazonian separatists and the military reportedly clashed in the village of Mukanga in Muyuka. Clashes also occurred at the center of Muyuka on the same day (coded separately). No fatalities reported.
02 September. A police officer was kidnapped in Kumbo. Ambazonian Separatists are believed to be responsible for the abduction.
02 September. The army clashed with Ambazonian separatists in Muyuka. Four separatists were killed and three soldiers were reportedly injured.
01 September. The body of a local radio employee was found. He had reportedly been detained by security forces the day before.
01 September. During the night, the Director of Bamali school was killed by unidentified armed men.

01 September. Military forces reportedly attacked the town of Pinyin in Santa subdivision (Nord-Ouest) - specifically the Kwindegli, Hausa, Ndanpang, and Ngali neighborhoods. Unconfirmed reports have put the death toll at 5.
Security measures: 31 August. The mayor of Buea banned motorbikes within the municipality in an effort to curb kidnappings and insecurity.
30 August. Judge Ekambi Alexander of the Ndop High Court was kidnapped from his home in Buea. Ambazonian Separatists are believed to be responsible for the kidnapping.
30 August. Boko Haram attacked Matakaya. One person was killed.
30 August. Boko Haram attacked the town of Fotokol and looted shops in the town. One fatality was reported.
29 August. Women gathered in the streets of Buea to call for peace and negotations.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Presidential Guard
notes: Recruitment: 28 August. The Ministry of Defense announced the recruitment of 2,600 new troops to join the Rapid Intervention Battalion and the Presidential Guard.
28 August. In retaliation for the deaths of two soldiers the week prior, military personnel attacked the village of Zoa, 20km from Wum, burning down houses.
28 August. A retired soldier was killed by separatists who suspected he was providing support to soldiers in Guzang.
On 24 August, at least two gendarmes were killed by suspected separatists in Zhoa, Wum, during clashes.
24 August. The military reported killing 10 Ambazonian Separatists in Bekora and Lipenja. The fatalities were disaggregated between the villages.
24 August. The military reported killing 10 Ambazonian Separatists in Bekora and Lipenja. The fatalities were disaggregated between the villages.
24 August. 49 plantation workers were attacked and tortured by Ambazonian separatists in Mafange of Tiko. No casualties reported.
On 24 August, BH men and Cameroonian soldiers clashed in Nguetchewe: no available toll.
Report of massive arrests and "torture" by soldiers in the Wum area in reprisal for the kidnapping of the President of the Wum High Court on 21 August by suspected separatists. Toll unavailable.
On 22 August, separatits attacked the Cameroonian army in its Furu-Awa, Menchum, camp and seized an important number of weapons. Several soldiers were wounded.
On 21 August, the President of the Court of First Instance in Wum was kidnapped on the Bamenda-Wum highway by suspected separatists.
On 20 August, a man was killed by BH men in Fadje, Fotokol.
On 17 August, 2 people were killed in Hayabe Arabe, Mora, during a raid by BH.
On 17 August, a trader was killed by BH men between Tolkomari and Bornori Gana, Kolofata.
On 16 August, the first assistant mayor of the Ndop council, Nkoketunjia Division of the North West region was reportedly abducted by unidentified armed men.
On 15 August, a shootout was witnessed around Muea, in Buea, South West region, as gunmen attacked soldiers leading a convoy of trucks out of the region.
On 15 August, a shootout was witnessed in Tole, Buea, between armed men and security forces. One civilian injured and residents fleeing to the bushes for safety.

On 14 August, some armed men attacked a convoy transporting the CPDM Member of parliament for Ngoketunjia Njingum Musa, in Babungo, Ngoketunjia Division. At least 7 separatists, 4 soldiers and one civilian were killed, several others injured.
On 14 August, clashes between soldiers and unknown gunmen were recorded in Bamenda, North West region. One dead.
On 14 August, Cameroonian forces reportedly killed at least 5 separatists and freed a hostage during an attack carried out on a separatist camp in Tabli, Lebialem division.
On 14 August, suspected separatists tortured a Cameroonian soldier in Ediki. A video of his killing emerged online, showing him brought to a mass grave.
On 13 August, BH and Cameroonian soldiers clashed in a locality close to Garno, Makary: 2 soldiers and 8 BH men dead, several wounded.
On 13 August, Cameroonian soldiers and BH men clashed in Garno, Fotokol, Logone-et-Chari: 8 BH dead, 2 prisonners, 3 wounded.
On 12 August, a traditional chief of the Ekondo Titi commune was assassinated by some armed men in Ekondo Titi, Ndian.
Looting: On 12 August, BH men looted a herd of 150 cattle around Fotokol, Logone-et-Chari.

On 11 August, some armed men attacked the residence of the Secretary General of the President in Ngoh Ngoh in Yaounde. The shootout with the military guards led to the killing of at least two of the attackers while the others succeeded to escape. Some sources claimed this event was fabricated.
On 11 August, the chief of the Naga health center, Darak, was kidnapped by Boko Haram men.
On 11 August, BH men attacked Cameroonian soldiers in Gosi, Mokolo, Mayo Tsanaga: 1 assailant killed and several wounded.
On 11 August, BH men kidnapped a woman in Gore Djidda, 26km from Makary, close to the Lake Chad.
Property destruction: On 10 August, at least five buses belonging to the Mondial transport agency were burnt down by unknown men.
On 9 August, Boko Haram men killed a man at his residence in Limani, Mayo Sava.
On 8 August, BH men attacked the Afade village: 7 BH killed and 1 arrested after clashes with Cameroonian soldiers.
Non-violent activity: Around 6 August, Cameroonian forces reportedly attacked and harassed several times the staff of the Mbingo Baptist hospital, Boyo County.
Property destruction: Around 6 August, Cameroonian forces reportedly shut down and damaged health centers in the Momo County.
Around 6 August, Cameroonian forces reportedly attacked a local government health unit in Mbonge, Meme County. A sick victim was burned to death.
Around 6 August, Cameroonian forces reportedly killed a medical doctor and his wife in Mbengwi, Momo.
Around 6 August, Cameroonian forces reportedly opened fire at an ambulance transporting patients between Mbingo Baptist Hospital and the Bamenda General Hospital, leaving a nurse seriously injured.
On 6 August, BH men attacked the Zaman village, 17 km from Makary, killing one vigilante.
On 5 August, Cameroonian and separatists forces clashed in Tombel, Kupe Muanenguba county. No available toll.
On 5 August, 4 gendarmes were killed in Esu, a village near Wum, North-Ouest, as they were ambushed by possibly separatists. 6 assailants also dead.
On 5 August, BH men attacked the Ngame village, 15km from Waza, firing shots in the air that forced the populations to flee and looting the entire village.
On or around 4 August, separatists ambushed a convoy of Cameroonian forces in Bafut, Bamenda. 8 soldiers and a separatist dead.
On or around 4 August, clashes between Cameroonian and Separatists forces erupted in Mbengwi, Momo. Toll unavailable.
On or around 4 August, clashes between Cameroonian and separatists forces erupted in Belo, Boyo County. Toll unavailable.
On 4 August, a police officer was killed at his home by unidentified men in Mutengene, Fako.
On 4 August, the Divisional Officer of the Menchum valley was kidnapped by armed men on the Bamenda - Wum road. He was freed two days later.
On or around 4 August Cameroonian forces set fire to the Kake Kumba village, Meme.
On 3 August, 3 BH fighters were killed during clashes with Cameroonian soldiers in Ldaoutsaf, Mayo Moskota.
On 3 August, a man was killed in Gakara during a Boko Haram attack.

On 1 August, a gendarme shot and killed a civilian after he refused to stop at a checkpoint near Mbouda between Batcham and Balenssing, Bamboutos. The residents then attacked the police post in Batcham to find the gendarme and avenge their friend.

On 1 August, a gendarme shot and killed a civilian after he refused to stop at a checkpoint near Mbouda between Batcham and Balenssing, Bamboutos. The residents then attacked the police post in Batcham to find the gendarme and avenge their friend.
On 31 July, the mayor of Buea organised a demonstration in support of the government in Buea, gathering some 200 people.
On 31 July, a Boko Haram man was killed during clashes with the Cameroonian army in Amchide.
On 31 July, 3 Cameroonian gendarmes were ambushed and severely wounded as Ambazonian separatists attacked them on the Wum-Bamenda axis.
On 30 July, clashes between armed separatists and Cameroonian security forces resumed in Ndop, Ngohketunjia Division.
On 30 July, 9 young Anglophone Cameroonians were executed by security forces tracking separatists in Buea.
On 29 July, at least 4 civilians were killed by a suspected BH landmine explosion in Blamahadji village on the route to Banki, Nigeria.
On 28 July, unknown gunmen attacked the police post in Kumba.
On 28 July, suspected armed separatists attacked the Ndop prison, Ngohketunjia Division, with gunfire and arson, freeing hundreds of inmates and stealing ammunitions.
On 28 July, BH men attacked Hina killing 5 men and kidnapping 1.
On 28 July, the son of the local chief was kidnapped by BH militants in Maigobouri, Mayo Moskota. His body wound found on 30 July.
On 26 July, a man was killed by BH men in Goldavi, Mayo Moskota.
On 26 July a farmer was killed by Boko Haram militants in his field located in Zeneme, Mozogo, Extreme-Nord. A similar attack occurred a week before in Mozogo.
On 26 July, a civilian was killed in Baljoel, Mayo Moskota by BH men for the second time in one week.
On 24 July Cameroon Military Forces killed a Boko Haram militant in Kouyape, Extreme-Nord.
On 24 July a villager was kidnapped and killed by Boko Haram militants in Blangoua, Extreme-Nord.
On 24 July 5 civilians were killed by Boko Haram militants in Gouzoudou, Kolofata, Extreme-Nord.
On 24 July, Boko Haram men attacked the Talomari village, Kolofata, killing 5 people and wounding 3.
On 24 July, BH men ambushed Cameroonian soldiers in Kamdjidji, Zamga, Mozogo. 15 BH killed.
On 24 July, a civilian was kidnapped in Baljoel, Mayo Moskota by BH men. His body was found the following day.
Looting: On 23 July, unidentified armed men ambushed some traders in Waza robbing them of all their possessions.
On 22 July 11 civilians were kidnapped by Boko Haram militants in Greya, Extreme-Nord. The victims were later released by the army. No fatalities were reported.
On 22 July, BH men attacked Makary, Logone et Chari, killing a herder and seizing 98 goats.
On 22 July, BH men attacked the Souargue village, Hile Alifa, one man kidnapped.
On 22 July, BH men attacked the Talakachi village, Makary: 3 civilians and a BH man killed in the ensuing clash with the defending residents.
On 21 July a man was killed and cattle stolen during a raid by Boko Haram in the village of Goldavi, Mozogo Extreme-Nord.
On 21 July, Boko Haram killed a person in Goldavi and stole 13 sheeps.
On 20 July, unidentified men killed a priest near Muyuka.

assoc_actor_1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Gendarmerie; Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Late July. Military soldiers, BIR and gendarmerie forces attack at least 25 civilians and loot property in Kumbo of Jakiri in search of Ambazonian separatists. 1 civilian is killed in the attack.
On 19 July, Boko Haram kidnapped 4 children in Baljoel, Mayo Tsanaga.
On 18 July, separatists ambushed Cameroon military forces in Wum and decapitated one officer in the operation.
On 17 July, suspected separatists clashed with military forces in Bamenda. One seperatist killed.
On 16 July, suspected separatists attacked Cameroon police forces in Ndop and killed one. Three other policemen and local peacekeepers were kidnapped.
On 16 July, Boko Haram killed two persons in Goudoumboul, Mayo Tsanaga.

On 15 July, four soldiers reportedly executed two women and two children near Maroua. They accused them of belonging to Boko Haram. An investigation into the incident was started and the soldiers were arrested.
Month of July. Residents protested in Bertoua of Lom-Et-Djerem over poor electricity provision. [size=no report]
Property destruction: On 14 July, suspected separatists destroyed the offices and insallations of two public societies, the Cameroon Development Cooperation and the SONARA in Limbe.

On 12 July, at least five people (four soldiers and a journalist) were injured following an attack by separatist fighters on the convoy of Cameroon's Defence Minister in Small Ekombe in the South West region. 10 secessionists were allegedly killed.

Following the killing of a police superintendent in Kumba on 8 July, seven people were killed in Kumba, Ekondo Titi, during various army operations. Unknown dates coded as two events over 9-13 July with a date precision of 2.
