On 12 July, Cameroonian soldiers killed 15 civilians in Batibo, North-West.
On 11 July, Cameroonian soldiers killed 5 civilians in Bambili, Bamenda, North-West.
On 10 July, clashes between Separatists and security forces in Buea continued for the second day.
Arrests: On 10 July, police arrested hundreds of people in the Ndobo neighbourhood of Douala in retaliation for the rise in separatism.
On 10 July, a man was killed during a Boko Haram attack in Mavare, Kolofata.
On 9 July, Separatists stormed Buea and clashed with security forces: 4 people dead and a policeman kidnapped.
On 9 July, Separatists stormed Bamenda and clashed with security forces. Several dead among Separatists were reported (unknown coded as 10).

Following the killing of a police superintendent in Kumba on 8 July, seven people were killed in Kumba, Ekondo Titi, during various army operations. Unknown dates coded as two events over 9-13 July with a date precision of 2.
On 9 July, a nomadic camp between Garno and Ngouma, Logone et Chari, was attacked by BH men. 2 dead and 46 cattle heads seized.
On 8 July, a police superintendent was killed near his home by separatists in Kumba, Ekondo Titi.

Around 7 July, a gendarme travelling in a bus in his civilian capacity was killed by unknown gunmen at the Sabga hill checkpoint, along the Bamenda-Ndop road. Gunfire exchange followed in the area between the assailants and the army.

Around 7 July, a gendarme travelling in a bus in his civilian capacity was killed by unknown gunmen at the Sabga hill checkpoint, along the Bamenda-Ndop road. Gunfire exchange followed in the area between the assailants and the army.
On 5 July, the residence of the Mayor of Bamenda 3 was attacked by Ambazonian fighters who attempted to kidnap the Mayor. A gendarme was wounded.
On 4 July, a gendarme was killed during an armed attack launched by Ambazonian fighters on Balikumbat, North-West, security post. One was also wounded.
On 3 July, vigilantes repelled the attack of alleged BH men in Abancouri, Balgaram, Logone et Chari.
On 3 July, Cameroonian forces attacked a BH group in Glem, Afade, Logone-et-Chari: 5 BH killed and 1 wounded.
On 2 July, construction workers in Garoua demonstrated as they are not being payed for the construction of CAN 2019 infrastructures.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Cameroon (1982-); Military Forces of France
notes: On 1 July, Ambazonian Separatists and Cameroonian soldiers battled in Muea, Buea. The prison was attacked and several prisoniers freed. Two policemen were reportedly killed. Reportedly, a French soldier killed a civilian during the fighting.

On 1 July, armed men attacked the gendarmerie brigade in Penda Mboko, Fiko, and burned it down. The attack is considered a reponse to the security meeting betzeen the Governor of the South West Region and various stakeholders from Littoral.
On 1 July, a military officer was killed in an ambush by Separatists in Mbengwi, Momo.
On the night between 30 June and 1 July, Ambazonian Separatists and Cameroonian soldiers battled in Buea.
On 30 June, a man was killed by Boko Haram men during a second raid in Zanga.
On 29 June, Cameroonian soldiers attacked armed men who had erected a barricade in Buea following the announcement of the visit of the French special envoy.
On 29 June, the convoy of the French Secretary of State directed to Buea was attacked at Mile 16 (Bolifamba) by Ambazonian forces. Two soldiers were killed and several wounded.
On 29 June, two soldiers were killed and five others injuried in Tugyi, 20 km from Mbengwi, Momo, as Ambazonian men ambushed them.
On 29 June, 2 people were killed by Boko Haram men during a raid in Zamga.
On 27 June, the Babadjou gendarmerie was attacked by alleged Ambazonian separatists attempting to free a prisoner.
On 27 June, Cameroonian soldiers attacked a separatist camp in Belo.
On 27 June, BH men raided Goulfo/Afade, Logone et Chari, killing 3 civilians. One later arrested.
On 27 June, a suspected French soldier allegedly shot and wounded a woman in Ekona, South-West.
On 26 June, a BH man was killed in Talakachi during a confrontation with the army.
On 26 June, 4 BH men were killed in Gogo/Blamederie, Mayo Sava during an army operation.
On 25 June, Ambazonian separatists and Cameroonian soldiers clashed in Fiango, Kumba II.
On 25 June, 2 BH men were killed by Cameroonian soldiers in Fima/Fotokol, Logone et Chari during an ambush.
On 24 June, 2 people died as a soldier threw deliberatly a grenade in Kousseri.
On 24 June, three people were killed by Boko Haram men in Guid-Zeleved, Mayo Tsanaga
On 23 June, a herder was killed during a Boko Haram raid in Sagme, Logone et Chari. 300 cattle heads seized.
On 23 June, 4 BH men were killed in Zourou, Mayo-Sava by the army.
Around 23 June, Cameroonian army reportedly executed a civilian in Fundong, Boyo.
Around 23 June, Cameroonian army reportedly killed two civilians in Bombey, Kumba
Around 23 June, Cameroonian army reportedly opened fire on a taxi in Bamenda, killing the driver and one passenger, while the other passengers were wounded.
On 23 June, a policeman was kidnapped by presumed separatists in Kumba, South-West. It was later leared the officer was executed.
On 21 June, a police patrol was attacked by suspected separatists in Bamenda: one policeman and one assailant dead, several policemen wounded.
On 21 June, a gendarme was killed during an attack of the gendarmerie post by Ambazonian separatists in Mutengene, South West.
On 21 June, Cameroonian soldiers attacked an Ambazonian base in the Bengwi department, Momo. Weapons and military material were seized. 4 hostages were freed and 3 civilians killed.
On 21 June, 4 businessmen were kidnapped by alleged ADF men in Bangem, South West.
On 20 June, a vigiliante was killed during a BH attack in Blabline, Logone et Chari
On 19 June, Cameroonian forces attacked and burned down the villages of Ediki, Mbalangi, Banga Bakundu on the Buea-Kumba axis. People took shelter in the forest.
On 19 June, Cameroonian forces attacked and burned down the villages of Ediki, Mbalangi, Banga Bakundu on the Buea-Kumba axis. People took shelter in the forest.
On 19 June, Cameroonian forces attacked and burned down the villages of Ediki, Mbalangi, Banga Bakundu on the Buea-Kumba axis. People took shelter in the forest.
On 18 June, a battle between the security forces and ADF elements in Ekona was reported. Some militants were "neutralised".
On 16 June, a military patrol was attacked by Ambazonian separatists in Fundong, North-West: one killed and several wounded.
On 16 June, 2 kamikazes exploded their vests in Limani resulting in the death of a child.
On 16 June, two people were killed by BH men in Tchika, Lac Tchad.
On 16 June, a couple supporting the ruling CPDM was killed in Batibo, Momo, by alleged Ambazonian separatists.

Movement of forces: Over June 15-17, ADF elements locked down the the Buea-Kumba axis to try to assert their authority in the area. Sand trucks were forced to unload on the road to prevent passage, while money was extorted from some passenger vehicles. Military forces were deployed around Kumba to clear the highway, leading to clashes on the 18th.
Property destruction: Possibly in June, Cameroonian forces reportedly ransacked the local health unit in Ikiliwindi, Meme County, destroying the facility and manhandling the staff present.
On 15 June, a driver carrying was executed by ADF elements on the way to Ekondo Titi after they learnt he had transported a gendarme the day before and accused him of betrayal.

Possibly in June, Cameroonian forces reportedly ransacked the Government Integrated Heath Unit in Bafia, Muyuka local government of Fako County, shooting heavily with machine guns. Many patients and staff were wounded.
Possibly in June, Cameroonian forces reportedly attacked the Hospital in Lebialem, Sud-Ouest, killing a nurse.
On 13 June, locals demonstrated against South-West and North-West workers working at the construction of the Biya's stadium. Police arrested union leaders.
On 12 June, Boko Haram killed a man in Alladjiri, Kerawa.
On 10 June, a Police commissioner was kidnapped by unknown armed men in Muea, Buea. Unclear if in official capacity during attack.
On 9 June, a Cameroonian soldier was reportedly killed by armed men in Furu-Awa, Menchum department.
On 8 June, Boko Haram men attacked the village of Djalingo, Dogba. 10 civilians, including the village Lawan, and 10 BH men killed.

actor2: Police Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Prison Guards
notes: On 6 June, separatists reportedly attacked the Bavenga prison, Muyuka, freeing the prisoners. Toll unknown.
Property destruction: On 6 June, separatists reportedly burned down the Legal Department and the State Counsel of Muyuka. There were clashes in the town the day before.
On 5 June, clashes were reported in Muyuka between separatists and military forces. Toll unknown.
On 5 June, a police officer was kidnapped in Fundong, North West Region. Unclear if in official capacity during attack.
Early June: images of the kidnapping and execution of a policeman by presumed separatists in Fundong, North-West.
On 3 June, Cameroonian soldiers repelled an attack by Boko Haram men in Zuru, Amchide.
Property destruction: On 2 June, the residence of Minister Mengo Victor Arrey in Mbinjong, Upper Bayang, was burned down by some armed men.
On 1 June, the head of the vigilante militia of Talla Massali village, Ashigashiya, was killed during an ambush pepetrated by Boko Haram.
On 1 June, the village chief of Wakassao, Touboro, was reportedly kidnapped by a Cameroonian soldier, as he refused to pay the traditional tax to the traditional chief.
On 31 May, Cameroonian forces allegedly accidentally killed Prince Mbah Dan Njeck of Bessi Fondom in Momo County, as they opened fire at the Nsamungong market.
On 30 May, BH men attacked Cheripouri, Kolofata: they killed a man before leaving as Cameroonian soldiers arrived.
On 30 May, a Boko Haram incursion was repelled by a vigilante milita in Mada Kolo, Ndiguina, Logone et Chari. One BH killed and another captured.
On 28 May, 2 herders were killed by the explosion of a landmine in Sagme, Logone et Chari.
On 28 May, a man was killed during a BH incursion in Yegoua, Kolofata. Some cattle seized.
On 28 May, a man was wounded during a BH incursion in Afade, Logone et Chari. Some cattle seized.
On 27 May, BH men attacked Ndaga, Logone et Chari: the traditional chief was killed, his brother wounded, cattle seized.

On 25 May corpses of Batibo youths were discovered in bushes in Batibo. Circumstances of death unclear. Batibo saw VAC by Ambazonian separatists and clashes between the separatists and military forces earlier in 2018.
On 25 May, the principal of the Baptist Academy of Muyuka (South-West) was kidnapped by Ambazonian separatists. He was freed on 29 May.
On 25 May, the principal of Bolifamba High School (Buea, South-West) was kidnapped by Ambazonian separatists.
Looting: On 22 May, a brewery truck was attacked at 8 km from Mbengwi. Assailants set fire to the truck.

On 20 May, during a march to commemorate the independence of Cameroon in Yaounde, opposition parties protested the government's handling of the ongoing tensions in the English-speaking regions. As they were unauthorised to carry banners, they marched with hands on their heads and showed pictures of the violence happening there.
On 20 May, clashes between Ambazonian separatists and policemen were reported in Konye and Batibo. Several people dead were reported (10 fatalities spread over two events)
On 20 May, Ambazonian separatists ambushed a group of policemen in Ekona. One policeman dead and two wounded.
On 20 May, clashes between Ambazonian separatists and policemen were reported in Konye and Batibo. Several people dead were reported (10 fatalities spread over two events)
On 20 May, Cameroonian soldiers reportedly raided Menka. 8 dead bodies were found in the woods around the city.

assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-); Vigilante Group (Cameroon)
notes: On 20 May, several Boko Haram men attacked Ashigashiya: 2 vigiliantes and one soldier injured.
Arrests: On 19 May, the village chief of Goudoumboul and six other people were arrested over allegedly providing food to Boko Haram militants.
On 19 May, the Bangem mayor and two of his staff members were kidnapped by some armed men, while distributing some pro-government gadgets for the 20 May celebration.
On 18 May, Ambazonian elements and Cameroonian soldiers clashed in Menka, Santa: 27 Ambazonian fighters and 5 hostages dead.
Between 15 and 17 May, three days of clashes between Cameroonian soldiers and Ambazonian separatists in Kwakwa Kombone, Meme. 27 Cameroonian soldiers allegedly killed.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: On 17 May, Boko Haram men and security forces clashed in Wouro, Mayo Sava, as BH men attempted to seize cattle.
Between 15 and 17 May, three days of clashes between Cameroonian soldiers and Ambazonian separatists in Kwakwa Kombone, Meme. 27 Cameroonian soldiers allegedly killed.
On 16 May, three armed separatists exchanged fire with two Cameroonian soldiers in Buea, wounding one.
Non-violent activity: On 15 May, sounds of gun shots were heard in Buea. It is unclear whether it was a military drilling exercise or clashes between separatists and the Cameroonian army.
On 15 May, clashes between separatists and gendarmes were reported in Ekona, South-West region.
Between 15 and 17 May, three days of clashes between Cameroonian soldiers and Ambazonian separatists in Kwakwa Kombone, Meme. 27 Cameroonian soldiers allegedly killed.
Month of May. Military forces raid Etoko village, near Mamfe, Manyu, searching for Ambazonian separatists and force civilians to flee.
On 14 May, separatists and the Cameroonian army clashed in the Boa Village, Meme. 16 dead and several houses burnt down.
On 14 May, the Fue-Bakundu village, Meme, was attacked by the Cameroonian army, who opened fire on civilians, as some insurgents were deemed to shelter there: 37 civilians dead and 400 wound.
On 12 May, Cameroonian security forces tortured an Ambazonian separatist following his arrest.
Property destruction: On 11 May, alleged separatists attacked Nafut's highschool, North-West, causing important material damage.
On 11 May, a man not respecting the "dead city" day imposed by separatists was kidnapped by unidentified men in Widikum, North-Ouest.
On 10 May, 4 detainees at the Muyuka police station, South-West region, escaped after an attack on the building by unidentified men.
Around 10 May, Cameroonian soldiers reportedly attacked Baba Mbonge, Meme, killing 10 civilians before setting some houses ablaze.

Around 10 May, Cameroonian soldiers reportedly attacked Kuke, Meme: the people had gotten wind of the arrival of the soldiers and all disappeared into the nearby bushes. Military forces set the entire village on fire.

On 8 may, 7 anglophone detainees attempted to walk out of the Yaounde military court during trial to express dissatisfaction at the proceedings and the bad living conditions of anglophone prisoniers. They were blocked by security forces.
Property destruction: On 8 May, the Government High Schoolin Bafut was set on fire by unidentifed men.
On 7 May, a gun battle between separatists and military forces took place in Mbengwi, close to Belo.
On 7 May, a man was killed by Boko Haram men in Krawa, Mayo-Tsanaga.
Non-violent activity: On 6 May, gunshots were heard in Buea.
On 6 May, a gun battle between supposedly separatists and military forces took place in Mbalangi, between Kumba and Muyuka.
Around 6 May, a gun battle between separatists and military forces took place in Muyengue, close to Belo, North West. One soldier was killed.
On 5 May, a man was killed at his field in Krawamafa by Boko Haram men.
In early May, a video posted on social media showed the village of Kuke Mbomo, South-West (25 km north of Mount Cameroon - approx. coordinates used) destroyed by alleged Cameroonian soldiers.
Looting: On 5 May, some armed men burned down 40 houses at 18km from Kolofata, Mayo-Sava.
Property destruction: On 4 May, the office of Divisional Officer of the locality Nkongho, in Belo, North-West, was burnt down by unidentified men.
On 3 May, a man was killed during a Boko Haram incursion in Tcherive, Mayo-Sava. 20 huts burned.

On 2 May, groups of BH fighters attacked Mabanda village, close to the Sambisa forest, executing some villagers accused of failing to inform BH when Cameroon army arrived. The intervention of the Cameroonian army promted BH men to retreat after some clashes. 14 civilians were executed, and 7 BH men killed when the army intervened. Dozens were wounded.

On 2 May, groups of BH fighters attacked Mabanda village, close to the Sambisa forest, executing some villagers accused of failing to inform BH when Cameroon army arrived. The intervention of the Cameroonian army promted BH men to retreat after some clashes. 14 civilians were executed, and 7 BH men killed when the army intervened. Dozens were wounded.
Around 1 May, the village chief of Kalama, Makary was kidnapped by Boko Haram. He was freed on 6 May after a ransom was paid.
On 1 May, a truck was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram men in Madina, Makari. Severe material damages but no physical harm.
Looting: On 30 April, Boko Haram elements attacked Benesoue locality, Fotokol, seizing several cattle heads. They planted landmines to cover their retreat.
On 30 April, Boko Haram elements attacked Amchide, Kolofata: 1 dead.
On 30 April, armed separatists attacked the Ashing school, Belo (North-West), abducting the principal and the chaplain. The chaplain was later released but the principal has not been found.
On 29 April, footage recorded shows the centre of the Munyenge, South West, ablaze. Government forces reportedly destroyed it and killed civilians
On 29 April, Boko Haram men attacked Bia, Kolofata: 1 dead and cattle seized.
On 29 April, Boko Haram men attacked Blabline, Kolofata: 1 dead and cattle sezied.
On 28 April, two Cameroonian gendarmes were killed in Bali-Nyongha, Mezam (North-West) by armed separatists.
On 28 April, a teacher was gunned down after suspected separatist assailants fired gunshots at a school in the town of Muyuka, South-West.
On 25 April, Cameroonian forces and Ambazionian separatits clashed in Kumba (South-West) after the assassination of a teacher. Toll unavailable.
On 25 April, a soldier was killed in Andek (North-West) by a presumed ambazionian armed group.
On 25 April, Mbouda students took the street to protest the missing payment of a 3000 CFA school fee. Police was deployed.
On 25 April, a teacher was killed in Kumba (South-West) by a secessionist armed group. A student was also wounded.
In late April, footage recorded shows 13 soldiers setting fire to a house in Azi, Lebialem.
On 24 April, 2 Boko Haram elements were killed by Cameroonian soldiers in Cherif Moussari, Kolofata.
On 24 April, 2 Cameroonian civilians were kidnapped by armed men in Mbalangi, South-West.
21 April. During the weekend, an armed group attacked a naval base in Manja. 'Several' fatalities were reported (coded as 10).

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Looting: On 21 April, Boko Haram men looted and burned down Matakaya village, Amchide. BIR intervention later allowed to recover the cattle stolen.
20 April. An armed group attacked a police station in Widikum. Two people were injured during the clashes.

Around 20 April, the governor of the North-West region was attacked while going to the inauguration ceremony of an administrative officer in the Momo department. Cameroonian security forces repelled the attack. Toll unknown.
On 20 April, clashes were reported between Cameroonian soldiers and Ambazonian separatists in Lebialem: 4 Cameroonian soldiers and 15 Separatists dead. 3 Cameroonian soldiers wounded.

On 20 April, a Cameroonian military vehicle was hit by a landmine planted by Ambazonian separatists in Eyumedjock nearby Menji, while going to support their fellow-soldiers engaged in a battle nearby. 2 dead and 4 severely wounded.
On 18 April, Zigague vigilantes tracked Boko Haram elements and killed 4, arrested 1. They recovered also 150 cattle heads, sezied by Boko Haram.
On 18 April, Boko Haram men attacked Zalala, Zigague and seized a cattle herd. One wounded.
On 17 April, separatists and military clashed in Ajin, North-West region: the village was burned down and several dead were reported.

Around 17 April, villages near Ajin in Nord-Ouest including Anyajua village (which is located in the Belo district), were set on fire either by Cameroonian soldiers or separatists following their clashes. Toll unknown.
On 16 April, 2 fishermen were killed by Boko Haram in Ngame, Waza.
On 13 April, the Kumba village was attacked by Ambazonian separatists. Army repulsed them.
On 12 April, Cameroonian army dispersed Ambazonian elements blocking the Kumba-Buea road, after some short clashes in Kumba
During the 12 April week, Ambazonian gunmen are suspected to have kidnapped the President of a credit union in Ndian division bringing him to an unknown destination.
11 April. Ambazonian fighters ambushed a military escorted Pamol convoy in Ekondo Titi. Three soldiers were injured and three separatists were killed.
On 11 April, Boko Haram elements attacked Amichde: 2 people wounded.
On 9 April, a Boko Haram kamikaze was arrested by police forces before triggering his explosives.
On 9 April, Boko Haram elements kidnapped 2 truck drivers between Mada and Zigague.
08 April. Ambazonian Separatists abducted a retired judge in Ewelle. The judge was released on 11/04.
On 8 April, Boko Haram men attacked the village of Alagarno (Kolofata) killing 2 people and injuring 2 others.
On 4 July, Magou's Pygmies, 45 km from Lomie, Est, demonstrated against the expolitation of the forest and the lack of public services in their village.
On 7 April, Cameroonian forces ambushed BH men at Double bridge (Mora): 1 dead among BH men. Bikes and food were seized.
Property destruction: On 5 April, BH elements set fire to twenty houses in Zamga, Mayo Tsanaga.
Property destruction: Around 4 April, suspected separatists destroyed a number of houses and property in the Mbonge subdivision, including in Bakumba, Masaka, Ngwandi villages.
On 4 April, suspected ADF separatists and government troops clashed in Belo, Northwest region. At least one separatist dead.
On 3 April, the Cameroonian army allegedly attacked the Mungo Vendeur village, Nguti. One civilian died as a result of fire, while 6 were shot down.
On 2 April, the Cameroonian army post in Amtalia, Waza, was attacked by BH men and kamikazes. 2 kamikazes dead and 1 soldier wounded.

On 2 April, suspected ADF separatists and government troops clashed in the bush of Nguti. The government claims that soldiers freed 12 tourists "kidnapped" by separatists, whereas the tour operator denied this circumstance.
On 2 April, a man was killed by BH men following an attack in Mogbere, Limani.
On 2 April, BH elements attacked a military post in Sagme, Fotokol. 5 soldiers and 15 BH men dead; 3 soldiers wounded. The attacked soldiers were those who participated in the Gomaram operation.
Looting: On 1 April, BH men seized 254 cattle heads and 193 sheeps in Matakaya, Amchide.
On 1 April, Cameroonian soldiers organised a military operation against BH in the Gomaram Island, Chad Lake. 10 BH men dead.
31 March. Ambazonian Separatists abducted three chiefs from Widikum. The chiefs were accused of supporting government efforts against the separatists. The chiefs were released on 04/04.
On 30 March, clashes between military and separatists were reported in Konye, Kumba. Houses are reported to have been reduced to ashes. Unconfirmed sources talk of military casualties.
30 March. Military forces razed homes in Big Ngwandi.
On 30 March, a group of separatists attacked a military post in Moundogo, Ekondo Titi. 15 separatists died, 7 soliders were wounded (2 severely)
On 30 March, a Boko Haram kamikaze was killed by the Cameroonian army in Doulo.
30 March. A soldier was killed during clashes with Ambazonian Separatists in Dadi.
27 March. Ambazonian fighters attacked a military base in Ikassa. Three separatists were killed.
26 March. Separatists clashed with security forces outside of the of the DO officer's home in Kumba. One separatist was killed.

Arrests: On 26 March, Cameroonian forces arrested six Boko Haram fighters and 25 female accomplices while transporting ammunition, food, material to fabricate explosive devices, torches, drugs and medications to other Boko haram fighters in Nigeria.
On 26 March, Ambazonian separatists attacked the Widikum high school dormitory, killing a student.
On 26 March, the FMM post was attacked by Boko Haram in Fotokol. 2 soldiers dead, one missing and 3 wounded.
On 25 March, secessionist fighters attacked a police post and a poll station in Bangem on the Senate election-day. They were repulsed in the two cases by police. Two killed.
25 March. Ambazonian Separatists attacked a Gendarmerie base in Konye. One separatist was killed.
On 25 March, two travelers were killed by Boko Haram men around Gassama, Logone and Chari.
On 25 March, a woman was killed by Boko Haram men in Krawa-Mafa in Mayo Moskoto.
Arrests: On 23 March, men of the Cameroonian elite Rapid Reaction Battalion have arrested 31 suspected members of Boko Haram in Kolofata.
Looting: On 23 March, BH men attacked the Samana village, Bargaram. Herders had to flee.
On 23 March, security forces raided Bole village, Meme, burning houses and killing at least one civilian.
On 22 March, a government official was killed and a district administrator wounded in an ambush blamed on anglophone separatists on the Azi-Alou axis.
On 20 March, security forces attempted to free the four hostages kidnapped on 15 March by supposed Ambazonian Separatists. "Four terrorists" and one civilian died during the operation.
On 20 March, a man was killed and twenty cattle heads were seized by BH men in Mayo Holta, Mayo Tsanaga.
18 March. The home of Minister of Economy and Planning Paul Tasong in Mmockbie (no coordinates available) was burned by an unidentified group.
On 17 March 4 people were wounded by ADF while going to political meeting in support of president Biya in Menji.
17 March. A seminar in Lewoh (no coordinates available) was burned down.

17 March. Ambazonian Separatists abducted Professor Tambo, a member of the board of education, while on his way from Alou to Menji. The perpetrators also shot the former mayor. The professor was later released.
18 March. During the weekend, a taxi driver was abducted by suspected Ambazonian Separatists while driving by Diffa (no coordinates available), near Kake.
On 17 March 40 people were abducted by ADF men while going to a political meeting in support of president Biya in Fontem.
17 March. Classrooms were set on fire in Bomaka (aka Womaka).

On 15 March, two Tunisians and two Cameroonians working on a public construction site were kidnapped by Ambazonian Separatists. One of the Tunisians was killed by the group. The rest of the hostages were rescued by military forces on 20/03.
1-30 March. A curfew was imposed for the month of March throughout the Sud Ouest, with the exception of Fako.
15 March (on or around). Ambazonian Separatists burned three vehicles that attempted to travel along the Kumba-Ekombe road near Kake.
On 15 March, BH kidnapped the chief of the Charack village (between Makari and Hile Alifa).
In March, Ambazonian separatists tortured and killed a man in Bakundu Foe, Mbonge, accusing him to be a government informant.
On 14 March one soldier was killed by armed separatists in Kumba.
On 13 March, the commander of the Nguti gendarmerie and two gendarmes were killed when its brigade went under attack by suspected separatists.
On 11 March, two student gendarmes were killed in an assault on the Nsongwa gendarmerie , North West, by separatists. Four others were wounded.
On 10 March soldiers clashed with BH forces in Sagme as they went to recover a herd. 4 BH men were killed in the clashes.
A soldier was killed in an attempted kidnapping of students by separatist militants from a school in Batibo.
08 March. The Governor of the Nord Ouest issued a ban on motorcycles in Batibo, Widikum and Balikumbat. The ban is in response to the use of motor bikes by separatists.
08 March. A soldier shot and killed a motorbike rider who drove through a military post while the national anthem was being performed.
Looting: Boko Haram incursion at the Chepouri village in Kolofata. Several houses were looted.
On 7 March, one soldier was killed and three civilians wounded by suspected armed separatists in Batibo.
07 March. Ambazonian Separatists attacked a naval base in Mana. One soldier and a dozen separatists were killed (coded as 13 total fatalities).
03 March. Gendarme soldiers fire rounds in Afab village near Mamfe, Manyu, killing a child.
Demonstrating teachers were dispersed by policemen.
28 February. The home of SDF candidate John Fru Ndi was burned down. Separatist are believed to be behind the attack after Ndi ignored their ban on the SDF congress in Bamenda.
26 February (on or before). Soldiers attacked Bombele, suspecting separatists of hiding in the village. They burned homes in the village and destroyed property.

Movement of forces: Cameroon deployed additional troops to its English speaking regions after another wave of attacks on public buildings and the kidnapping of military and government officials by suspected armed separatists. It also imposed a month-long curfew on nighttime driving in the South-West due to the insecurity.
26 February (on or before). Soldiers attacked Boa, suspecting separatists of hiding in the village. They set fire to the village. An elderly woman who could not flee was killed in the fire.
26 February (on or before). Military forces attacked Ngumu (Mbonge, Meme), looking for Ambazonian Separatist. They burned homes and destroyed property.
24 February. Separatists attacked a gas station and Gendarmerie base in Njinikom. A shopkeeper was killed in the cross fire and two fighters were also killed during the clash.
24 February. Ambazonian Separatists attacked military and Gendarmerie bases in Munyenge. One soldier was killed during the attack.
5 civilians killed between Bourvare and Goumouldi. No further information.

actor1: SCACUF: Southern Cameroons Ambazonia Consortium United Front
notes: A state officer was kidnapped by presumed separatists.
3 people killed in Kordo.
3 civilians were killed in Baljoel by Boko Haram.
21 February. The body of a woman whose breasts had been cut off was discovered in Buea.
Property destruction: 40 houses were burned down.
Armed men killed an education clerk and kidnapped the traditional chief and son staff in Etam.
One dead and 150 houses burned in Vourkaza.
20 February (on or before). Military forces clashed with Ambazonian Separatists in Ekok.

assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 20 February. Ambazonian Separatists attacked the Gendarmerie base in Mundemba, BIR forces arrived to provide additional military support. 2-4 attackers were killed.
20 February. A doctor was shot and injured by security forces in Bamenda after her cab driver failed to follow their instructions.
20 February. Suspected separatists abducted a traditional leader in Ikiliwindi. The leader was believed to be collaborating with the military. There are also reports of a demand for a ransom.
Boko Haram militants killed five civilians and wounded five others in northern Cameroon after crossing the border from Nigeria.
Students from Bafoussam Classical High School, pushed by their professors, marched to draw attention to their poor results.
18 February. Ambazonian Separatists attacked a Gendarmerie patrol in Babensi. One soldier was killed.
26 January- 26 February (sometime between). Military forces attacked Kwa Kwa (no coordinates available) and burned the village. An elderly woman was killed in the fires.
15 February. A soldier was stabbed to death by unidentified assailants in Kumba.

In February, two civilians from the mostly francophone Bamileke ethnic group in Meme were allegedly beaten with guns and machetes by Ambazonian separatists accusing them of being pro-government. One of them was left bleeding.
12 February (on or before). A chief in Mundemba was killed by separatists, he was accused of supporting military forces.
12 February. Ambazonian Separatists attacked the Gendarmerie base in Toko and set fire to the mayor's home. 'Several' separatists were killed (coded as 10).

On 11 February, during Youth Day celebrations, riots erupted in Buea when prisoners who were brought out to swell the marching ranks disappeared and Francophone Cameroonians mounted pressure on the authorities to call for payments.

On 11 February, Youth Day celebrations were disrupted in most areas in West Cameroon to protest the crisis in the Anglophone region. In places like Bali, Mamfe, Mundemba, Ndop and Muyuka, angry youths sympathetic to the detained leaders of Cameroon Anglophone Civil Society Consortium disrupted government activities planned for the day. In Mutengene, people protested with placards. In Bamenda, Buea, Kumbo, Tiko, Limbe, Kumba and Ekona, people responded to a massive civil disobedience call made by the Consortium.

1 Boko Haram militant killed by the army, the other died when his charge explosed.
Three soldiers were killed in the southwestern village of Kembong, during some "scattered attacks".
11 February. Ambazonian Separatists and military forces clashed in Ekok throughout the night.
The deputy head of the anglophone Batibo region, Namata Diteng, had been kidnapped after his burnt-out car was found in an isolated area.
Security Measures: Cameroon imposed a week-long night curfew from Saturday in its restive English-speaking west citing fears of an "imminent" attack by separatists.
10 February. Military forces stormed a funeral in Meli during a search for separatists. They shot and killed one civilian at the funeral.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 6 BIR soldiers and 2 civilian guides were killed during a clash with heavily armed poachers.
A soldier was killed in Bamenda.
An IED explosion wounded 7 soldiers
Property destruction: unknown men set fire to Tchomba high school.
6 men killed by Boko Haram in Hitawa. 100 houses, 1 church and 4 shops burned.

Movement of forces: Witnesses said heavy artillery fire is being reported in Bamenda (the capital of the North West region) amidst heavy military activity in the English-speaking regions of Cameroon on the night of February 3. No further details of an actual clash.
Gunshots were heard during the night between Saturday and Sunday, and clashes were reported between military forces and separatists.

Fifty armoured vehicles and assault weapons were deployed by the government in the English-speaking regions. Reports of beating, extortion and houses being burned in two days by soldiers around Belo. Army spokesman Colonel Didier Badjeck said claims that houses were burned and people shot in Bole last week were 'totally false'. Fatalities could not be confirmed.
A sniper opened fire on a Amour Mezam bus: a civilian was wounded.

Cameroon security forces have killed four civilians in the country's restive English-speaking west. One person was shot dead late Saturday in Bamenda, the main regional town where he was enjoying a night out.
On 3 February, 4 dead bodies of people arrested in Belo were found at the Bamenda hospital.

Fifty armoured vehicles and assault weapons were deployed by the government in the English-speaking regions. Reports of beating, extortion and houses being burned in two days by soldiers around Belo. Army spokesman Colonel Didier Badjeck said claims that houses were burned and people shot in Bole last week were 'totally false'. Fatalities could not be confirmed.

In the Belo region a 26-year-old man was killed, shot dead while hiding in a loft space while security forces were trashing private homes. Witnesses spoke of destroyed homes, broken windows and televisions, radios and computers thrown into a pile then set ablaze.

Two people were killed by armed police on the road linking Bamenda to neighbouring Bafut. The police opened fire because the civilians "did not comply" when they were pulled up, a security source said.
2 people killed in Yawa of Kolofata subdivision.
On 1 February, two gendarmes were killed by separatists at the Mbingo (North-West) checkpoint.
On 1 February, men dressed in civilian clothes but believed to be security forces shot a man at his shop in Bamenda and took him away.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 5 civilians were killed and 6 others wounded by a 42nd BIM soldier between 2am and 5am in Mora.
In Bamenda, suspects riding a motorcycle shot dead an officer.
A soldier assigned to the Limani post was killed in an ambush by Boko Haram. He was going to Bonderi.
Armed separatists attacked a checkpoint in the village of Bingo, in the country's Northwest Region. Two wounded gendarmes were taken to hospital, where they died of their injuries.
A civilian died after being shot by soldiers during an operation in the nearby city of Santa.
On 30 January, an Ambazonia separatist attacked the Ntungfe primary school in Belo, and shot and wounded a teacher.
The sub-prefect and his staff were kidnapped. They were subsequently freed by the security forces.
On 29 January, a student was killed by security forces in Shishong, Kumbo.
A gendarme was shot down in Kumbo during an attack by secessionists. The victim is a chief warrant officer deployed in this region as part of security operations in English-speaking areas.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: A home-made bomb exploded on the passage of a Cameroonian army vehicle carrying elements of the Rapid Intervention Battalion (BIR) in Ekok, not far from the Nigerian border. Two soldiers were injured.
Property destruction: Bamenda's makert was set on fire. Secesionists' groups are believed to be behind it.
Several petrol stations were attacked in neighborhoods incl. Ntarikong, Travelers, Hospital Round About, Nkwen, Foncha Street in Bamenda. Exchanges of fire were reported.
A man was killed while at his field by Boko Haram.
On 19 January, a military barrack in Mbengwi, Momo, was attacked by unknown gunmen. No toll available.
A man was kidnapped in Minimari, Fotokol.

On 18 January, security forces raided Kwakwa village, Bole, burning hundreds of houses and killing at least seven civilians. The raid came our days after separatists in Kombone detained two military men and beheaded one of them.
1 villager was kidnapped this morning in Layouna, Waza and was found dead.
2 dead (plus the attacker) in a suicide bombing by Boko Haram at Matakaye Elie Amchide.
4 people were killed Roum (Tourou canton in Mayo-Tsanaga) in a Boko Haram attack. Dozens of houses and a church burned.

On 15 January, in reprisal for the killing of a military man in Kombone, Cameroonian soldiers raided Kwakwa village, Bole, robbing and setting houses on fire. They raided the town again three days later, on 18 January, killing at least seven civilians.
On 14 January, separatists in Kombone detained two military men and beheaded one of them.
A policeman was killed on Sunday by presumed separatists in a restive English-speaking region of Cameroon. Other officers may have also been killed, an official added.
02 people killed in Dzaba and Dzamazaf (Mayo-Moskota) in incursions of Boko Haram
3 people kidnapped in Toukoumaya, Waza.
Explosion of two suicide bombers in Ouro-Kessoum district in Amchide: 02 dead (suicide bombers) and 02 wounded
1 dead and one wounded in a Boko Haram attack in Assighassia, 30 houses burnt, 50 oxes and sheeps taken.
03 people killed in Gangawa by Boko Haram
A vigilance committee member killed at Dzamazaf in Mayo Moskota by Boko Haram. Church ransacked and 11 oxen taken away.

A young assailant was killed by soldiers in Garoua. Repeated assaults between young militants and men in uniform have been recorded in Yelwa district in Garoua. On Monday, two elements of the Rapid Intervention Battalion (BIR), an elite unit of the Cameroonian army, had been seriously attacked, and it was in response to this affront that the BIR soldiers retaliated on the "young people".
On 7 January, armed separatists attacked and killed at least one member of the security forces in Kwakwa's neigboring village of Kombone, Meme.
On 7 January, in retaliation for the earlier killing of a member of security forces, Cameroonian soldiers raided Kombone in Meme and reportedly killed two civilians.
01 villager died at Goldavi in a Boko Haram attack.
A farmer, who was kidnapped 15 days ago, was found beheaded on his field in Tolkomari.

A traditional leader, Abang Ashu, was hanged by the people, following suspicions that he was providing information to the military about the positions and activities of English-speaking secessionists.
2 dead and 28 injured in suicide bombing this morning in Bia. 3 fatalities include the bomber.
Two explosions (kamikazes) in the locality of Kordo: three killed in suspected Boko Haram attack.
1 dead in an incursion in the village Guilkidaye.
Students blocked access to university campus protesting against institutions that alledegly embezzled students' primes.

notes: Arrests: 38 mercenaries (from Equatorial Guinea, Chad, Sudan, and CAR) were arrested in Cameroon, on a bus near the EG border. They are suspected of plotting a coup against Obiang.
On 27 December, Boko Haram elements kidnapped a 10-years-old child in Bia, Mayo Sava.
On 25 December, 3 gendarmed outshot and a Divisional Officer residence was razed during clashes with separatists in the South-West region.
3 villagers killed by Boko Haram
In retaliation to the assassination of 4 gendarmes, Cameroonian forces have razed the training camps of "Ambazonians", set up in the Nigerian forests bordering Cameroon.
Secessionists allegedly killed 4 gendarmes in Kembong.
Property destruction: In December, the Kwakwa village in Meme was completely destroyed by Cameroonian soldiers.
In December, several alleged killings by security forces in Dadi, Kajifu and Bodam. 10 unknown fatalities spread over the three locations.
In December, several alleged killings by security forces in Dadi, Kajifu and Bodam. 10 unknown fatalities spread over the three locations.
New clashes erupted between military and assailants presented as separatists under SCACUF, allegedly resulting in several deaths.
A farmer was kidnapped by suspected Boko Haram members as he went to his field in Tolkomari village in Mayo-Sava, Far North.

On 13 December, 23 people were allegedly arrested, detained illegaly and tortured by Cameroonian soldiers in Dadi. Throughout December, several people were allegedly killed by security forces in Dadi, Kajifu and Bodam. 10 unknown fatalities spread over the three locations.
2 dead including the kamikaze in a suicide bomb attack in Matakaya near Amchide.
Arrests: On 12 December, over 40 men, women and youngsters were arreted by Cameroonian forces in Buea, and a ransom of 20000 fcfa per person was asked.
On 12 December, Boko Haram elements and local militia clashed in Kouyape, Mayo Sava. One wounded.
On 12 December, a woman kamikaze exploded herself in Amchide, Mayo Sava. 2 dead and one wounded.
2 civilians and a kamikaze killed in a sucide attack in Kerawa, Far North.
On 11 December, four gendarmes were shot in Kumba during a crossfire battle with separatists.
A truck driver and a shepherd kidnapped by Boko Haram in the Goulma area, on the road between Tilde and Dabanga. They were later released by the army. A third passenger of the truck was found dead.
Boko Haram incursion in Kouyape. 2 wounded vigilance committee members and five shops looted.

actor1: SCACUF: Southern Cameroons Ambazonia Consortium United Front
notes: Some 200 SCACUF youth exchanged gunfire with the national defense and security forces in some localities in Manyu Department, including when they attacked a police post in Mamfe, leaving five wounded soldiers, a military police killed and at least five attackers shot dead by the Cameroonian army.
Kombone, located on Kumba-Mamfe Road in Meme Department, Southwest Region, was the scene of clashes between gunmen and police. One policeman dead and several wounded.
Three secessionist fighters were killed during clashes with the Cameroonian army at the Sanghang border post in Manyu department.
On 5 December, two gendarmes were allegdly killed during clashes with separatists in Kebong, Manyu.
Arrests: On 12 May, 184 were arrested in Mora.

assoc_actor_1: SCACUF: Southern Cameroons Ambazonia Consortium United Front
notes: The Big Nyang village's chief, Abang Ashu (Akwaya District, Southwest Region) was severely beaten and tied to a tree in early December. He was accused to be close to the Cameroonian defense forces and of betraying elements of the Ambazonian defense forces to republican forces.
Arrests: On 12 March, 1155 people were arrested in Kolofata.

A group of armed individuals suspected of being affiliated with the Islamist sect Boko Haram abducted ten people and killed two others after raiding a village in the Tchebe-Tchebe locality, Far North region.
A security force' vehicle on its way to counter an alleged Islamist attack in a village in Tchebe-Tchebe struck an antipersonnel mine, leaving two soldiers killed. It is unclear who laid the mine.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: A 42nd BIM vehicle hit an IED at Hodogo. 4 injured.
Five Cameroonian policemen and a soldier were killed by suspected separatists around Mamfe.
Two villagers killed and a girl kidnapped in Tchebetchebe.
Four Cameroonian soldiers were killed by suspected separatists around Mamfe. One soldier who was severely wounded escaped.
Looting: houses burned, about 300 livestock heads and 3 motorcycles taken from Tallassari.
Property destruction: 5 houses burned and food stolen.
One villager was killed in Sanda-Wadjiri. No further details.
On 27 November, Buea university students were brutally beaten and abused by security forces who raided the campus and the residence halls after the students joined their teachers' strike.
A truck was attacked on the national No.1 between Dabanga and Gouess. Three missing, one injured.
On 27 November, Boko Haram elements attacked a truck in Gassama, Logone et Chari, wounding the driver. The other travellers went missing.
Protesters in Bangangte expressed their indignation at the closure of the radio by the Minister of Communication.
On 23 November, 3 Boko Haram supporters were killed by Boko Haram elements in Dougdje, Kolofata.
5 dead and a dozen wounded in this morning's suicide bombing in Kolofata.

A policeman was wounded in the night from Saturday to Sunday at the main food market in Bamenda, by two motorcycle individuals who opened fire on a patrol. A 23-year-old civilian was accidentally shot by policemen and died in hospital on Monday. The same night, at least three civilians were injured by the police, two of them shot, according to concordant sources.
Property destruction: School destroyed in Hodogo on the night of November 16
Arrests: Abba Goroma alias Abba Adam alias Alhadji Hassan, former commander of Banki and Kumshe sectors, was arrested on November 16, in Kodek with four of his bodyguards and transferred to Yaounde.

An altercation occurred between villagers and a Chinese worker, who took a homemade gun and shot a villager dead. The local population reacted with pebbles, pickaxes, and clubs to fight the Chinese man who was also killed. The anger of local populations did not stop at the death of the Chinese, they also administered a caning to all Chinese nationals of the yard.

Four homemade bombs exploded in the night of 12-13 November in Bamenda, the regional capital of northwestern Cameroon, without casualties. One of the bombs exploded shortly after 9:00 pm near the mobile intervention group (GMI), a police unit often targeted in recent weeks. The other three explosions occurred at regular intervals between 3am and 4am on a commercial avenue. These different explosions did not make a victim.
Crowd burned a Presidential Guard's vehicle after the Guard shot accidentally a youngster following a dispute about a car accident.

Four homemade bombs exploded in the night of 12-13 November in Bamenda, the regional capital of northwestern Cameroon, without casualties. One of the bombs exploded shortly after 9:00 pm near the mobile intervention group (GMI), a police unit often targeted in recent weeks. The other three explosions occurred at regular intervals between 3am and 4am on a commercial avenue. These different explosions did not make a victim.

Property destruction: "A group of young men" set on fire the girls' dormitory at St. Pius College, located in the South West. Beds, books, notebooks and the personal effects of the 32 students were totally charred.
Property destruction: The public school of Vouzi burned.
Property destruction: On 12 November, Boko Haram elements set fire to a school in Goshi, Tourou.
On 11 November, Boko Haram elements raided the residence of a man in Waramide, Sandawadjiri: his two wives were kidnapped.
Sali Lafia kidnapped in Sandawadjiri, was found killed this morning in Bornori. 2 OTHER villagers (Zara Abba and Wanie Haman) kidnapped at Warawide on the same day.
On 10 November, Cameroonian elements ambushed Boko Haram fighters in Djebrili, Mayo Tsanaga: 3 BH men killed, 2 motos and 3 bikes recovered.

On the night of 9 to 10 November, a soldier serving with the 22nd Motorized Infantry Battalion was killed. The incident took place in Akwem, 30 km from Mamfe in the southwestern administrative region.
Incursion in Talakachi. A wounded villager, 3 motorcycles, 4 bicycles and cattle washed away.

Two policemen were killed by assailants in three separate attacks to checkpoints in Bamenda's peripheral neighbourhoods. 2 assailants were also killed. One civilian died in the national guards' riposte.
Two policemen were killed by assailants in two different attacks in Bamenda's peripheral neighbourhoods. 2 assailants and one civilian dead in national guards' riposte.

A Cameroon policeman has been killed while pursuing men who attacked a school in one of the country's English-speaking regions, where tensions have fuelled a separatist movement, authorities told AFP on Tuesday. "Suspected separatists gunned down a gendarme yesterday (Monday) in Jakiri".

On November 06, 2017, the 35th anniversary of the ascension to the supreme office of President Paul Biya, activists, activists and sympathizers of the Democratic Rally of the Cameroonian People, dressed in the colors of the party of the burning flames, invested the multifunctional center and promotion of the young people of Baham, theater of the demonstration, to the effect of celebrate the man of renewal.
On 6 November, a Boko Haram incursion in Kerawa, Mayo Tsanaga: 2 civilians dead.
A kamikaze killed and another arrested in Igawa by the army
2 people killed in Kerawa-Mafa
3 people killed at Mahola
3 fighters killed in fighting by the FMM in Mayo-Sava
On 3 November, Boko Haram elements and Cameroonian soldiers clashed in Blakafe, Mora: one dead, 2 wounded.
Arrests: On 11 March, 337 people were arrested in Gakara, Mayo Sava.
On 3 November, military operation by the Cameroonian army and Vigilantes against Boko Haram in Double, Mayo Sava: 2 dead and 1 wounded.
Targeted killing of a trader last night in Bogo
Defusal: On 02 November, vigilantes discovered a landmine on the Idoua-Gossi axis, Mayo Tsanaga.
6 dead in a suicide bombing yesterday night in Zamga (including the perpetrator)
Property destruction: On 1 November, the Presbyterian Secondary School in Bafut was set on fire by unidentifed men.
2 people killed yesterday night at Mada II.
Defusal: On 31 October, vigilantes discovered a landmine in Tourou, Mayo Sava.
On 31 October, a woman kamikaze exploded herself in Zamga, Mozogo: 6 children dead, 6 wounded.
At least 11 villagers slaughtered last night in Gouderi

assoc_actor_2: CACSC: Cameroon Anglophone Civil Society Consortium
notes: Property destruction: Two houses, belonging to the President of the now outlawed Cameroon Anglophone Civil Society Consortium, CACSC, Barrister Felix Agbor Nkongho, aka Agbor Balla, have been attacked by yet to be identified arsonists.
On 29 October, Boko Haram elements attacked Zigague, Waza: 2 civilians dead and 2 wounded.
A march against polio took place in Yaounde.
Explosion of 3 kamikazes that night in Mozogo. No other victims registered
On 24 October, Boko Haram elements raided Bla-Indali, Mayo Sava and killed a man. Some cattle was seized.
On 24 October, Boko Haram elements killed a farmer in Goledje, Mayo Tsanaga.
On 24 October, Cameroonian elements ambushed BH men in Gouzda Vreket, Mayo-Moskota: 2 BH men killed and some goods recovered.
Opposition demonstration in support to anglophone regions was dispersed by police forces.
Defusal: Police forces detonated an IED found in Bamenda; no injuries reported.
A vigilante died after walking on a land-mine in Amtchali. 2 wounded.
Detonation: 2 kamikazes were killed in Limani in the explosion of their charges. Unclear if detonated prematurely.
On 17 October, an attempt by BH elements to raid a military post in Bounderi failed.
Clashes over the payment of vehicles duties between mototaxi and policemen were reported.
Clashes between bus company's former workers (on strike) and current workers. One wounded.
On 10 October, 2 kamikazes were discovered by Vigilante militia in Limani, Mayo Sava: one of them blew himself up, killing both.
Defusal: On 10 October, a landmine was discovered by Cameroonian soldiers on the Cheripouri-Gederou axis.
2 civilians killed in Ldaoutsaf in an attack by Boko Haram
On 9 October, Boko Haram elements raided Ldoutfa, Mayo Tsanaga, shooting on farmers: 2 dead and one wounded. 7 motos seized.
On 9 October, armed men raided Tikre, Mora, and kidnapped one person.

Arrests: between 06/10 and 08/10, hundreds of arbitrary arrests were perpetrated by police forces in Bamenda and Buea, in the aftermath of October, 1st demonstrations. 500 people were arrested and transferred to Bafoussam prison.

Arrests: between 06/10 and 08/10, hundreds of arbitrary arrests were perpetrated by police forces in Bamenda and Buea, in the aftermath of October, 1st demonstrations. 500 people were arrested and transferred to Bafoussam prison.
Two hand-made explosives were thrown inside local priest's bedroom. No injuries reported.
Muslim demonstrators went to the street to show their support to Cameroonian authorities against secession.
On 6 October, Boko Haram men attacked Medina, Logone et Chari, but they were repelled by Cameroonian soldiers.
On 5 October, Boko Haram elements and Cameroonian soldiers clashed in Limani.
On 3 October, Boko Haram elements raided Fotokol, Logone et Chari: one wounded.
Double suicide bombing in Mozogo. 3 dead (2 kamikazes and 1 civilian) .

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Detonation: A home-made device exploded overnight near a police station in Cameroon's restless English-speaking region, where separatist leaders have launched a campaign for independence. The bomb detonated near a police unit called the Mobile Intervention Group in Bamenda. Another device nearby was safely defused by police. There was no claim of responsibility by late afternoon.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: A total of 38 identified demonstrators were killed as a result of live bullets by the defence and security forces in North-West and South-West regions of Cameroon in independence protests. 4 fatalities recorded on 28 September, remaining 34 fatalities divided between events on 1 October in Mamfe, Balikumbat, Limbe, Oku, Akwaya, Ikiliwindi, Kumba, Tombel, Eyumojock, Fontem, Muyuka, Bafut, Ekona Mbenge, Ashong, Ndop, Ndu, Bamenda, Kumbo and Beau. REDHAC reported 100 fatalities.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: In Kumbo, soldiers shot and wounded two demonstrators around midday who had raised the blue and white flag of the Ambazonia separatist movement in the town. Later in the day, a man was killed later attempting to do the same at the local chief's palace.
The gendarmerie station of Fongo-Tonga was assaulted by secessionists militants.

Arrests: Police maintained a tight grip in English-speaking Cameroon on Monday a day after the anglophone minority declared symbolic independence. In Buea, police carried out overnight arrests in one of the city's districts, and left with individuals who were in handcuffs.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: A total of 38 identified demonstrators were killed as a result of live bullets by the defence and security forces in North-West and South-West regions of Cameroon in independence protests. 4 fatalities recorded on 28 September, remaining 34 fatalities divided between events on 1 October in Mamfe, Balikumbat, Limbe, Oku, Akwaya, Ikiliwindi, Kumba, Tombel, Eyumojock, Fontem, Muyuka, Bafut, Ekona Mbenge, Ashong, Ndop, Ndu, Bamenda, Kumbo and Beau. REDHAC reported 100 fatalities.

Catholic bishops have denounced the "barbarism" and "irresponsible use" of force against demonstrators in Cameroon's English-speaking regions last weekend. "In Bamesing, in the archdiocese of Bamenda, some young men were caught and shot on the legs," they added, adding that many people were arrested and "taken away to where we do not know."

5 prisoners were killed by police as they attempted to escape from Kumbo's prison, seizing the occasion prompted by Sunday's demonstrations. Two were wounded by bullets and are at the hospital.

On 29 September, Boko Haram and militia clash in Ashigashiya, Mayo Sava: 14 houses burned down, a bike seized.
2 soldiers killed this morning in the explosion of a mine planted by suspected BH militants between Bonderi and Kangarwa

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 4 demonstrators killed in Ekona on September 28.
On 27 September, Boko Haram elements raided Doulo, Mayo Sava: one civilian wounded by gunfire.
On 27 September, Cameroonian forces intervened and evicted Boko Haram men from Nigue, Logone et Chari.
On 26 September, Boko Haram men attacked Godele, Mayo Tsanaga: 2 people kidnapped. A body was found on 16 October.
2 people seriously wounded after BokoHaram incursion in Limani
On 24 September, armed men from Nigeria attacked Limani, Mayo Sava: 2 civilians wounded.
The body of a soldier, possibly murdered by Boko Haram, was found this morning on the road Zamga-Djibril.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Armed men from Central African Republic attacked a group of herders looting animals and kidnapping 7. Later on, Cameroonian military forces attacked them killing 3 armed men and a hostage.
Armed men from Central African Republic attacked a group of herders looting animals and kidnapping 7. Later on, Cameroonian military forces attacked them killing 3 armed men and a hostage.
On 23 September, armed men raided Igawa, Mayo Sava.3 women kidnapped, and other goods seized.

During anti-government demonstrations, people shot at the security forces in Mamfe, wounding a police officer. Two civilian deaths were also recorded in the town. Another demonstrator was gunned down when they stormed the residence of the mayor of Buea, Ekema Patrick Esunge. Other deaths were reported in Limbe, Santa, Kumbo, Bamenda, Ekona, Bamenda and Ndop.

During anti-government protests, Bernard Okalia Bilai, governor of the south west region told the state daily Cameroon Tribune that protesters shot at the security forces in Mamfe, wounding a police officer. Two civilian deaths were also recorded in the town. Another protester was gunned down when they stormed the residence of the mayor of Buea, Ekema Patrick Esunge. Other deaths were reported in Limbe, Santa, Kumbo, Bamenda, Ekona, Bamenda and Ndop.

During anti-government protests, protesters shot at the security forces in Mamfe, wounding a police officer. Two civilian deaths were also recorded in the town. Another protester was gunned down when they stormed the residence of the mayor of Buea, Ekema Patrick Esunge. Other deaths were reported in Limbe, Santa, Kumbo, Bamenda, Ekona, Bamenda and Ndop.
Explosion of a suicide bomber in Kolofata. No civilian casualties.

Several thousand demonstrators took to the streets in English-speaking parts of Cameroon in protest at perceived discrimination in favour of the country's francophone majority. Deaths were reported in Limbe, Santa, Kumbo, Bamenda, Ekona, Bamenda and Ndop.

Other deaths were reported in Limbe, Santa, Kumbo, Bamenda, Ekona, Bamenda and Ndop.

Two civilian deaths were also recorded in the town. Another protester was gunned down when they stormed the residence of the mayor of Buea, Ekema Patrick Esunge. Other deaths were reported in Limbe, Santa, Kumbo, Bamenda, Ekona, Bamenda and Ndop.

Several thousand demonstrators took to the streets in English-speaking parts of Cameroon in protest at perceived discrimination in favour of the country's francophone majority. Several state officers were wounded and state buildings were plundered in several areas of Southwestern region. A protester was gunned down when they stormed the residence of the mayor of Buea, Ekema Patrick Esunge. Other deaths were reported in Limbe, Santa, Kumbo, Bamenda, Ekona, Bamenda and Ndop.
Two civilian deaths were recorded in Mamfe on 22 September.
A hand-made bomb exploded with no casualties. Authorities link the event to the political turmoil taking place in anglophone Cameroon.
On 22 September, a farmer was hit by a landmine while going to his field in Zelevet, Mayo Tsanaga. One wounded.
On 22 September, armed men raided Talamade: two civilians killed, one wounded and 8 kidnapped.
2 killed people and 2 injuried after Boko Haram attacked Mainankoua village (Kolofata). Many others villagers remain captives.
A hand-made bomb exploded and wounded 3 policemen. Authorities link the event to the political turmoil taking place in anglophone Cameroon.
2 wounded in Sagme attack.
On 20 September, armed men and Cameroonian soldiers clashed in Talamade, Mayo Sava: 7 children kidnapped on 18 September died.
On 20 September, Boko Haram elements raided Mainankoua, Mayo Sava. 2 dead and 2 wounded.
5 dead in a twin suicide attack this morning in Kossa (two fatalities included for bombers).
Defusal: On 17 September, vigilantes discovered a landmine in Bounderi, Mayo Sava.
Property destruction: In the night of 16th to 17th sept, Boko Haram members attacked Hidoua and Bavaloga villages, burning 109 houses.
Property destruction: On 16 September, Boko Haram elements raided Tourou, setting fire to more than 60 houses.
On 16 September, 3 Boko Haram men attempted to kidnap a villager in Makary, Logone et Chari.
A MNJTF military personnel and 2 vigilantes of Bonderi were killed between Ardori and Woulba, after IED explosion.
On 15 September, some Boko Haram elements attacked the Cameroonian soldiers in the Djebrili area. One soldier was wounded.
On 14 September, Boko Haram elements ambushed some Cameroonian traders on the Bodo-Rann axis: 2 dead and 5 kidnapped.
5 dead in suicide attack by Boko Haram in Sanda-Wadjiri.
The spouse of Meinta, farmer in Bia village, has been kidnapped last night by Boko Haram armed elements
On 12 September, a military vehicle was hit by a landmine on the Wambache-Gouloudja axis: one wounded.
On 11 September, 2 Boko Haram men clashed with unknown militia in Tallakachi, Mozogo: 1 dead.
On 10 September, a man was lynched by the crowd after he killed the village chief in Larba, Hina.
A bomb exploded at the Bamenda Hospital Roundabout.
ADF attacked the Besongabang army camp, 3 dead and one wounded seriously.
Agreement: 5 hostages kidnapped on 17 August by Boko Haram were freed.
Following some illegal exactions on Njindoun farmers, people's protestations resulted in the death of a young man.
Agreement: 5 people abducted in Dzaba on the night of 05 September returned to their village.
Local media report that a second person was killed early Tuesday as violence continued.
3 dead, 8 people kidnapped, 46 houses burned in Dzaba.

Violent unrest broke out in northwestern Cameroon after gendarmes shot dead a teenage boy on Monday. The unrest points to the continued tensions in the country s two English-speaking region. Hundreds of people shouted and ran to seek refuge Monday evening at the cathedral in Cameroon s northwestern town of Kumbo amid the unrest. A school and government buildings were burned in protest.

In an official statement, Cameroon's defense minister, Joseph Beti Assomo, said that a boy was shot accidentally after villagers attacked gendarmes with locally made guns, wounding one of the gendarmes. The defense minister said the gendarmes were in Kifem on an anti-drug operation and that they opened fired in self-defense. Residents say the gendarmes seized the teenager s corpse and paraded it through the streets.
A man slained yesterday night in Doulou, near Mora by BokoHaram militants
On 3 September, Boko Haram elements raided Kalguiwa, Mayo Sava: 2 people dead.
Boko Haram asking ransom & foodstuffs to villagers in exchange for woman abducted in Igawa.
Gunmen kidnapped 3 persons in Bougoue, at around 20km from Touboro-Sorombeo road, in North Region
Gunmen mounted on motorcycles (Boko Haram) attacked Ashigashia Village, burning 14 houses before they were repelled by vigilantes.
Magala Kabir village chief and one of his sons were killed in an attack.
On 29 August, Cameroonian soldiers ambushed BH elements who had stolen a herd in Igawa, Mora.

Rebels burned down homes and stole vehicles and cattle after killing 16 people in two villages near Mora, in Cameroon's Far North province, about 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the border with Nigeria.
On 27 August, two teenagers were kidnapped in Bourha, Mayo Tsanaga by 4 armed men.
3 dead in Zamga in an attack performed by Boko Haram
Defusal: On 25 August, Cameroonian soldiers defused a landmine on the Bounderi-Kerawa axis.
On 25 August, a Boko Haram raid on Zamga, Mozogo, was repelled by Cameroonian soldiers: 3 civilians and 2 Boko Haram men dead.
At least 15 people killed and 8 others abducted in Gakara (Kolofata).
On 24 August, a Boko Haram raid on Goura, Logone et Chari was repelled by local militia.
On 24 August, Boko Haram men attacked Ngorsono, Logone et Chari: 4 civilians dead, 2 wounded and 20 houses burned down.
Suicide bombing this morning in Mozogo. No details of injuries.
An explosion from Boko Haram suicide bombers killed 4 people and injured 5 others in Kordo
On 23 August, Cameroonian soldiers occupied some localities in the Lac Chad and clashed with Boko Haram men: 4 BH dead.
A 40-year old man was shot last night in Katchimiri (near Doulo) after an incursion of Boko Haram members.
On 22 August, 2 kamikazes exploded themselves in Amchide: 2 civilians dead and 2 vigilantes dead. 4 wounded.

At least half a dozen schools in Cameroon's two English-speaking regions have been burned in the past week. It is the latest sign of deepening tensions as the ongoing strike in Cameroon's two English-speaking regions enters its tenth month. Residents say schools are being targeted for failing to respect the call to strike until all anglophone activists are released from detention.

On 20 August, Cameroonian soldiers ambushed some armed men who raided some herds in Dalari, Kolofata. 10 armed men dead.
On 19 August, a Boko Haram man was killed by Cameroonian soldiers during an ambush in Ganse, Mayo Sava.
On 17 August, a Cameroonian soldiers' patrol was ambushed by Boko Haram elements in Gouldouam, Mayo Sava: 3 dead and 1 wounded.
On 17 August, Boko Haram men raided Guipere, Mozogo: one dead and 6 children kidnapped, houses burned down and goods seized.
3 soldiers dead and one wounded after BH ambush in Wambache in Mora.
BH incursion in Maskota: 1 dead, 6 children kidnapped, 4 houses burnt down, livestock slaughtered.
On 15 August, 2 villagers were surprised by unidentified assailants on their fields in Ashigashiya, Mayo Sava. One dead.
Glo inhabitants repelled and pursued BH assailants till Dougoum (Nigeria): 3 dead and weapons seized.
On 13 August, Boko Haram elements attacked a herders' campment in Yegoua, Kolofata: several herds seized and several herders disappeared.

notes: BIR elements pursued BH men who stole livestock and forced them to leave their booty.
Boko Haram elements abducted two people at Madakar village, Mayo Moskota: one was found dead on 13/08/2017 in Goledje
Suicide bombing by three females in Kalguiwa. A member of a vigilante commitee was injured.
Nigerian refugees at Minawao camp protested against reductions in WFP food supplies, looting one of the organisation's trucks.
On 6 August, a suicidal attack in Amchide, Mayo Sava, killed 9 children and wounded 4.
On 6 August, a suicidal attack by 2 kamikazes in Waza, Logone et Chari, wounded 13 civilians.
On 6 August, the incursion of 5 Boko Haram men in Ganse, Mayo Sava was repelled by Cameroonian soldiers.
A twin suicide bombing in Waza, Extreme Nord, left 15 people injured. The attack had not been claimed as of the time of publishing.
A suicide bombing attributed to Boko Haram in Ouro Kessoum, Mayo-Sava in Extreme Nord, left at least nine killed, including the suicide bomber, and four injured.
5 dead (4 kamikazes and 1 civilian) in suicide attacks.
Clashes between BH and Cameroonian forces. 2 soldiers dead.
Vigilante chief was executed in his house by BH men.
2 soldiers wounded after clashes with Boko Haram terrorists at Gloudjan checkpoint.
On 23 July, Boko Haram men attacked the military post of Meleri, Mayo Sava. Attack repelled, but 4 soldiers wounded.
On 22 July, Cameroon soldiers ambushed Boko Haram elements in Kerawa. 15 bicycles loaded of goods.
2 dead (one kamikaze and one vigilante) and 4 wounded in a suicide attack. One kamikaze on the run.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Cameroon's security forces were on Thursday accused of torturing hundreds of Boko Haram suspects, leading to dozens of deaths, in what Amnesty International said was a war crime. Deprivation of food, water and medical treatment was also used; 32 of the 101 victims said they had seen people die because of the torture and ill-treatment.
A civilian was killed by Boko Haram men at Zeneme village, 10 km from Ashigashiya.
Gendarme killed four fellow gendarmes in Kousseri, Logone et Chari department, on 14 July to protest his alleged mistreatment by the squadron commander.
A suicide attack in Waza: 16 dead (14 civilians + 2 bombers and 42 wounded.

Cameroonian army killed two Boko Haram kamikazes.
Boko Haram men kidnapped a businessman and some members of his family in Karena.

A military post was attacked by Boko Haram after twin attacks on Omaka village in Mora, Far North region: toll unknown.

Suicide attack in Ngalbi (Mora). 4 kamikazes and 1 civilian dead.
On 1 July, two women kamikazes were detected and killed by Cameroonian soldiers in Kolofata.
A suicide attack took place this morining in Kerawa. 2 kamikazes and 1 civilian dead.
Clashes between Boko Haram and Manigueide village's population in the Afade district. One Boko Haram man and two civilians killed.
On 27 June, 2 Cameroonian soldiers were ambushed by Boko Haram men in Ombeche, Mayo Sava. One dead and one wounded.
On 26 June, 8 Boko Haram men attacked the residence of the Alagrano health centre's chief and killed him.
On 26 June, Boko Haram fighters attacked Gakara, Mayo Sava: 3 women were raped.

Two BH kamikazes blew themselves up: one wounded.
A BH kamikaze was killed by the army.
On 23 June, Boko Haram elements attacked Gakara, Mayo Sava; one person kidnapped and some food seized.

On 22 June, the military post in Bargaram was attacked by Boko Haram men: one dead and three wounded.
8 people died as two BH kamikazes blew themselves up.
The Doglo village (Nigeria) chief and his son were murdered.
A soldier died on the Gouzda Vreket - Zamga route because of the explosion of a IED.

On 20 June, a military patrol was hit by a landmine on the Zamga-Djebrili, Mayo Tsanaga: one dead and one wounded.

Violence spread out as a debt between prisoners was not paid back. Police intervention brought the situation back to normal.
On 17 May, 6 villagers were hit by a land mined in Homaka. 3 wounded.
On 15 June, Vigilantes and Cameroonian soldiers clashed while ambushing Boko Haram elements in Sandawadjiri. 1 dead and 9 wounded.

A kamikaze blew up himself without civilian victims.

Kamikazes' explosions were reported in Limani: two civilians dead and nine wounded.
One vigilante died and 9 were wounded in clashes against Boko Haram

2 suicide bomber blew themselves up; no civilian casualty
