On 9 June, a kamikaze was discovered and killed by Cameroonian soldiers in Mora.
On 9 June, a handicapped kamikaze exploded himself: 1 dead.
On 8 June, a Boko Haram supporter (civilian) was wounded during an ambush by Vigilante Militia in Gogo-Kossa.
1 suicide bomber blew herself up, she died as well as a 8-years-old girl wearing an explosive charge. 2 civilians were wounded.
A local pupil was aggressed just before the school exam date. This episode raises attention over sporadic violence aganist educational establishemnt in English Cameroon.

Around 30 Cameroonian soldiers fighting the Nigerian jihadist group Boko Haram were arrested after a demonstration to demand the payment of bonuses and some leave. The soldiers on Sunday "set about stopping traffic with barricades on national route number one," the ministry said in a statement broadcast on state radio.
Defusal: On 4 June, a landmine was discovered by Cameroonian soldiers on the Moskota-Vreket axis.
A kamikaze was shot dead half an hour before the arrival of Mayo-Sava prefect coming from a ceremony in Kolofata
Suicide attack in Kolofata, 11 dead and 30 wounded.
Bafia's bishop was found dead under mysterious circumstances.
Suicide attack in the village of Diakana (also spelled Djamkana): 2 dead (kamikazes) and two wounded (vigilantes)
On 1 June, two women kamikazes wounded two people in their explosion in Djakana, Limani.
Suicide attack in Kolofata, the kamikaze died, some people were wounded
Army checkpoint in Boungour, 20 km from Makary, was attacked by Boko Haram. One solider died.
On 25 May, the military post of Boungour, dans le Lac Tchad, was attacked by Boko Haram men. Two soldiers wounded.
Four people kidnapped, three young girls and one woman in Gakara and one women in near-by Dougdje.
Two kamikazes exploded themselves, another one was killed by police. No civilian casualty.
Arrests: On 23 May, 400 people were arrested in Kolofata.
On 22 May, several armed men attacked Mbaldjock. Several goods seized and 8 wounded.
Double suicide attack this morning in Mora: 3 dead (2 kamikazes and 1 civilian) and 3 wounded. 2 kamikazes wanted.
On 16 May, 30 Boko Haram soldiers attacked Kolofata: shops looted and goods seized. One wounded.

Suspecting negotiation leaders of corruption, dockers went again on strike (3 days after their initial action) to demand better conditions to GPAC after assaulting at 22h the harbour entrance. Police intervened with teargas to disperse workers without success. Activities resumed gradually on Thurdsay, 18th thanks to the intervention of SYNTRAC another labour organisation.
Agreement: Many Boko Haram militants surrendered to Cameroonian police after famine among Lake Chad islands worsened.
4 women were kidnapped in Vreket by Boko Haram while looking for fresh water.
On 15 May, 4 people were kidnapped by Boko Haram in Goudza Vreket, Mozogo.
On 14 May, Cameroonian soldiers ambushed Boko Haram fighters in Gakara, Mayo Sava.
Two Nigerian kamikazes exploded themselves killing one civilian and wounding six people.
Boko Haram killed 2 vigilantes and kidnapped two children. The children's bodies were found in the morning in the same location.
Boko Haram attacked the Marins base on Kessa, 7 km away from Fotokol. They were driven back after some hours of fighting.
Boko Haram incursion in Ndaba-Blakoldji in the outskirts of Kolofata; four people were killed, ten wounded, houses were torched and cattle and food were stolen.
On 1 May, Cameroonian soldiers repelled Boko Haram incursion in Manawachi, Kerawa.
On 28 April, Cameroonian soldiers ambushed BH supporters in Magdeme, Mayo Sava.
On 28 April, a kamikaze died in Tchakamari, Mora in the explosion of her charges.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Reportedly, on Thursday afternoon the Multinational Mixed Force (FMM) tracked down and killed two Boko Haram militants. During the fight, terrorists fired indiscriminately and wounded 43 civilians. Later, some sources affirmed FMM killed 50 militants during this operation.
A suicide bombing was reported in the Chakarmari area. The bomber was killed and one civilian was injured.
4 members of a vigilance committee from Achigachia were killed during clashes with Boko Haram.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: One civilian was killed and 35 other injured, as well as 7 BIR soldiers, during an attack by Boko Haram militants on Ndaba in the Kolofata area. Several militants were also killed (unknown fatalities coded as 10).
3 Cameroonian soldiers were killed and 5 wounded when their truck hit a landmine planted by suspected Boko Haram militants as it passed between Homeka and Bladole in Mora district.
A suicide bomber on a bicycle killed a constable and 2 civilians in an attack in Kolofata. 4 others were injured.
Ex-employees of state companies staged a sit-in outside the Ministry of Finance in Yaounde to demand their rights.
Suspected Boko Haram fighters killed one person and abducted 3 girls in Mbereche, near Limani.
On 19 April, Boko Haram men attacked Mbichere, Mayo Sava: 1 dead, 3 girls kidnapped.
Hundreds of youths in Bamenda marched on the Cameroonian Ministry of Posts and Telecomms to demand the re-instatement of internet for Cameroon's English-speaking regions.
At least 2 people were killed by Boko Haram fighters during an attack in Sandawadjiri.
On 9 April, 12 armed men attacked Ganai, Mayo Sava: 4 dead.
A suicide bombing by a suspected Boko Haram bomber resulted in 3 killed and 20 wounded in Kolofata.
At least 4 people were killed by Boko Haram fighters in an attack on the locality of Ganei.
On 6 April, Boko Haram men attacked Gakara: one woman was raped, CNI and cloth seized.
On 5 April, Boko Haram men attempting to sheltering in a school were repelled by Cameroonian soldiers.
On 4 April, Boko Haram fighters were intercepted by some vigilantes. Motos, bicycles and weapons seized.
2 suspected Boko Haram suicide bombers set off their explosives at the entrance to Mora, near a technical high school. No other casualties were reported.
A market in Limbe was attaced by arsonists. The govenrment accuses secessionist groups of being behind the attack.
On 31 March, Boko Haram fighters attacked Gakara, Mayo Sava: one civilian wounded, 7 bicycles and 6 sheep seized.
On 30 March, two kamikaze died in Kourgui, Mayo Sava in the explosion of their charges.
Arrests: On 30 March, 811 people were arrested in Talamade.
Teachers took to the streets in Yaounde, Maroua and Bambili to demand between 25-60 months of backpay, bonuses and promotions.
Teachers took to the streets in Yaounde, Maroua and Bambili to demand between 25-60 months of backpay, bonuses and promotions.
Teachers took to the streets in Yaounde, Maroua and Bambili to demand between 25-60 months of backpay, bonuses and promotions.

At least 3 Boko Haram militants were killed during an attack carried out on Cameroonian navy positions in Soueram area, near Ngouma. At least 2 Cameroonian military personnel were injured and taken to Kousseri for treatment. Other sources said as many as 9 were killed during the attack, mostly Boko Haram fighters.
Arrests: On 18 March, 642 Nigerian refugees were arrested in Dabanga.
On 18 March, the village chief was aggressed by 4 armed men in Ndoukoula, Diamare.
On 17 March, a girl was kidnapped by unidentified men in Mbichere, Mayo Sava. She was wounded by gunshots while attempting to escape.
4 army personnel were injured when a truck travelling between Zamga and Djibrili in the Mayo-Moskota area hit a landmine planted by suspected Boko Haram fighters .
Arrests: On 15 March, 1171 (330 Nigerians) were arrested.
Arrests: On 13 March, 1587 people were arrested in Ganse.
On 12 March, Boko Haram fighters attacked a military post in Soueram, Fotokol. 3 BH killed and 2 soldiers wounded.
Defusal: On 11 March, a landmine was discovered by Cameroonian soldiers on the Kolofata-Kerawa axis.
One person was killed and several wounded in an attack by Boko Haram on Goulouzivini village, near Wana.
On 10 March, 11 Boko Haram men attacked Goumouzini. One dead, one wounded and 18 houses burned down.
On 9 March, 4 unidentified men attacked dans la zone de Touboro, North Region. 1 vigilante dead and one wounded.
A suspected BK suicide bomber detonated himself in the Magdeme area. No casualties were reported.
On 6 March, 2 women kamikazes were killed by Cameroonian soldiers in Wambashe, Mayo Sava.
2 suspected BK suicide bombers were killed by soldiers in the Boudoua area of Limani.
A villager was killed in the Madina neighbourhood of Fotokol by Boko Haram fighters.
A villager was killed by Boko Haram fighters in the Waza area.
On 24 February, Boko Haram fighters attacked Kouyape, Mayo Sava. One local militia member was killed, three shops were raided and motos seized.
2 people were killed (including a bomber) and 2 wounded in a suicide attack by suspected Boko Haram militants in Amchide.
On 21 February, Boko Haram forces were repelled from Ganse, Kolofata by Cameroonian soldiers.
The National Center for Youth and Sports Bamenda was the target of an attempted arson attack.
On 17 February, 12 Boko Haram men attacked Doudo, Bogo: 4 motos and other goods seized. They were catched by Cameroonian soldiers. 4 dead.
3 Cameroonian soldiers were killed when their vehicle hit a mine planted by suspected Boko Haram fighters at Gouzda Vreket in Mayo-Tsanaga.

The Minister of Communications reported that at least 60 Boko Haram fighters were killed (4 fatalities reported in other events), a stronghold destroyed and a large stockpile of weapons seized during an offensive by Cameroonian army forces in the Mandara Mountains area since Jan.26. The minister also reported more than 5,000 people had been freed from captivity by Boko Haram. 20 suspected Boko Haram fighters were also arrested.
On 12 February, Cameroonian soldiers ambushed Boko Haram men in Bia, Mora: 2 motos seized.
On 11 February, vigilante militia intercepted 4 Boko Haram fighters in Waramide, close to Sandawadjiri: 1 BH killed.

2 protesters were killed and 10 others injured when police opened fire on them as they tried to storm a police station in Ndop in Cameroon's northwestern Anglophone region. The protesters were demanding the release of those accused of setting a French school on fire. After the deaths, the protesters allegedly kidnapped the families of the area brigade commander and police commissioner and demanded the release of all detained youths from the area.
A French school was set on fire in the Ndop during ongoing unrest in Cameroon's northwestern Anglophone region.
Looting: On 7 February, Boko Haram soldiers attacked Bakaresse, Kolofata: mobile phones, money, cloth and food were seized.

Unidentified assailants allegedly used physical intimidation to prevent students from returning to classes during continued dead city strikes in Bamenda. Unidentified individuals also set fire to an administrative block in Bamenda during continued dead city strikes. A bus used by the bilingual Nitop high school was also vandalized.
6 Cameroonian soldiers were injured in a clash with Boko Haram fighters at Gakara.
On 6 February, vigilante militia ambushed Boko Haram men in Bakeresse, Kerawa. 1 AK47, a motorcycle were recovered.
Property destruction: On 4 February, Boko Haram men attacked Goumouldi, as a retaliation against cattle dealers. 4 houses were burned down.
On 4 February, Cameroonian soldiers ambushed Boko Haram forces in Gakara, Kolofata. 6 soldiers wounded and 7 BH killed.
On 3 February, two women kamikazes attempted to launch a suicidal attack in Kerawa: one exploded herself under the pressure of militia and the second was killed by the militia.

At least 4 people were killed, including 3 bombers, in a suspected Boko Haram suicide attack at Double market in the Far North near the Nigerian border. Other sources estimated as many as 16 had died. Many of those injured were taken to Mora hospital.

An armed group attacked a UN Technical Monitoring Team, killing five individuals a UN independent contractor, three Nigerian nationals and one Cameroonian national in the vicinity of Hosere Jongbi, near Kontcha, Cameroon, about 700 kilometres north of the capital Yaounde. A soldier of the Rapid Intervention Battalion belonging to the escort of the team was also wounded.
1 person was killed and 3 wounded in an attack by Boko Haram fighters on the Ouro-Moussa Kambo locality of Fotokol district.
Looting: On 29 January, Boko Haram men attacked Kerawa. No further info available.
Looting: On 27 January, 16 Boko Haram men seized some cloth, food and cattle in Gabal, Kolofata.
Looting: On 25 January, some armed men seized people's goods at the mosquee's exit in Bia, Kolofata.
On 22 January, Boko Haram men attacked Blakafe, Mora: one person was wounded by gunfire and some food was seized.
On 21 January, the Cameroonian army launched a military operation at the Waza Park, where the presence of around 300 armed men was reported.
On 21 January, Boko Haram men could hoist 2 BH flags in Kolofata during an incursion. Cameroonian soldiers brought them down after confronting them.
On 21 January, 4 children were surprised by an unknown explosion while they were burning trash. 2 dead and 2 wounded.
At least 3 people were killed and 4 others injured in a suicide attack by a suspected Boko Haram member in the Madana district of the city of Kousseri.
On 20 January, Nigerian refugees barricaded the road linking Zamai and Minawao.
On 20 January, the incursion of 15 Boko Haram men was repelled in Korgui, Mora by Cameroonian soldiers.
Bamenda was again shut down by a dead city protest strike which was accompanied by a demonstrations, although there were no reports of violence.
On 18 January, 2 children were hit by a landmine in Soueram, Fotokol. 2 wounded.
On 18 January, a woman who refused to obey a vigilante militia was executed in Kouyape, Mayo Sava.

assoc_actor_1: CACSC: Cameroon Anglophone Civil Society Consortium
notes: Violent protests broke out in Buea after police arrested two leaders of the CACSC following the banning of the organization. Police used water cannons, tear gas and aerial gunfire to disperse the crowds. In some parts of the city youths built barricades and scuffled with police. There were also reports of vandalism against petrols stations and cars damaged.

assoc_actor_1: CACSC: Cameroon Anglophone Civil Society Consortium
notes: A peaceful sit-in in Limbe called by the CACSC later turned into clashes between stone-throwing youths and tear gas firing by police/gendarmerie. 30 people were arrested. This occurred after youth started setting up barricades in the town.
16 bodies were found in the Gnam-Gnam area. They are suspected to have been killed by Boko Haram.
On 14 January, Cameroonian fighters ambushed Boko Haram fighters in Goudale, Mokolo. 8 BH dead and 3 arrested.

Police opened fire on some youths in the city of Bamenda, who were protesting the alleged detention of some Anglophone labour leaders, resulting in serious injuries to 3. This occurred during a dead city strike related to ongoing labour strikes and calls for Anglophone independence. Looting was also reported in Bamenda during the incident, as well as a break-in at the Cameroonian election organizations premises in the city during which 3 vehicles were burned.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Suspected Boko Haram fighters ambushed RIB soldiers, killing 3, in the Kolofata area. This followed a similar attack the day before.
2 suspected Boko Haram suicide bombers were killed in Kolofata as they attempted to target Cameroonian military forces. One died after detonating their bomb, while the other was killed by gunfire.

2 suspected Boko Haram suicide bombers were killed after detonating their bombs when confronted by vigilance committees members in the Double area of the Far North. One vigilance committee member was injured in the attack.
On 11 January, a 70-years-old man was killed by Boko Haram men in Afade, Makari.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Suspected Boko Haram militants killed an RIB soldier in an attack in the Kolofata area.
On 9 January, some men killed a soldier, took his weapon and looted a shop in Kolofata.
Looting: On 8 January, the villages of Mbanari and Bia around Kolofata were looted and several herds were seized.
On 7 January, Cameroon soldiers and Boko Haram men clashed in Igawa, Mora. Two dead and two wounded.
On 7 January, Cameroonian forces cordoned Glem (Dabanga) off: a person trying to escape was killed.
On 6 January, Boko Haram fighters attacked Ngourou and were repelled by Cameroonian soldiers.
On 4 January, a Boko Haram incursion in Sandawadjiri, Mayo Sava, was repelled by local militia.
On 4 January, a mass protest against cattle thief's sprung up in Kaina-Polgue, Mayo Danay.
On 3 January, Boko Haram fighters attacked Glem, Dabanga: one civilian wounded by gunfire, some food were seized.
Looting: On 3 January, Boko Haram fighters attacked Kalguiwa, Mora: two herds seized.
Defusal: On 3 January, a landmine was discovered by vigilantes and defused by Cameroonian soldiers on the Kangara-Bonderi axis.
On 2 January, a military vehicle was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram in Igawa, Mayo Sava. One soldier dead and two wounded.
On 2 January, military forces ambushed Boko Haram men in Djebrili: 2 BH dead and a bike recovered.
On 29 December, Cameroonian soldiers ambushed 3 Boko Haram fighters in Wambashe, Kolofata. One BH fighter dead.
A suspected Boko Haram suicide bomber killed 3 (including the bomber) and wounded 5 in Mora.
On 25 December, Cameroonian soldiers ambushed some alleged BH supply providers in Tayere, Doulo. One dead.
On 25 December, 10 Boko Haram fighters raided Chaode, Zigague. One kidnapped.
On 23 December, a Boko Haram attack was repelled by Cameroonian soldiers: 1 soldier wounded.
On 17 December, 20 armed men kidnapped a 75-years-old man in Homaka, Mayo Sava.
2 cattle traders were killed by Boko Haram fighters in the Grea area, near Kolofata.
Defusal: On 13 December, two landmines were defused on the Zamga-Djebrili in Mayo Sava by FMM soldiers
Defusal: On 12 December, a landmine was defused in Mayo Sava (Homaka-Madawaya axis) by FMM soldiers

2 people were injured during protests in Kumba. The city was shut down by demonstrators during the day, including the building of barricades to block roads, but in the evening security forces intervened, leading to clashes. Protesters threw rocks at police, while the police responded with tear gas.

At least 2 people were killed, allegedly by police firing, and 10 injured during protests in Bamenda. The protesters were attempting to thwart a rally planned by the ruling CPDM party, resulting in clashes with police. Protesters burned a police station in the citys 3rd district and released the prisoners detained there. 58 people were arrested on charges of rioting following the events.
Thousands of Bangwas from Lebialem division protested in Fontem to denounce perceived marginalization of Anglophones.

Protests continued in Bamenda where the demonstrators attempted to storm the premises of the Regional Division of the Juidical Police (DRPJ). The protesters demanded the release of an protester detained during earlier demonstrations.

Students of the University of Cameroon began a strike due to their grievances in relation to the Vice Chancellor who they say has embezzeled money and imposed unreasonable penalties on students. Riot police later arrived to disperse the students with tear gas, batons and aerial firing. At least 3 students were injured in the events.
Property destruction: 70 houses were burned and several shops ransacked during a Boko Haram attack on Ndiguina. No casualties were reported.
On 25 November, Cameroonian soldiers ambushed Boko Haram men in Kolofata: 64 BH dead, 55 weapons, 3 motos and 40 bikes seized.
On 25 November, Cameroonian soldiers ambushed Boko Haram men in Darack, Logone et Chari: 9 Boko Haram men dead.
2 female suicide bombers were killed in an attempted attack on Mora, while one blowing herself up, and the other shot dead by the soldiers.
30 suspected Boko Haram members were captured in the Darack area of the Far North (near Ngouma).
On 23 November, 2 BH kamikazes were killed by local militia while approaching some schools in Mora.

Clashes continued between protesters and police in Bamenda as the protesters demand an end to discrimination against anglophones and call for independence. At least 4 people were reported killed in the clashes but the details of the deaths were not clear.
6 soldiers were wounded in a landmine blast planted by suspected Boko Haram fighters in the Limani area.
A Cameroonian soldier was injured in another attack on Darack, a day after 6 people were killed in an attack in the same locality.
Police dispersed a lawyers protest in front of the Bamenda court of appeals.

Hundreds of people marched in Bamenda to support a teachers strike. The march evolved into calls for an end to discrimination against anglophones and independence for the Northwest. Clashes broke out between the protesters and police when they attempted to disperse the march.
A suspected Boko Haram suicide bomber was killed by soldiers in Kolofata.
Suspected Boko Haram fighters attempted to raid the town of Ndiguina but were repulsed.
5 Cameroonian soldiers and a vigilance committee member were killed in an attack by Boko Haram on a gendarmerie station on the island of Darack, near the Nigerian border.
Property destruction: On 21 November, Boko Haram men attacked Diguina, Waza: 1 shop looted, 52 houses burned.
Property destruction: On 20 November, 3 Boko Haram fighters attacked Madjina, Hile Alifa: 6 houses burned.
A thief was beaten to death by community group after he attempted to steal some bread.
On 19 November, 20 fishermen were attacked by Boko Haram men in Toumbou Ali, Logone et Chari: 3 dead, 2 wounded and 1 kidnapped.
On 19 November, 70 Boko Haram fighters ambushed a truck and an army pick-up between Waza and Zigue on the Route n1. One wounded.
On 18 November, two farmers were killed by Boko Haram men in Waza.
On 17 November, Boko Haram raid on Labado was repelled by local militia.
Looting: On 17 November, 30 Boko Haram men looted some shops in Kouyape, Mayo Sava.
Movement of forces: on 17 November, BH forces were allegedly gathering in Dabanga, in order to raid the Route N1.
On 11 November, 20 Boko Haram fighters were killed during a Cameroonian army ambush in Cheripouri, Mayo Sava.
Looting: On 10 November, 80 Boko Haram men attacked Agzawaya, Mayo Sava: 50 houses burned and food seized. No reported causality.

Long night of clashes between the motorcycle taxi drivers and police officers. 5 drivers were arrested for irregularities by the police and after the news circulated among their colleagues they stormed the police unit and erected barricades.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: The security situation in the Far North region was marked by Boko Haram attacking the positions of the defense and security forces in Cameroonian territory in the locality of Sandawadjiri near Kolofata, Nov. 9. The report states about twenty fighters of Boko Haram killed, weapons and ammunition seized.

A squad of gendarmes, Nov. 8, at City Chemist Roundabout, Bamenda used tear gas to disperse over 200 lawyers who were carrying on a peaceful demonstration. According to the gendarmes, they claimed that tear-gassing the crowd was an attempt to stop bike riders who wanted to disrupt the strike and not for the lawyers. The gendarmes arrested some of the bike riders after confrontations with some of the lawyers.
On 8 November, an army truck was hit by a landmine in Waliassi, Mayo Sava: 3 wounded.

Cameroonian workers at the China First Highway Engineering Company in Matomb went on strike in demand of better pay and working conditions. Violent confrontations have occurred, and the government is trying to mediate the crisis.
Property destruction: On 6 October, Boko Haram fighters attacked Goudjouane, Bounderi: 66 houses burned.
On 2 November, an army patrol was ambushed by Boko Haram men in Gassama, Dabanga: one wounded.
On 31 October, vigilantes killed a BH suspect in Agzawaya.
Arrests: Oct. 28, baton-wielding police stormed the Cameroon people party (Cpp), in Essos neighborhood in Yaounde. Kah Walla, the President of PPC and 51 other people were arrested.
On 28 October, 5 Boko Haram men attacked a truck in Dabanga, Logone et Chari: 1 dead and a woman kidnapped.
On 28 October, Boko Haram fighters attacked Gakara, Mayo Sava: 2 people kidnapped and goods seized.
On 25 October, several armed men kidnapped a man in Gakara, Mayo Sava, and brought him to Nigeria.
On 24 October, Boko Haram men attacked a herders' camp by night in Matakaya, Amchide: 2 herders dead and a herd seized.
On 24 October, a kamikaze exploded himself in Sandawadjiri: 3 dead and 6 wounded.

A suicide attack occurred in the Sandawadjiri locality. 2 suspected Boko Haram bombers were spotted by a vigilance committee in the area, resulting in one detonated their explosives and injuring 5 members of the committee. The other escaped.
A suicide attack occurred in the Waramide area of Kaigamari district, near Kolofata. The bomber detonated their explosives, killing 1 other person and wounding another.
On 19 October, the army post in Djebrili, Mayo Sava, was attacked by Boko Haram men: 1 soldier dead, 5 wounded, weapons seized.
Former employees of Placam Shipyard blocked a bridge over the Wouri to demand payment of severance.
On 15 October, an exchange of fire between Boko Haram men and Cameroonian soldiers was reported in Ardori, Mayo Sava.
On 15 October, Boko Haram fighters attacked Ganse, Mayo Sava: 1 dead and goods seized.
On 12 October, Cameroonian soldiers and part of the population put some BH fighters on the run following an incursion. 1 BH man dead.

People suffering from kidney failure and some supporters demonstrated at Yaounde General Hospital staged a demonstration to demand better treatment. Police were called, apparently on the claim that the protesters were going to rob the hospital, but left after the situation was explained.
On 9 October, Boko Haram men attacked Labadou, Mora: 2 dead, several wounded and several goods seized.

Boko Haram fighters attacked a Joint Multinational Force checkpost in the Sagme area of Maraki district. They killed one person and injured 4 police officers. Soldiers then arrived and engaged in a gunfight with the militants which lasted into the early hours of the morning (Oct.6-7).

The brother of a village chief who had just returned from a pilgrimage to Mecca was killed and 6 others injured in an attack in Selal-Mbousiki village in the Touboro area. The reason for the attack was not clear but residents say it was planned as the village chiefs house was targeted by the heavily armed gunmen.
A man was abducted in the Ouli area by unidentified "rebels" from the CAR. He was released on Oct.12.

Boko Haram fighters attacked a Joint Multinational Force checkpost in the Sagme area of Maraki district. They killed one person and injured 4 police officers. Soldiers then arrived and engaged in a gunfight with the militants which lasted into the early hours of the morning (Oct.6-7).
On 3 October, an attack by BH fighters to Double was repelled by Cameroonian army.
A Cameroonian soldier was killed and at least 2 others wounded in an attack on the Dambore-Ardebe outpost in Makari district. The attackers also burn down the outpost.
On 1 October, 3 men were kidnapped in Krong, Kaele (Mayo-Kani) by 6 armed men.
On 1 October, Cameroonian soldiers intercepted 8 suspects BH men in Amchide, killing 2 and seizing their animals.
On 30 September, 4 people were abducted by Boko Haram men in Mouria, Mayo Sava.
Bandits attacked the Balepouo resort in the Bafou area, leading to a gunfight with its residents. No casualties were reported.
Displacement: On 27 September, Koudougou people seek shelter in Fokotol, following the attack of BH men. Toll unavailable.

Arrests: A large number of people (no specific number but reported as a mass arrest) were taken into custody in the Wokaka area after either turning on a water tap that had been shut off by the municipality or for removing pillars from private plots of land marked for sale.
On 26 September, 2 people were abducted, along with some food, following the incursion of BH elements.
After a large number of people were arrested in the Wokaka area, residents of Wokaka marched on the offices of the Divisional Worker in Buea to demand their release.

Commercial bike riders in Douala engaged in a riding protest against the impounding of their bikes by council officials and security forces. They moved around the city demanding the release of their bikes and threatening more actions otherwise. The bikers allegedly became violent in some areas, assaulting at least one police officer, leading to clashes. At least 15 protesters were detained.

3 civilians were killed (4 fatalities including the bomber) when a vigilante attempted to stop a suspected Boko Haram suicide bomber. The bomber was allegedly headed to Mora but was prevented from reaching his target by members of the Djakana vigilance committee.
On 16 September, Boko Haram men attacked Sandawadjiri, Mayo Sava: two wounded and two people kidnapped.
On 15 September, a local militia was killed by Boko Haram elements in Bakaresse, Mayo Sava.
In September, the military post in Ardebe, Logone et Chari, was attacked by BH elements: one soldier dead and weapons seized.
Wokaka villagers organized a protest march to the Southwest Attorney Generals office in Buea to call for his departure.
On 10 September, a military vehicle was hit by a landmine in Djebrili, Mayo Sava. 6 wounded.
On 9 September, BH elements attacked Aissa Karde, Mora: one dead, 4 house burned down and 2 oxes killed.
Looting: On 2 September, BH elements raided Kalassari, Mayo Sava: more then 500 cattle heads and 100 sheep were seized.
Cameroonian forces prevented a Boko Haram raid on the Kerawa area about 7km away from the Nigerian border.

Arrests: 76 suspects were arrested in a search operation by the security forces in the Mora and Kolofata areas which was looking for Boko Haram members/supporters. Those arrested included 37 Nigerians, 32 Cameroonians, and 7 Chadians.
A civilian was killed and 2 children were kidnapped during a Boko Haram raid in the Gouzoudou area near Kolofata. Several shops were also looted.
Taxi drivers went on strike and demonstrated in central Bafoussam against what they perceive as corruption among the citys agents.
On 27 August, some BH men attacked Gakara, Kolofata: 4 dead, cattle and food seized.

Scores of Common Law Layers from the Northwest and Southwest regions and hundreds of activists of the SCNC occupied the Buea Magistrate Court to demand an end to the "arbitrary arrest and detention of anglophones in Cameroon".

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Members of the BIR engaged in an operation in the Tapi area of Touboro which succeeded in freeing 3 hostages from "bandits".
On 23 August, two Nigerian displaced people were abducted by some armed men in Mayo Sava and brought to Nigeria.
On 23 August, some Boko Haram elements attacked Tchakamari, Mora, on Natione Route n1. One dead and some shops looted.
Three civilians were killed and around 20 others wounded on Sunday in a suicide attack in in Mora, a town inCameroons far north near the Nigerian border. Another civilian died later of his wounds.
On 19 August, a vigilante was killed by a gunshot while going home in Bakaresse.
A militant of a vigilante group was killed in his house in Double by members of Boko Haram.
Boko Haram raided Kolofata, killing a local vigilante and a Nigerian national and looting homes.
On 18 August, two gendarmes were assaulted in Makari while going home by some unknown aggressors.
On 18 August, one civilians was wounded by a gunshot as BH men raided Karabiwa, Magdeme.
4 people were killed by Boko Haram in Gambarou, near Double, during the week starting on August 15th.
On 17 August, Cameroonian soldiers ambushed BH men in Grea, Kolofata: 27 BH men killed, 10 arrested, weapons and cattle seized.
27 combattants "eliminated" by the military in an ambush near Fotokol. 10 others arrested and weapons seized.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: A militant of Boko Haram was killed near Kolofata by elements of the Cameroonian Army.
In August, an incursion of a dozen Boko Haram elements was reported in Garaka, Kolofata. One dead.
On 14 August, Boko Haram men and the local militia clashed in Kerawa: one dead and one wounded.
Looting: On 13 August, some Boko Haram elements attacked Cheripouri, Mayo Sava: a shop was looted, some cattle, bikes and phones were seized.
On 11 August, 3 people were kidnapped by Boko Haram men in Ashigashiya, Mayo Sava.
On 11 August, 10 people were kidnapped by Boko Haram men in Bame, Kolofata.
Looting: On 5 August, some Boko Haram elements attacked Bourvare, Mayo Sava, seizing some cattle: the cattle was later recovered by Cameroonian soldiers.
Prisoners held a peaceful strike to protest prison conditions.
On 31 July, Boko Haram elements attacked Double, Mayo Sava. 1 civilian was killed.
On 31 July, Boko Haram elements attacked Hougne, Mayo Sava. 2 wounded, several houses burned down and some cattle seized.
After the village of Tchebe-Tchebe was mostly evacuated, Boko Haram invaded and beheaded the sole remaining civilian, a 60 year old man.
Boko Haram incursion into Kolofata repelled within an hour by military. Casualties unknown.
Property destruction: On 23 July, Boko Haram elements attacked Mora: 19 houses were burned down and some cattle was stolen.
ISIL affiliated group claims to have killed 17 soldiers and wounded others in Tan Bawri, near Fotokol.
On 22 July, a man was killed by some unidentified men in Mayo Gakara, Mayo Sava.
Property destruction: On 22 July, Boko Haram elements attacked Mora: 19 houses were burned down and some cattle was stolen.
Arrests: Vigilantes arrested local Boko Haram leader Koudjalima and handed him over to gendarmerie.
On 21 July, the military post in Dambore was attacked two times by Boko Haram men. 3 dead among the assailants.
On 17 July, the military post in Kamouna was attacked. No further information available.
On 17 July, some Boko Haram elements attacked Malloumri, Mayo Sava, killing 2 civilians.
On 17 July, the military post in Limani was attacked by Boko Haram men. 18 dead among the assailants.
On 15 July, a truck was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram elements in Double, Mayo Sava.

Security Measures: Cameroun is reopening its border with Nigeria in the Far North region because the threats of attacks by Boko Haram militants have subsided sufficiently to resume commercial activities, according to the regions governor. Cameroun closed the border amid at least 200 attacks by the Nigeria-based militant organisation, which killed as many as 480 people since July 2015, according to Amnesty International.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: A second military truck hit a landmine on july 14 in Double. No injuries reported.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: A soldier was killed and three others injured when a military truck hit a landmine in Limani-Waliyassi, Mayo-Sava department, on July 14.
Near Mozogo, six gunmen assassinated vigilante leader Modou Boukar by slitting his throat in his home on the day of his installation as chief.
Property destruction: On 14 July, Boko Haram elements attacked Amchide, Mayo Sava. Several houses were burned down.
On 13 July, 4 bodies were found: they were reportedly victims of Boko Haram.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Four soldiers were injured in Mourdas when their vehicle hit a landmine in Mourdas on July 12.

Soldiers demanded their friends ride a train for free, and shot in the air when train employees refused. Gendarmes intervened, arresting two soldiers. In protest against the arrests, 98 remaining soldiers stopped the train from leaving for several hours.
Two civilians were killed during an attack carried out by Boko Haram militants in Maloumri.
Government forces evicted illegal residents of a nature corridor in the north, including Faro, Benoue, and Bouba Ndjidda. Clashes left several residents and one soldier injured.
On 10 July, Boko Haram men attacked Amchide, Mayo Sava, killing 4 men (the village chief and his 3 children)
On 9 July, Boko Haram men attacked some civilians going to the Kouyape market and kidnapped 6.
Boko Haram abducted 6 women. One man on a bicycle escaped and alerted soldiers and vigilantes, who when on patrol to find the women.
On 7 July, a military vehicle was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram in Ganse, Mayo Sava. Two soldiers wounded.
On 7 July, Boko Haram fighters attacked Gouloum, Waza: 2 civilians dead, one wounded; several houses, cattle heads and other goods were seized.

Police forces and vigilantes clashed with suspected kidnappers in Martap. During the fire exchange two hostages were released and weapons of war and ammunition recovered. Two gunmen were killed while two others are still on the run.
On 4 July, Boko Haram elements kidnapped a 11-years-old boy and a 16-years-old girl in Gangawa, Mayo Sava.
On 3 July, 4 Cameroonian fishermen were ambushed by Boko Haram men. One wounded.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: On July 1 a group of Boko Haram members attacked an outpost of the Mixed Multinational Force (Fmm) in Homaka, injuring a soldier.
12 killed and four injured in suicide bombing in the village of Diakana (also spelled Djamkana). Many victims were members of vigilante group.
On 29 June, some truck drivers protested in Kousseri, Logone et Chari.
On 29 June, BH men and local militia clashed in Wawouli, Kolofata: 1 dead.
On 25 June, Cameroonian soldiers ambushed some BH men responsible of cattle thefts in Mada. 3 dead and some weapons seized.
Four killed, including one soldier, when vehicle hit landmine likely planted by Boko Haram near the village of Kamouna near Lake Chad.
Around 100 lawyers protested against the penal code. The march was "momentarily interrupted" by police.
On 24 June, Boko Haram elements attacked Gouzoudou, Mayo Sava. Two civilians dead and several shops looted.
On 24 June, Boko Haram elements attacked Kalguiwa, Mayo Sava. Two civilians dead, 3 wounded and 3 herds seized.
On 24 June, Boko Haram men attacked the residence of Baba Oumate and killed him.
Boko Haram raided Gouzoudou village, killing two and injuring two.
Boko Haram incursion into Kalguiwa village, killing one and injuring several. 15 huts burned.
On 21 June, BH men wounded a man in Kolofata, during an incursion to seize motos and foods.
On 20 June, the Cameroonian offensive against BH's sanctuaries in the Lake Chad resulted in 3 dead and one wounded.
On 20 June, Cameroonian soldiers and BH's men clashed in Amchide, Mayo Sava. 10 BH fighters dead.
On 19 June, some armed men attacked Am Talia, Waza, killing one civilian.
On 18 June, the chief of the Kordo village, Logone et Chari, was wounded by a gunshot during a Boko Haram attack.
Unidentified gunmen stormed gendarme post, one killed and one injured.
On 16 June, some herders were intercepted by Boko Haram fighters in Gnangnan, Waza: one herder was kidnapped, and two herds were seized.

More than 1,000 people accused of supporting Boko Haram in Cameroon are being detained in military bases and prisons, often without any evidence, and dozens are dying from disease, malnutrition and torture. Several detainees in the military bases told Amnesty that they were tortured and beaten with sticks, whips and machetes, sometimes until they lost consciousness. According to Amnesty in the main prison in Maroua, the capital of the Far North region, between six and eight people die every month in dirty and overcrowded cells where malnutrition is rife.
Movement of forces: BH forces were allegedly gathering on pick-ups along the Route N1 at the level of Hamtchaka.
Nearly 500 children marched to advocate for childrens rights and to demand social services.
On 13 June, 4 bodies were found in Mainankoua, Mayo Sava. They were probably killed bu BH men.
On 13 June, two local militias disappeared while busy in patrolling the surroundings of Maloumri, Mayo Sava, as they were probably surprised by Boko Haram men.
Two farmers killed by Boko Haram near Sakme village.
Boko Haram boarded a boat and killed around 9 civilians.
Boko Haram attack on fishermen on two Cameroonian islands on Lake Chad, killing 35 from Cameroon, Chad, and Nigeria. Another 55 fishermen abducted.
On 7 June, a military truck was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram men in Ganse, Mayo Sava. 2 soldiers severely wounded.
On 7 June, two militaries were killed by Boko Haram men in Maga, Mayo Danay, presumably when they were out of service.
Security forces ambushed Boko Haram militants, killing three.
On 3 June, Boko Haram men ambushed Cameroonian soldiers in Ajiri, Logone: one solider dead and several wounded.
Armed group took several hostages and battled with security forces. One civilian killed and 8 hostages released. The perpetrators are believed to be from CAR.
Armed group took several hostages and battled with security forces. One civilian killed by kidnappers and 8 hostages released. The perpetrators are believed to be from CAR.
Boko Haram "launched a small operation" but were repulsed. One civilian injured in his home.
Arrests: The president of the CPP, Kah Walla, and around ten other opposition activists were arrested for unclear reasons.
Boko Haram killed 9 and abducted 2, burning huts and stealing cattle.
5 Boko Haram killed a fisherman and injured another.
On 20 May, Boko Haram fighters attacked Lakafoua, Tourou, killing 10 civilians and burning down 40 houses.
On 15 May, a herder and some of his sheep were killed by a landmine planted by Boko Haram in Kamouna, Logone and Chari.
Herder died after stepping on a mine.
At least 3 suspected Boko Haram fighters were killed by Cameroonian army forces in Ngouraya (Goura) village bordering Nigeria when the fighters attempted to attack thhe village.

Former employees receiving pensions from the CICAM cotton company, based in Douala, protested outside its gates to demand their payments. Police were present and allegedly took placards away from the protesters, but no injuries or clashes were reported.

350 Vigilance Committee members fighting Boko Haram demonstrated in the Moskota prefecture of the Far North against the small shares of a donation by President Biya. The committee members say a large part of the donation was diverted by authorities.
2 Cameroonian soldiers were wounded on Djibrili-Gouzda road in the Far North by a mine planted by suspected Boko Haram militants.

A suspected female Boko Haram suicide bomber was killed by a "Vigilance Committee" in the Far North. A second suicide bomber traveling with the first allegedly blew herself up, but the circumstances of the second death were not clear.
A civilian was killed in Vizi by Boko Haram militants.
7 Boko Haram militants were killed by Cameroonian military forces backed by Vigilance Committee members in the area of Homeka village in the Far North.
On 6 May, Cameroonian forces ambushed some Boko Haram fighters in Kouloubia, Limani. One dead.
Cameroonian military forces backed by Vigilance Committee members killed a Boko Haram militant during an ambush in the Kouloubia area near Limani.
Three civilians killed in Boko Haram attack.
Looting: On 4 May, some Boko Haram elements attacked Kouyape, close to Kolofata. They looted some shops and left.
On 3 May, a military truck was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram men in Wambashe, Mayo Sava. No causalities.

actor1: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: 3 Boko Haram militants were killed by members of the BIR after stealing cattle from Grea village near Kolofata.
Two young female suicide bombers exploded, killing only themselves.
On 2 May, Cameroonian militaries intercepted 2 women kamikazes in Mayo-Esolary, Kolofata: they killed the first, while the second blew herself up.
On 28 April, Boko Haram elements kidnapped women in Limani, Mayo Sava.

Elements of the 31th BIM arrived in the market of Tchollire and beat people up for about 3 hours with belts, batons and assault rifles. They were also subject to various abuses in the towns stadium. They also allegedly arrested 300 people for 2 days. Several people were seriously arrested during the incident. It was not clear what prompted the action.
12 armed men attacked village, killing two.
Armed group attacked Catholic mission and stopped by vigilante militia.
On 19 April, Boko Haram men ambushed a military patrol in Zgague, Logone et Chari. 3 soldiers dead.
Three soldiers killed and three injured in ambush by Boko Haram.
Angry at a recent court ruling involving land claims, villagers from Botaland protested outside of the state counsels office and are met by anti-riot police officers.
On 14 April, a Nigerian military vehicle was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram men on the Kumche - Banki axis, Mayo Sava. Ten dead and 11 wounded.

After being dispersed from protesting outside a courthouse, villagers went to Isokolo and caused material damage to the home the local chief, also burning his car. Then they set fire to the home of the local magistrate.
Angry at a recent court ruling involving land claims, over 200 villagers protested outside of the court house and were dispersed by heavily armed security.
On 11 April, Cameroonian and Nigerian forces launched a combined attack against Boko Haram in Logone et Chari along the border. 1275 hostages were freed.
On 11 April, an attack by Boko Haram men to the military post in Pagme, Mayo Sava, was repelled. 2 dead.
After gendarmes arrested a motorcycle driver, young people attacked the gendarmes station to demand his release.
Three vigilantes, one civilian, and two militants killed in Boko Haram attack. Huts burned.
On 8 April, an attack by Boko Haram men to the military post in Talkomari was repelled.
On 5 April, Cameroonian and Nigerian forces launched a combined attack against Boko Haram in Madaoueha, Logone et Chari. One soldier died and 8 were wounded.
On 4 April, Boko Haram men killed 5 civilians and wounded much more during an incursion to Sandawadjiri, Mayo Sava.
Three children were kidnapped and later escaped.
On 31 March, the village chief of Djiala (Kossa), Mayo Sava, was kidnapped by Boko Haram men.
Vigilantes killed a female suicide bomber before she could detonate.
Police used tear gas and arrested around 60 members of the opposition who gathered to protest constitutional changes that would allow President Biya to extend his term.
On 29 March, Boko Haram elements attacked Seradje, Mayo Sava: 1 dead (the village chief).
On 25 March, Boko Haram elements attacked Zourou, Mayo Sava: 1 dead (the village chief) and two wounded.
On 25 March, a military vehicle was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram men in Zamga, Mayo Sava. 4 soldiers were wounded.
On 25 March, a military vehicle was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram men on the Amchide-Ganse axis. 1 dead and 8 wounded.
Thousands marched in protest of extending President Biyas term limits.
Lawyers protested the detention of colleague Dessolice Piendjou, who was subsequently released.
On 20 March, following an incursion of Boko Haram men in Kerawa, Mayo Sava, one of the assailants was arrested.
On 20 March, a BH attack aiming at seizing some cattle heads in Homaka, Mayo Sava, was repelled by local militia and military forces.
Angry villagers blockaded the local chiefs palace and shot his son in the leg. Security forces arrived later that night and "secured the village".
In a 48 hour operation, Cameroon military battled 30 rebels from CAR, freeing 12 hostages
On 19 March, 2 people were killed and two others kidnapped by BH men in Guederou, Mayo Sava.
Dam workers went on strike to demand benefits including daily food rations. 15 - 20 arrested.

actor2: Police Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Prison Guards
notes: Prisoners rioted against overcrowding. Clashes with guards, police, and military led to death of at least three inmates and many injuries on both sides.
On 14 March, a militia's (not identified) truck was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram elements on the Bargaram-Abassoum axis.
Hundreds marched to protest poor health services after a pregnant woman and her two unborn twins died under suspicious circumstances in a hospital. Police dispersed protesters with tear gas.
On 13 March, two kamikazes exploded themselves in Talkomari, Mayo Sava, killing one vigilante.
Two suicide bombers killed themselves in an attempted attack. No other injuries reported.
Soldier shot and injured the wife of the deputy prosecutor. Motives unknown.
Armed men searched houses and kidnapped 5 people, injuring others, in three villages in the Tchabal area.
On 11 March, two woman kamikaze exploded themselves in Homaka's market, Mayo Sava, before arriving to their goal, the mosque.
On 11 March, a military vehicle was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram men in Gouzda Vreket, Mayo-Moskota.
On 11 March, a military vehicle was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram men in Gouzda Vreket, Mayo-Moskota.
On 10 March, the local militia chief was killed during an incursion of Boko Haram.
After a man on a motorcycle is robbed by unidentified criminals, one of the alleged perpetrators is caught and fatally lynched by a vigilante mob.
A civilian is killed when Boko Haram raid the village of Emchoukouli near Fotokol.
Boko Haram kill a family of four during a raid for supplies.
The military repels as attack by Boko Haram. No reported casualties.
On 02 March, a military patrol vehicle was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram men in Gouzda Vreket, Mayo-Moskota.
An army vehicle hits a mine laid by Boko Haram. An army captain is killed.
Boko Haram raid Kolofata for livestock resulting in a clash between the group and local vigilantes. The vigilantes managed to recover the stolen livestock.
Boko Haram abduct and kill a livestock breeder during a raid on Kolofata.
Three civilians are killed when their vehicle hits a landmine on the Boungour - Souardje road, near Makari.
Five killed when their vehicle hit a landmine likely placed by Boko Haram.
Boko Haram abduct six residents of Wawoulle village in Kolofata. The insurgents later execute four of the captors.
On 26 February, some rioters ransacked the local gendarmerie post.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Cameroon (1982-); Kanuri Ethnic Group (Cameroon)
notes: An off-duty Kanuri police officer was assassinated, allegedly by Boko Haram
Two soldiers are killed diffusing a bomb laid by Boko Haram on the Amchide- Kumshe road.

After a village chief was replaced under disputed circumstances, the regional governor intervened and villagers erected barricades, vandalized property, and fired shots in the air in protest. Several arrested.
19 - 22 killed and 105 wounded in double suicide bombing at the Meme market.
Two suicide bombers detonated near a school, killing only themselves.
On 14 February, a military truck was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram elements. Two dead and 5 wounded.
On 13 February, Boko Haram elements killed 13 people during an incursion in Tombokare, Logone et Chari, looting and burning several houses.
Boko Haram kill seven villagers and burn three churches in Tourou.
Two Boko Haram suicide bombers kill six and wound 50 civilians.
On 10 February, Boko Haram elements attacked Bla Dole, Logone et Chari. Causalities unknown.
On 9 February, Boko Haram elements killed 3 people during an incursion in Gore Moussa, Logone et Chari.
Property destruction: On 8 February, Boko Haram men burned down 246 houses, 1 school and 4 churches during an incursion in Hidoua, Mayo Tsanaga.
On 8 February, Boko Haram elements killed a person and injured another during an incursion in Shahat, Logone et Chari.
Military killed 15 Boko Haram militants and captured 2.
Boko Haram attacked the village of Madakar, killing 3.
Vigilantes tried to arrest a suspected member of Boko Haram, which detonated an explosive, killing himself and the three vigilantes. Local imam nearby also wounded.
At least six - including one soldier and the two attackers - were killed in a suicide attack.
On 29 January, a woman kamikaze exploded herself in Talkomari, Mayo Sava, killing only herself.
On 29 January, a military truck was hit by a landmine planted by Boko Haram militants in the area of Ashigashiya, Mayo Sava. 12 people wounded.
On 29 January, a suicide attack killed three people un Bargaram, Logone et Chari.
Military "pushed back" an incursion by Boko Haram, unknown number of deaths reported and at least three civilians wounded.
On the same night that the military "pushed back" Boko Haram in the area, explosions were heard in military camp in a separate incident.
Boko Haram suicide attack on a school killed at least six, including the two attackers, and injured about a dozen more. Vigilante militia arrested two others before they could detonate.
On 26 January, a double suicide attack in Kerawa, Mayo Sava, resulted in the injury of 19 people.
Four Boko Haram suicide bombers attacked a market, killing 37 and injuring 81.
Boko Haram attack left three dead, including a member of a vigilante militia.
Soldier killed by a mine likely planted by Boko Haram.
On 22 January, Cameroonian militaries ambushed Boko Haram men in Ashigashiya, Mayo Sava. One dead.
Suicide bomber detonated in mosque, killing himself and 4 others and injuring 2. A vigiliante group prevented more deaths by alerting worshippers just before the explosion.
Boko Haram suicide bomber killed himself and 12 civilians at a mosque in Kouyape, also known as Gaboua, just south of Kolofata.
Defence Forces pushed back an attack by Boko Haram in the Kolofata Sub-division, killing two assailants.
Two were killed overnight in the Kolofata area by Boko Haram. Troops responded and attackers fled.
On 11 January, a kamikaze died when his charge exploded in Talkomari, Mayo Sava.
Boko Haram gunmen attacked the village of Goura Tembe in the Makari area, killing one and injuring one and burning part of the town.
Boko Haram suicide bomber killed himself and injured three in a mosque in Danke village near Kolofata.
Boko Haram suicide bomber killed himself and two others in front of a mosque.
Boko Haram incursion; one farmer killed, two women kidnapped.
On 5 January, BH elements attacked Oulou Msao, Logone et Chari. One killed and 70 houses burned.
an attack by Boko Haram against the village of Ouro-Mari in the Makary Subdivision is foiled by a military response.
Boko Haram ambushed a vehicle transporting the Special Commissioner to Dabanga and the local chief of police, Ismaila Sago, kidnapping them. Two civilians dead.
04 January. 2 soldiers killed 2 police officers, accused of working in intelligence positions with Boko Haram in Dabanga, Logone Birni.
On 4 January, the FMM attacked BH elements who infiltrated Walashi refugees in Malashi, Mayo Sava. One dead.
A vigilante group chased away a Boko Haram suicide bomber, who then detonated, killing only herself.
On 2 January, gunshots were heard after a Boko-Haram incursion in Mozogo. 2 dead.
Two Boko Haram suicice bombers detonated explosives outside a mosque, killing themselves and injuring 27.
Two Boko Haram suicide bombers killed themselves and injured one other; they detonated their explosives as they ran away from villagers who foiled their plan to attack civilians.
A Boko Haram suicide bomber killed herself and injured two civilians with a bomb in the village of Tolkomari in the far north.

A vigilante group discovered a group of female suicide bombers trying to get access to a mosque and alerted the authorities. A vigilante hit one bomber with an arrow and then she detonated her explosive. Security forces killed another bomber without detonation.
Eight civilians and one suicide bomber were killed in an attack by Boko Haram. 22 injured
After two suicide bombers attacked civilians in Waza, a third potential bomber was shot and killed by soldiers.
At least two suicide bombers detonated in Waza, killing at least six people including themselves.
Two soldiers killed by a land mine.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Military forces carried out "mopping up exercises" against Boko Haram over three days in the Mayo-Sava area of extreme north region, killing around 100 militants and releasing hundreds of their hostages.
Two Boko Haram suicide bombers killed themselves and 5 civilians, injuring at least one soldier near the Dabanga military base.
Boko Haram attacked the village of Gouzoudou, killing at least five and burning around a dozen houses.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Military forces carried out "mopping up exercises" against Boko Haram over three days in the Mayo-Sava area of extreme north region, killing around 100 militants and releasing hundreds of their hostages.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Military forces carried out "mopping up exercises" against Boko Haram over three days in the Mayo-Sava area of extreme north region, killing around 100 militants and releasing hundreds of their hostages.
Boko Haram killed one and wounded two, burning buildings in a village near Fotokol.
Boko Haram attacked a suburb of Fotokol, killing one and burning buildings.
Four teenage girls associated with Boko Haram blew themselves up, killing a traditional chief and four of his family members.

assoc_actor_2: ADDEC: Association for the Defense of the Rights of Students of Cameroon
notes: Arrests: Thierry Batum, president of the Association for the Rights of Students of Cameroon (ADDEC), was arrested for "inciting revolt" for organizing a protest.
Army launched ground and air assault against Boko Haram, capturing 19.
5 Boko Haram killed in firefight with Cameroonian army
Property destruction: 10 Boko Haram attacked the home of a local leader with grenades and burned down a school.
Boko Haram attacked two large trucks, burning one and taking the other with the driver and his assistant on board.
The regional president of the Cameroon Peoples Democratic Movement was assassinated by Boko Haram. Authorities responded by killing around 10 assailants in the extreme north.
Boko Haram killed five people in an incursion into Bia.
Boko Haram assassinated the son of a tribal chief.
At least 3 civilians and 1 young female suicide bomber were killed in an attack attributed to Boko Haram. Authorities responded, shooting and killing a second bomber.
Security Measures: The government began providing security equipment, including light firearms and knives, to vigilante groups in the extreme north as part of national efforts against Boko Haram.
Boko Haram attacked the village of Barakesse, killing two civilians and burning around 40 homes.
Boko Haram conducted an incursion into the village of Gafe, abducting 6 civilians before the military could be alerted.
A woman was beheaded by unidentified assailants on disputed farm land near Buea Road.
The military retook control of Keraoua after Boko Haram took control earlier in the morning. Reports indicated that Boko Haram fled as additional troops arrived, and there was no continued fighting.
One day after attacking Keraoua and killing several civilians, Boko Haram "seized control of the town" as military forces were sent in for reinforcement.
About 20 Boko Haram militants on motorcycles attacked Keraoua, killing at least 9 and kidnapping 20.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Angry at the recent death of a motorcyclist at the hands of the military, protestors clashed with the military and set fire to a military base. One soldier was injured and military equipment was damanged.
Military responded to a Boko Haram raid on the town of Doulo, engaging in a gun battle with the militants. Casualties unknown.
Boko Haram attacked Ashigashiya. Military response led to violent clashes.
A motorcyclist was killed and another was seriously injured when troops fired on them in an attempt to impose nightly travel restrictions.
Boko Haram raided the village of Doulo, killing 8 and injuring 9.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Boko Haram ambushed military forces from the Rapid Intervention Battalion. Casualties unknown.

Boko Haram raided Cameroonian territory near the village of Soueram in the Far Nort. Military response led to "heavy fighting". Coordinates are approximate based on Soueram's location 17 km from Fotokol.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Boko Haram ambushed a military vehicle, killing an officer from the Rapid Intervention Force and injuring three other soldiers.

Movement of forces: About 90 US troops were deployed to Cameroon to help stop the spread of Boko Haram. A total of 300 troops will eventually be deployed, meant to be armed for protection but not for combat.
Twin suicide bombings by young women likely affiliated with Boko Haram killed at least 9 and wounded dozens in the town of Kangeleri, near Mora.
Suspected Boko Haram gunmen launched rockets at two commercial trucks near Dabanga, injuring at least one.
After Boko Haram attacked the village of Siguel, they headed towards Bodo where a vigilante militia fought back and captured 5 militants.
Over 10 Boko Haram attacked the village of Siguel, near Bodo, setting it on fire. No report of casualties.
In retaliation for arrests in Bodo, Boko Haram attacked the nearby village of Mafoufou, burning most of the homes.
Around 300 pro-government youth held a flashmob in central Yaounde to demonstrate patriotism and support for troops fighting Boko Haram.
Boko Haram killed 8 and kidnapped a young girl in an attack on a village in the Tika area. Over 100 houses were burned along with at least one vehicle, and several were injured.
Clashes between military and Boko Haram in Amchide for second day. 15 Boko Haram killed on Sept 22.
2 women suicide bombers of Boko Haram killed themselves and injured two farmers.
Clashes between military and Boko Haram in Amchide. 2 Boko Haram killed on Sept 21.

Two Boko Haram suicide bombers detonate 200 meters from each other in the market in Mora. Civilians were targeted. 5 killed, including an off-duty policeman, two civilians, and the two suicide bombers. 29 wounded.
Boko Haram ambushed soldiers on patrol in Dabanga, killing two and burning two vehicles.
About 9 civilians were killed by suspected Boko Haram assailants who also burned several houses.
The army pushed back an attack by Boko Haram, killing at least three.
At least 9 were killed and 14 injured in twin suicide attacks by two teenage boys likely linked to Boko Haram. The attacks took place in the Latin Quarter and the main market of Kolofata.
Nearly 1000 soldiers marched to protest lack of payment for service as peacekeepers in CAR.
Hundreds of angry passengers demonstrated in front of the Camair-Co office after their flights were repeatedly cancelled. They burned tires

At least 30 people were killed in the far north in successive suicide attacks in Keraoua - one in the marketplace and the second near a military camp. The suicide bombers were women; no group has claimed responsibility though preliminary blame is pointed at Boko Haram.

At least 30 people were killed in the far north in successive suicide attacks in Keraoua - one in the marketplace and the second near a military camp. The suicide bombers were women; no group has claimed responsibility though preliminary blame is pointed at Boko Haram.
Arrests: Authorities arrested journalist Simon Ateba who was investigating the conditions of Nigerian refugees in the far north. He was deatined for four days before being released.
Boko Haram attacked the village of Blame, torching homes and killing 8 civilians and 2 soldiers.
On the third day that protesters tried to prevent the military from gaining access to Afrique Media in Douala, soldiers used batons and tear gas to clear the crowd and seal the offices.

Arrests: Refugees from CAR have reportedly been involved in frequent theft and hostage taking, prompting the Cameroonian police to initiative a wave of arrests of all CAR refugees found outside of predetermined humanitarian camps.
For a second day in a row, protesters prevented the military from gaining access to the offices and studios of Afrique Media in Douala by surrounding the building.
Hundreds of Boko Haram fighters attacked Ashigashiya and Cameroonian troops responded, leaving 10 militants and 1 soldier dead and 2 soldiers injured. Some arrests were also made.
Security Measures: Police sealed off the weekly market in Maroua to conduct a security raid and identity checks.
When the military attempted to shut down the offices and studios of Afrique Media in Douala, protesters surrounded the building and prevented them from gaining access.

Boko Haram attacked the villages of Tchakarmari and Kangaleri (geo coordinates not available) in the North. They burned houses, killed at least 8 (fatalities spread over two locations), and kidnapped up to 145 civilians.

Boko Haram set fire to police and military facilities in Afade, killing one. Reports differ on whether the person killed was a gendarme or an inmate. 3 other inmates died in the fires. 4 soldiers and 3 policeman reportedly missing.
Boko Haram behead 3 people in Tchebe-Tchebe, and set fire to land.
A suicide bomber attacked a popular night spot in the Pont Vert neighbourhood of Maroua, killing at least 21 civilians and injuring 67.
At least 20 people were killed, including the perpetrators, after 2 allegedly female suicide bombers blew themselves up in a busy marketplace in Maroua. At least 32 people were wounded.
The village of Kaforam was allegedly occupied by Boko Haram fighters.
More than 20 civilians were killed when more than 80 suspected Boko Haram fighters attacked the village of Kamouna near Lake Chad. 7 soldiers were present but they were overwhelmed by the attackers.
More than 20 people were killed when more than 80 suspected Boko Haram fighters attacked the village of Kamouna near Lake Chad. 7 soldiers were present but they were overwhelmed by the attackers.
Residents of Lobo district in Lekie set up a protest camp on the Yaounde-Douala highway to demand compensation related to the construction of the highway for their village which has not appeared.

A suspected Boko Haram militant was killed during an attack on a Cameroonian military post in the locality of Ldaoutsas (lat/longs not available) in the Far North region. A civilian was also wounded in the attack.

Twin suicide blasts killed at least 13 and injured 17 others, many of them soldiers, at a bar in the border town of Fotokol. The bombers were dressed in burqas and struck as locals were breaking their Ramadan fast. Of the 13 killed (all reportedly during the first blast at the bar), 1 was a Chadian soldier, while of those wounded at least 4 were Chadian soldiers and 3 were Cameroonian soldiers. Most of the soldiers were wounded in the second attack which hit as soldiers from a nearby special forces camp approached the bar after the first blast, although other reports say the second bomber headed straight for the military camp and there was a gunfight before the detonation. The attack were claimed by Boko Haram.

Twin suicide blasts killed at least 13 and injured 17 others, many of them soldiers, at a bar in the border town of Fotokol. The bombers were dressed in burqas and struck as locals were breaking their Ramadan fast. Of the 13 killed (all reportedly during the first blast at the bar), 1 was a Chadian soldier, while of those wounded at least 4 were Chadian soldiers and 3 were Cameroonian soldiers. Most of the soldiers were wounded in the second attack which hit as soldiers from a nearby special forces camp approached the bar after the first blast, although other reports say the second bomber headed straight for the military camp and there was a gunfight before the detonation. The attack were claimed by Boko Haram.
Boko Haram clashed with a vigilante patrol in the Mayo-Sava department, leaving three vigilantes dead.
Boko Haram attacked the village of Bodo in the extreme north but were repelled by military forces, who killed 3-24 militants.
100 students at the University of Maroua protested in tribute to a fellow student who was recently killed in a fight with a uniformed military man.
Boko Haram attacked Dabanga and Ngassa, stealing supplies and taking hostages. Two security personnel died and many were injured in pursuit of the militants.
Boko Haram attacked Dabanga and Ngassa, stealing supplies and taking hostages. Two security personnel died and many were injured in pursuit of the militants.
Two Cameroonian soldiers were killed and around 20 injured when Boko Haram attacked using grenades in the far north.
Women from 11 Protestant organizations marched for peace and against Boko Haram.
"Two INGO national staff members were shot after being ambushed by armed assailants while travelling from the project site back to their base of operations."
Movement of forces: Cameroon sent military reinforcements to the border with Nigeria, near Maroua, in anticipation of further fighting with Boko Haram.
A Cameroonian soldier was killed and two others injured while on patrol in the far north when they were ambused by Boko Haram militants.
Boko Haram clashed with the Cameroonian military on a patrol near Zevelet, killing two soldiers, and injuring three soldiers and a civilian. The military returned fire, killing around 60 militants.
Farmers started a series of protests against the Socapalm multinational firm by occupying the Dibombari palm plantation.
An unidentified armed group attacked a market in the district of Betare Oya, taking hostages. Following a clash with the local population, the hostages were released.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: Boko Haram fighters attacked a Cameroonian military position and burned down houses in Amchide but were repulsed without reported casualties.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: Boko Haram militants, the deadly Islamist sect, has attacked two villages - Bia and Blaberi - overnight in northern Cameroon. Most recent death toll indicates 19 people killed in the violence; many of the victims decapitated.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: Boko Haram militants, the deadly Islamist sect, has killed no fewer than 10 people in overnight attacks on two villages in northern Cameroon. There were consecutive attacks by Boko Haram in Bia and Blaberi in the district of Kolofata in the early morning, the military reported.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: Boko Haram attacked Dabanga village and killed three civilians.

15 heavily armed men likely from a CAR rebel group tried to carry out a kidnapping of 8 civilians but locals attacked with guns and machetes, releasing the hostages, killing several militants and taking two captive. Some were wounded but final injury and death counts are unknown.

20 March-5 April. A video emerged in July 2018 showing soldiers executing two women and two children. Analysis has determined that the incident likely occurred between 20 March - 5 April 2015 near a military barrack by Zelevet. Seven soldiers were later arrested for the incident. The civilians were suspected of helping Boko Haram.

16 people were kidnapped when a bus was seized near the CAR border at Babio by a heavily armed group believed to be made up of ex-Seleka rebels. Those kidnapped include four traditional leaders and the head of the Organization of Women of the Cameroon Peoples Democratic Movement (ORDPC). Some were later released, but reports conflicted over how many.
Around 8,000 people marched against Boko Haram and to show solidarity with the security forces.
Movement of forces: 2,500 Chadian troops who were fighting Boko Haram in Nigeria crossed back over to the Cameroonian towns of Fotokol and Maltam.

Thousands of women marched to commemorate International Womens Day, show support for the countrys fight against Boko Haram, and advocate for womens rights and security. Police and their wives marched alongside of them to assure security and support.
Several thousand people, primarily youths, protested to denounce Boko Haram and its leader Abubakar Shekau.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: 2 Cameroonian soldiers and 12 civilians died as a result of IEDs on the Mora-Limani road set by Boko Haram.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: Seven or eight villagers were killed when they fought back against Boko Haram fighters who stole 70 cows and torched houses in Gaboua. Nine of the militants were also killed by the villagers who were armed with clubs, machetes and bows and arrows.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion

A human rights group claims Cameroons security forces have been using torture and illegal detention in the fight against Boko Haram in the far north. 50 people reportedly suffocated while locked in a cell and were buried in mass graves.
Police officers who were patrolling the coast by boat exchanged fire with seven Nigerian gunmen that led to the death of two policemen and the disappearance of a third.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: In ongoing clashes, Boko Haram attacked the positions of the Chadian military and Chad continued to reinforce its positions in Fotokol. 13 militants and one Chadian soldier were killed, several were wounded.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: Boko Haram hijacked a bus of 30 passengers in Tourou.

notes: Extremists from Boko Haram attacked the town of Kolofata, looting food and livestock.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: Nine Cameroonian soldiers were injured in an attack by Boko Haram.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad

Thousands marched in support of the Cameroonian army which is confronting Boko Haram.

notes: Around 800 Boko Haram militants attacked the town of Fotokol, killing 81 civilians and setting fire to buildings before being repelled by regional forces. Up to 500 civilians were wounded
Hundreds demonstrated in favor of national security forces who are fighting Boko Haram in the north.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: Boko Haram attacked a Chadian army contingent near Fotokol. 3 soldiers were killed and 12 wounded, mostly by explosive devices, and 123 militants were killed according to the military.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: Boko Haram attacked the Dola village to steal a horse, and villagers fought back with bows and arrows. Three locals and three militants were killed in the exchange.

notes: Exposives buried by Boko Haram on the Fotokol - Kousseri road have recently killed an unspecified number of military personnel.

notes: Troops fought in "heavy clashes" with Boko Haram, leaving two Cameroonian soliders injured.

Thousands of Cameroonians rallied in Kousseri in support of Chadian troops which arrived there to assist Cameroon and Nigeria in their fight against Boko Haram.

Movement of forces: Chad has deployed a large military force, including at least 400 vehicles and helicopters, to assist Nigeria and Cameroon in their fight against Boko Haram. The vehicles arrived in Kousseri on Jan.17.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: 3 people were killed by Boko Haram fighters while traveling in a pick-up truck.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: Boko Haram fighters attacked a Cameroonian military base in Kolofata, killing 1 soldier. The Cameroonian military claims it killed 143 Boko Haram fighters and repulsed the attack at the military base and other strategic areas around the locality over 5 hours.

Recruitment: Cameroon has said it is recruiting 20,000 more defence and security forces to fight Boko Haram following reports that the militant group, based in Nigeria, is recruiting young Cameroonians to fight for them.

actor1: Boko Haram - Jamatu Ahli is-Sunnah lid-Dawatai wal-Jihad
notes: Boko Haram fighters attacked a bus on the Waza-Mora road, killing 11 passengers and injuring 6 others. The fighters then took the remaining passengers hostage and transported them away using the bus.
At least 15 people, including 12 security personnel, were wounded in a clash with residents of Bamali while police attempted to receover firearms allegedly stolen from Bamali palace.

A confrontation between the Bamukumbit and Baligangsen villages of the Balikumbut sub-division led to 1 fatality and the destruction of four houses in Baligangsen.

Rebels from the Central African Republic attacked a village on the border between the CAR and Cameroon. The rebels kidnapped 16 people and demanded a ransom. Most of the kidnapped wre Mbororo cattle herders since they are known to be wealthy.

Clashes broke out between the people of Oku and the people of Mbessa when Oku people attacked Mbessa people while doing community work on a road. The Mbessa retaliated by killing five Oku. Both groups have fought for years over land rights and boundari

Police raided the hideout of armed group. The two groups exchanged gunfire, resulting in seven of the armed group being killed. The armed group was known for attacking villages and looting cars on the road.
Citizens from the villages of Bawock and Bali Nyongha began burning down each others homes when a dispute occured over farming land. Over 300 homes were burned.

Three people died and several injured when road bandits attacked an Cameroonian army convoy returning from the border of Nigeria and Equatorial Guinea. It was not reported which side of the conflict had casualties.
