Men dressed in military fatigues but not Cameroonian since they didnt speak the language, killed a woman they were robbing. Twenty more people were injured by the men.
Violence broke out between the Banfaw and the Bororos over land rights. Three people died but it is not reported which side of the conflict the deaths were on.
The Bagam and the Bameyan clashed durin the month of September. Thirteen people died but it is not stated which side of the violence the casualties are on.
Clashes erupted between the Banyangui and the Bororos over land. In the dispute, 13 were killed. It is not stated which ethnic group the people killed were from.
An unidentified armed group raided the headquarters of Cameroons opposition party, Social Democratic Front (SDF). A party official was killed and eleven people injured.
1,000 people protested against police brutality.
Workers Representatives of the South West Development Authority (SOWEDA) staged a protest to demand work wages and explain termination letters of people who were fired.
Demonstrators protested French policies towards Cameroon and Africa.

An armed group attacked Bororos, a group of cattle herders, in Djalingo, a border town with Central African Republic. Children were kidnapped and money stolen. The group may have been former rebels from CAR.

Bandits, who were thought to be ex-rebels from the Central African Republic, were accused of plotting an attack on a village. In response to the planned attack, police and soldiers fought the bandits in a gun battle. The area is known for highway robb

In the formerly disputed of area, Bukassi, a Cameroon soldier was killed in overnight attacks by Nigerian forces. Cameroonian soldiers did not respond. They were ordered not to in order to try and maintain peace in the area.
Cameroon accuses Nigerian troops of firing on soldiers

Three bandits were killed by officers after the bandits were suspected of potentially raiding settlements. Armed groups are known for raiding homes and cattle along the borders of Cameroon and Central African Republic.

In the year 2005, clashes between the sedentary Gbaya and the nomadic Foulbe (Fulani) resulted in twenty people dead. Clashes were over land disputes. It is not reported which side received casualties.

Nigerian military shell Cameroonian security post

Three villages in Cameroon on the border of the Central African Republic were attacked by bandits. Three people were killed and 24 kidnapped. Among those killed was a traditional chief. Fighting is thought to be aggravated by former fighers in Central A
Two students were killed by police while protesting for better facilities at Buea University and for the release of students arrested during earlier protests..
Protesters marched for more security in the city. Residents felt that there was a resurgence of insecurity.
Protesters demanded justice over the murder of John Khontem, a SDF politician.
4,000 Cameroonians marched against President Biya after the leader of the Social Democratic Front (SDF), John Khontem, was killed. Khontem accused Bayis political party of harassing activists.

John Khontem, a member of the opposition group Social Democratic Front (SDF), was killed after openly criticizing the ruling party, Cameroonian Peoples Democratic Rally (RDPC) and the local leaders in Bamenda.

The Coalition for National Reconciliation and Reconstruction (CNRR), a main opposition party, held a protest to demand fair elections. Police forces did not interrupt the rally for fear of looking bad internationally. Instead, police forces assualted 2

Police forces assualted 20 civilians within viewing range of a rally held by the Coalition for National Reconciliation and Reconstruction (CNRR). Police forces did not interrupt the rally for fear of looking bad internationally and instead attacked civi

Demonstrators protested for reforms in the electoral system three months before elections in October. The protest was led by opposition parties. Police stopped the protest with violence. Protesters were beaten up and two were arrested.

A group identified as Bororos, a sub ehtnic group of Fulani, attacked Cameroonians in a cross border attack. In a four attack on Koza, 15 cattle were stolen, 100 houses burned and nine villagers killed.
Teachers protested to regularly received their wages and to clear their salary arrears. Police intervened in the protest but it is unclear the extent of how they intervened.
Trade unions and taxi drivers protested against police harassment. Protesters were stating that police would solicite them for money or indiscriminately take driving licenses away.
Trade unions and taxi drivers protested against police harassment. Protesters were stating that police would solicite them for money or indiscriminately take driving licenses away.

Cameroonians protested the deportation of Cameroon citizens from Equatorial Guinea at the Equatorial Guinean consulate. The deportation was seen as racist. Rioters set the consul generals vehicle on fire.
Thousands of Bakassi residents protest as UN officials visit the region
Traders protested against police harassment. Traders stated that police were seizing goods imported from Nigeria.

After a motorcycle taxi driver was shot by police at a check point, witnesses of the event went to the police station. Police responded with water canons and fired guns in the air to disperse the crowd. Two people were killed in the rioting,
Nigerians protested a Court hearing that ordered the handing over of Bakassi to Cameroon.
4 Mbororo (fulani) activists detained and tortured.
